<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Buddhism</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Religion and philosophy based on Buddha's teachings</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"Buddhadharma" and "Buddhist" redirect here. For the magazine, see <a href="/wiki/Buddhadharma:_The_Practitioner%27s_Quarterly" title="Buddhadharma: The Practitioner's Quarterly">Buddhadharma: The Practitioner's Quarterly</a>. For the racehorse, see <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_(horse)" title="Buddhist (horse)">Buddhist (horse)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>

</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="background:#FFD068;padding-bottom:0; text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Nirvana_(Buddhism)" title="Nirvana (Buddhism)">Nirvāṇa</a></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content hlist" style="padding-top:0; background-color:#FDE7B9; border: 2px solid #FDE7B9">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Enlightenment_in_Buddhism" title="Enlightenment in Buddhism">Awakening</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Four_stages_of_enlightenment" title="Four stages of enlightenment">Four Stages</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Arhat" title="Arhat">Arhat</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pratyekabuddha" title="Pratyekabuddha">Pratyekabuddha</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Bodhisattva" title="Bodhisattva">Bodhisattva</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Buddhahood" title="Buddhahood">Buddha</a></li></ul></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="background:#FFD068;padding-bottom:0; text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Schools_of_Buddhism" title="Schools of Buddhism">Traditions</a></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content hlist" style="padding-top:0; background-color:#FDE7B9; border: 2px solid #FDE7B9">

</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="background:#FFD068;padding-bottom:0; text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Buddhism_by_country" title="Buddhism by country">Buddhism by country</a></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content hlist" style="padding-top:0; background-color:#FDE7B9; border: 2px solid #FDE7B9">

</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-below hlist">

<li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Buddhism" title="Outline of Buddhism">Outline</a></li></ul>
<ul><li><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:P_religion_world.svg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer" data-file-height="360" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="28" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/P_religion_world.svg/31px-P_religion_world.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/P_religion_world.svg/47px-P_religion_world.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/P_religion_world.svg/62px-P_religion_world.svg.png 2x" width="31"/></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Religion" title="Portal:Religion">Religion portal</a></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1063604349">.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:inline;font-size:88%;font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .navbar-collapse{float:left;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .navbar-boxtext{word-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .navbar ul{display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::before{margin-right:-0.125em;content:"[ "}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::after{margin-left:-0.125em;content:" ]"}.mw-parser-output .navbar li{word-spacing:-0.125em}.mw-parser-output .navbar a>span,.mw-parser-output .navbar a>abbr{text-decoration:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-mini abbr{font-variant:small-caps;border-bottom:none;text-decoration:none;cursor:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-full{font-size:114%;margin:0 7em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-mini{font-size:114%;margin:0 4em}</style><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Buddhism" title="Template:Buddhism"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Buddhism" title="Template talk:Buddhism"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Buddhism&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dharma_Wheel_(2).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="697" data-file-width="697" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Dharma_Wheel_%282%29.svg/220px-Dharma_Wheel_%282%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Dharma_Wheel_%282%29.svg/330px-Dharma_Wheel_%282%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Dharma_Wheel_%282%29.svg/440px-Dharma_Wheel_%282%29.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dharma_Wheel_(2).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Dharmachakra" title="Dharmachakra">Dharmachakra</a>, a sacred symbol which represents Buddhism and its <a href="/wiki/Schools_of_Buddhism" title="Schools of Buddhism">traditions</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vesak.JPG"><img alt="An image of a lantern used in the Vesak Festival, which celebrates the birth, enlightenment and Parinirvana of Gautama Buddha." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Vesak.JPG/220px-Vesak.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Vesak.JPG/330px-Vesak.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Vesak.JPG/440px-Vesak.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vesak.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An image of a lantern used in the <a href="/wiki/Vesak" title="Vesak">Vesak Festival</a>, which celebrates the birth, <a href="/wiki/Enlightenment_(spiritual)" title="Enlightenment (spiritual)">enlightenment</a> and <a href="/wiki/Parinirvana" title="Parinirvana">Parinirvana</a> of <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Gautama Buddha</a></div></div></div>
<p><b>Buddhism</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'b' in 'buy'">b</span><span title="/ʊ/: 'u' in 'push'">ʊ</span><span title="'d' in 'dye'">d</span><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="'z' in 'zoom'">z</span><span title="/əm/: 'm' in 'rhythm'">əm</span></span>/</a></span></span> <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key"><i title="English pronunciation respelling"><span style="font-size:90%">BUU</span>-dih-zəm</i></a>, <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'b' in 'buy'">b</span><span title="/uː/: 'oo' in 'goose'">uː</span><span title="'d' in 'dye'">d</span></span>-/</a></span></span> <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key"><i title="English pronunciation respelling"><span style="font-size:90%">BOOD</span>-</i></a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWells2008_1-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWells2008-1">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoach2011_2-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoach2011-2">[2]</a></sup> also known as <b>Buddha Dharma</b> or <b>Dharmavinaya</b> (<abbr title="translation">transl.</abbr><span> "doctrines and disciplines"</span>), is an <a href="/wiki/Indian_religions" title="Indian religions">Indian religion</a> or <a href="/wiki/Indian_philosophy#Buddhist_philosophy" title="Indian philosophy">philosophical tradition</a> based on a <a href="/wiki/Pre-sectarian_Buddhism" title="Pre-sectarian Buddhism">series of original teachings</a> attributed to <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Gautama Buddha</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> Originating in <a href="/wiki/History_of_India" title="History of India">ancient India</a> as a movement professing <span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn"><a href="/wiki/%C5%9Arama%E1%B9%87a" title="Śramaṇa">śramaṇa</a></i></span> between the 6th and 4th centuries BCE, it <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road_transmission_of_Buddhism" title="Silk Road transmission of Buddhism">gradually spread throughout much of Asia via the Silk Road</a>. Presently, it is the <a href="/wiki/Major_religious_groups" title="Major religious groups">world's fourth-largest religion</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELopez2001239_5-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELopez2001239-5">[5]</a></sup> with over 520 million followers (<b>Buddhists</b>) who comprise seven percent of the global population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012a_6-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012a-6">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> Buddhism encompasses a variety of traditions, beliefs, and spiritual practices that are largely based on the Buddha's teachings and their <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_philosophy" title="Buddhist philosophy">resulting interpreted philosophies</a>.
</p><p>As expressed in the "<a href="/wiki/Four_Noble_Truths" title="Four Noble Truths">Four Noble Truths</a>" of the Buddha, the goal of Buddhism is to overcome the suffering (<span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Du%E1%B8%A5kha" title="Duḥkha">duḥkha</a></i></span>) caused by desire (<span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Ta%E1%B9%87h%C4%81" title="Taṇhā">taṇhā</a></i></span>) and ignorance (<span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Avidy%C4%81_(Buddhism)" title="Avidyā (Buddhism)">avidyā</a></i></span>) of reality's true nature, including impermanence (<span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Impermanence#Buddhism" title="Impermanence">anitya</a></i></span>) and non-self (<span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Anatt%C4%81" title="Anattā">anātman</a></i></span>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> Most Buddhist traditions emphasize transcending the individual self through the attainment of <span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Nirvana_(Buddhism)" title="Nirvana (Buddhism)">nirvāṇa</a></i></span> (<abbr title="literal translation">lit.</abbr><span style="white-space: nowrap;"> </span>'quenching') or by <a href="/wiki/Bodhisattva" title="Bodhisattva">following the path of Buddhahood</a>, ending the cycle of death and rebirth (<span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83s%C4%81ra_(Buddhism)" title="Saṃsāra (Buddhism)">saṃsāra</a></i></span>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199827–28,_73–74_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199827–28,_73–74-9">[9]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201399_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201399-10">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPowers2007392–393,_415_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPowers2007392–393,_415-11">[11]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Schools_of_Buddhism" title="Schools of Buddhism">Buddhist schools</a> vary in their interpretation of the paths to liberation (<span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Buddhist_paths_to_liberation" title="Buddhist paths to liberation">mārga</a></i></span>) as well as the relative importance and canonicity assigned to various <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_texts" title="Buddhist texts">Buddhist texts</a>, and their specific teachings and practices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams1989275ff_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams1989275ff-12">[12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson1997xx_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson1997xx-13">[13]</a></sup> Widely observed practices include: <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_meditation" title="Buddhist meditation">meditation</a>; observance of <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_ethics" title="Buddhist ethics">moral precepts</a>; <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_monasticism" title="Buddhist monasticism">monasticism</a>; "<a href="/wiki/Refuge_in_Buddhism" title="Refuge in Buddhism">taking refuge</a>" in the Buddha, the <span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Dharma#Buddhism" title="Dharma">dharma</a></i></span>, and the <span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%85gha" title="Saṅgha">saṅgha</a></i></span>; and the cultivation of perfections (<span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn"><a href="/wiki/P%C4%81ramit%C4%81" title="Pāramitā">pāramitā</a></i></span>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
</p><p>Two major extant branches of Buddhism are generally recognized by scholars: <i><a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravāda</a></i> (<abbr title="literal translation">lit.</abbr><span style="white-space: nowrap;"> </span>'School of the Elders') and <span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81y%C4%81na" title="Mahāyāna">Mahāyāna</a></i></span> (<abbr title="literal translation">lit.</abbr><span style="white-space: nowrap;"> </span>'Great Vehicle'). The <i>Theravāda</i> branch has a widespread following in <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Sri_Lanka" title="Buddhism in Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a> as well as in <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Southeast_Asia" title="Buddhism in Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a> (namely <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Myanmar" title="Buddhism in Myanmar">Myanmar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Thailand" title="Buddhism in Thailand">Thailand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Laos" title="Buddhism in Laos">Laos</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Cambodia" title="Buddhism in Cambodia">Cambodia</a>). The <i><span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn">Mahāyāna</i></span></i> branch—which includes the traditions of <a href="/wiki/Zen" title="Zen">Zen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pure_Land_Buddhism" title="Pure Land Buddhism">Pure Land</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nichiren_Buddhism" title="Nichiren Buddhism">Nichiren</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tiantai" title="Tiantai">Tiantai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tendai" title="Tendai">Tendai</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Shingon_Buddhism" title="Shingon Buddhism">Shingon</a>—is predominantly practiced in <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Nepal" title="Buddhism in Nepal">Nepal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Bhutan" title="Buddhism in Bhutan">Bhutan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Buddhism" title="Chinese Buddhism">China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Malaysia" title="Buddhism in Malaysia">Malaysia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Vietnam" title="Buddhism in Vietnam">Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Taiwan" title="Buddhism in Taiwan">Taiwan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Korean_Buddhism" title="Korean Buddhism">Korea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Japan" title="Buddhism in Japan">Japan</a>. Additionally, <span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vajray%C4%81na" title="Vajrayāna">Vajrayāna</a></i></span> (<abbr title="literal translation">lit.</abbr><span style="white-space: nowrap;"> </span>'Indestructible Vehicle'), a body of teachings attributed to <a href="/wiki/Mahasiddha" title="Mahasiddha">Indian adepts</a>, may be viewed as a separate branch or an aspect of the <i><span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn">Mahāyāna</i></span></i> tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-White_2000_21_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-White_2000_21-15">[15]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism" title="Tibetan Buddhism">Tibetan Buddhism</a>, which preserves the <span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn">Vajrayāna</i></span> teachings of eighth-century India, is practiced in the <a href="/wiki/Himalayan_states" title="Himalayan states">Himalayan states</a> as well as in <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Mongolia" title="Buddhism in Mongolia">Mongolia</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPowers200726–27_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPowers200726–27-16">[16]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Kalmykia" title="Kalmykia">Russian Kalmykia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> Historically, until the early 2nd millennium, Buddhism <a href="/wiki/Decline_of_Buddhism_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="Decline of Buddhism in the Indian subcontinent">was widely practiced in the Indian subcontinent</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Keown2004p208_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-Keown2004p208-20">[20]</a></sup> it also had a foothold to some extent in other places such as <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Afghanistan" title="Buddhism in Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Uzbekistan" title="Buddhism in Uzbekistan">Uzbekistan</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_the_Philippines" title="Buddhism in the Philippines">Philippines</a>.
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Life_of_the_Buddha"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Life of the Buddha</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Worldview"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Worldview</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3"><a href="#Four_Noble_Truths_–_dukkha_and_its_ending"><span class="tocnumber">2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Four Noble Truths – <i>dukkha</i> and its ending</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#The_cycle_of_rebirth"><span class="tocnumber">2.2</span> <span class="toctext">The cycle of rebirth</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-5"><a href="#Saṃsāra"><span class="tocnumber">2.2.1</span> <span class="toctext">Saṃsāra</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-6"><a href="#Rebirth"><span class="tocnumber">2.2.2</span> <span class="toctext">Rebirth</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-7"><a href="#Karma"><span class="tocnumber">2.2.3</span> <span class="toctext">Karma</span></a></li>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Life_of_the_Buddha">Life of the Buddha</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mahajanapadas_(c._500_BCE).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="771" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Mahajanapadas_%28c._500_BCE%29.png/220px-Mahajanapadas_%28c._500_BCE%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Mahajanapadas_%28c._500_BCE%29.png/330px-Mahajanapadas_%28c._500_BCE%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Mahajanapadas_%28c._500_BCE%29.png/440px-Mahajanapadas_%28c._500_BCE%29.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mahajanapadas_(c._500_BCE).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ancient kingdoms and cities of India during the time of the Buddha (circa 500 BCE) – modern-day India, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" representing the stage of his <a href="/wiki/Asceticism" title="Asceticism">asceticism</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Four_Scenes_from_the_Life_of_the_Buddha_-_Enlightenment_-_Kushan_dynasty,_late_2nd_to_early_3rd_century_AD,_Gandhara,_schist_-_Freer_Gallery_of_Art_-_DSC05124.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3240" data-file-width="4320" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Four_Scenes_from_the_Life_of_the_Buddha_-_Enlightenment_-_Kushan_dynasty%2C_late_2nd_to_early_3rd_century_AD%2C_Gandhara%2C_schist_-_Freer_Gallery_of_Art_-_DSC05124.JPG/220px-thumbnail.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Four_Scenes_from_the_Life_of_the_Buddha_-_Enlightenment_-_Kushan_dynasty%2C_late_2nd_to_early_3rd_century_AD%2C_Gandhara%2C_schist_-_Freer_Gallery_of_Art_-_DSC05124.JPG/330px-thumbnail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Four_Scenes_from_the_Life_of_the_Buddha_-_Enlightenment_-_Kushan_dynasty%2C_late_2nd_to_early_3rd_century_AD%2C_Gandhara%2C_schist_-_Freer_Gallery_of_Art_-_DSC05124.JPG/440px-thumbnail.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Four_Scenes_from_the_Life_of_the_Buddha_-_Enlightenment_-_Kushan_dynasty,_late_2nd_to_early_3rd_century_AD,_Gandhara,_schist_-_Freer_Gallery_of_Art_-_DSC05124.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Enlightenment of Buddha, Kushan dynasty, late 2nd to early 3rd century CE, Gandhara</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Gautama Buddha</a></div>
<p>Buddhism is an Indian religion<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> or philosophy founded on the teachings of Gautama Buddha, a <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Arama%E1%B9%87a" title="Śramaṇa">Śramaṇa</a> also called Shakyamuni (sage of the Shakya's), or "the Buddha" ("the Awakened One"), who lived c. 5th to 4th century BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin19987–8_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin19987–8-22">[22]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst2013ix–xi_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst2013ix–xi-23">[23]</a></sup> Early texts have the Buddha's family name as "Gautama" (Pali: Gotama). The details of Buddha's life are mentioned in many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_Buddhist_Texts" title="Early Buddhist Texts">Early Buddhist Texts</a> but are inconsistent. His social background and life details are difficult to prove, and the precise dates are uncertain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199813–14_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199813–14-24">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[note 1]</a></sup>
</p><p>The evidence of the early texts suggests that <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Siddhartha_Gautama" title="Siddhartha Gautama">Siddhartha Gautama</a> was born in <a href="/wiki/Lumbini" title="Lumbini">Lumbini</a>, present-day <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a> and grew up in <a href="/wiki/Kapilavastu_(ancient_city)" title="Kapilavastu (ancient city)">Kapilavastu</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[note 2]</a></sup> a town in the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Gangetic_Plain" title="Indo-Gangetic Plain">Ganges Plain</a>, near the modern Nepal–India border, and that he spent his life in what is now modern <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">Bihar</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[note 3]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh" title="Uttar Pradesh">Uttar Pradesh</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198849_34-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198849-34">[32]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199813–14_24-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199813–14-24">[24]</a></sup> Some hagiographic legends state that his father was a king named Suddhodana, his mother was Queen Maya.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Thomas2013p16_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-Thomas2013p16-36">[33]</a></sup> Scholars such as <a href="/wiki/Richard_Gombrich" title="Richard Gombrich">Richard Gombrich</a> consider this a dubious claim because a combination of evidence suggests he was born in the <a href="/wiki/Shakya" title="Shakya">Shakya</a> community, which was governed by a <a href="/wiki/Ga%E1%B9%87asa%E1%B9%85gha" title="Gaṇasaṅgha">small oligarchy or republic-like council</a> where there were no ranks but where seniority mattered instead.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198849–50_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198849–50-37">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[note 4]</a></sup> Some of the stories about Buddha, his life, his teachings, and claims about the society he grew up in may have been invented and interpolated at a later time into the Buddhist texts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198818–19,_50–51_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198818–19,_50–51-41">[37]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to early texts such as the Pali <i>Ariyapariyesanā-sutta</i> ("The discourse on the noble quest", <a href="/wiki/Majjhima_Nik%C4%81ya" title="Majjhima Nikāya">MN</a> 26) and its Chinese parallel at <a href="/wiki/Madhyama_Agama" title="Madhyama Agama">MĀ</a> 204, Gautama was moved by the suffering (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dukkha" title="Dukkha">dukkha</a></i>) of life and death, and its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samsara" title="Samsara">endless repetition</a> due to <a href="/wiki/Rebirth_(Buddhism)" title="Rebirth (Buddhism)">rebirth</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[39]</a></sup> He thus set out on a quest to find liberation from suffering (also known as "<a href="/wiki/Nirvana_(Buddhism)" title="Nirvana (Buddhism)">nirvana</a>").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[40]</a></sup> Early texts and biographies state that Gautama first studied under two teachers of meditation, namely <a href="/wiki/%C4%80%E1%B8%B7%C4%81ra_K%C4%81l%C4%81ma" title="Āḷāra Kālāma">Āḷāra Kālāma</a> (Sanskrit: Arada Kalama) and <a href="/wiki/Uddaka_R%C4%81maputta" title="Uddaka Rāmaputta">Uddaka Ramaputta</a> (Sanskrit: Udraka Ramaputra), learning meditation and philosophy, particularly the meditative attainment of "the sphere of nothingness" from the former, and "the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception" from the latter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWynne20078–23_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWynne20078–23-45">[41]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[42]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[note 5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Finding these teachings to be insufficient to attain his goal, he turned to the practice of severe <a href="/wiki/Asceticism" title="Asceticism">asceticism</a>, which included a strict <a href="/wiki/Fasting" title="Fasting">fasting</a> regime and various forms of <a href="/wiki/Pranayama" title="Pranayama">breath control</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Analayo_2011_p._236_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-Analayo_2011_p._236-50">[45]</a></sup> This too fell short of attaining his goal, and then he turned to the meditative practice of <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dhy%C4%81na_in_Buddhism" title="Dhyāna in Buddhism">dhyana</a></i>. He famously sat in <a href="/wiki/Meditation" title="Meditation">meditation</a> under a <i><a href="/wiki/Ficus_religiosa" title="Ficus religiosa">Ficus religiosa</a></i> tree — now called the <a href="/wiki/Bodhi_Tree" title="Bodhi Tree">Bodhi Tree</a> — in the town of <a href="/wiki/Bodh_Gaya" title="Bodh Gaya">Bodh Gaya</a> and attained "Awakening" (<a href="/wiki/Enlightenment_in_Buddhism" title="Enlightenment in Buddhism">Bodhi</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[46]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to various early texts like the <i>Mahāsaccaka-sutta,</i> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Sama%C3%B1%C3%B1aphala_Sutta" title="Samaññaphala Sutta">Samaññaphala Sutta</a>,</i> on awakening, the Buddha gained insight into the workings of karma and his former lives, as well as achieving the ending of the mental defilements (<i><a href="/wiki/Asava" title="Asava">asavas</a></i>), the ending of suffering, and the end of rebirth in <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83s%C4%81ra" title="Saṃsāra">saṃsāra</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Analayo_2011_p._236_50-1"><a href="#cite_note-Analayo_2011_p._236-50">[45]</a></sup> This event also brought certainty about the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Way" title="Middle Way">Middle Way</a> as the right path of spiritual practice to end suffering.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst2011233–237_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst2011233–237-52">[47]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchuhmacherWoener1991143_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchuhmacherWoener1991143-53">[48]</a></sup> As a <a href="/wiki/Buddhahood#Samyaksambuddha" title="Buddhahood">fully enlightened Buddha</a>, he attracted followers and founded a <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sangha_(Buddhism)" title="Sangha (Buddhism)">Sangha</a></i> (monastic order).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198849–51_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198849–51-54">[49]</a></sup> He spent the rest of his life teaching the <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">Dharma</a> he had discovered, and then died, achieving "<a href="/wiki/Parinirvana" title="Parinirvana">final nirvana</a>", at the age of 80 in <a href="/wiki/Kushinagar" title="Kushinagar">Kushinagar</a>, India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown2003267_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown2003267-55">[50]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2010105–106_27-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2010105–106-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p><p>Buddha's teachings were propagated by his followers, which in the last centuries of the 1st millennium BCE became various <a href="/wiki/Schools_of_Buddhism" title="Schools of Buddhism">Buddhist schools of thought</a>, each with its own <a href="/wiki/Tripi%E1%B9%ADaka" title="Tripiṭaka">basket of texts</a> containing different interpretations and authentic teachings of the Buddha;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199854–55_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199854–55-56">[51]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britannicatipitaka_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-britannicatipitaka-58">[53]</a></sup> these over time evolved into many traditions of which the more well known and widespread in the modern era are <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahayana</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vajrayana" title="Vajrayana">Vajrayana</a> Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[54]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin19981–5_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin19981–5-60">[55]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[note 6]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Worldview">Worldview</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_Buddhism" title="Glossary of Buddhism">Glossary of Buddhism</a></div>
<p>The term "Buddhism" is an occidental neologism, commonly (and "rather roughly" according to <a href="/wiki/Donald_S._Lopez_Jr." title="Donald S. Lopez Jr.">Donald S. Lopez Jr.</a>) used as a translation for the <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">Dharma</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Buddha</a>, <i>fójiào</i> in Chinese, <i>bukkyō</i> in Japanese, <i>nang pa sangs rgyas pa'i chos</i> in Tibetan, <i>buddhadharma</i> in Sanskrit, <i>buddhaśāsana</i> in Pali.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[58]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Four_Noble_Truths_.E2.80.93_dukkha_and_its_ending"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Four_Noble_Truths_–_dukkha_and_its_ending">Four Noble Truths – <i>dukkha</i> and its ending</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dukkha" title="Dukkha">Dukkha</a> and <a href="/wiki/Four_Noble_Truths" title="Four Noble Truths">Four Noble Truths</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Astasahasrika_Prajnaparamita_Dharmacakra_Discourse.jpeg"><img alt="color manuscript illustration of Buddha teaching the Four Noble Truths, Nalanda, Bihar, India" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="283" data-file-width="456" decoding="async" height="137" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Astasahasrika_Prajnaparamita_Dharmacakra_Discourse.jpeg/220px-Astasahasrika_Prajnaparamita_Dharmacakra_Discourse.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Astasahasrika_Prajnaparamita_Dharmacakra_Discourse.jpeg/330px-Astasahasrika_Prajnaparamita_Dharmacakra_Discourse.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Astasahasrika_Prajnaparamita_Dharmacakra_Discourse.jpeg/440px-Astasahasrika_Prajnaparamita_Dharmacakra_Discourse.jpeg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Astasahasrika_Prajnaparamita_Dharmacakra_Discourse.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Buddha teaching the Four Noble Truths. <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> manuscript. <a href="/wiki/Nalanda" title="Nalanda">Nalanda</a>, Bihar, India</div></div></div>
<p>The Four Truths express the basic orientation of Buddhism: we <a href="/wiki/Up%C4%81d%C4%81na" title="Upādāna">crave and cling</a> to <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%85kh%C4%81ra#Conditioned_things" title="Saṅkhāra">impermanent states and things</a>, which is <i>dukkha</i>, "incapable of satisfying" and painful.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENyanatiloka198065_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENyanatiloka198065-65">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201330_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201330-66">[60]</a></sup> This keeps us caught in <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83s%C4%81ra_(Buddhism)" title="Saṃsāra (Buddhism)">saṃsāra</a>, the endless cycle of repeated <a href="/wiki/Rebirth_(Buddhism)" title="Rebirth (Buddhism)">rebirth</a>, dukkha and dying again.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Samsara_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-Samsara-72">[note 7]</a></sup>
But there is a way to <a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">liberation</a> from this endless cycle<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarder200045–46_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarder200045–46-73">[66]</a></sup> to the state of <a href="/wiki/Nirvana" title="Nirvana">nirvana</a>, namely following the <a href="/wiki/Noble_Eightfold_Path" title="Noble Eightfold Path">Noble Eightfold Path</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Moksha_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-Moksha-88">[note 8]</a></sup>
</p><p>The truth of <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dukkha" title="Dukkha">dukkha</a></i> is the basic insight that life in this mundane world, with its clinging and craving to <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%85kh%C4%81ra#Conditioned_things" title="Saṅkhāra">impermanent states and things</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENyanatiloka198065_65-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENyanatiloka198065-65">[59]</a></sup> is <i>dukkha</i>, and unsatisfactory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200274–75_67-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200274–75-67">[61]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELopez2009147_79-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELopez2009147-79">[72]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB-DL_Four_Truths_81-2"><a href="#cite_note-EB-DL_Four_Truths-81">[web 1]</a></sup> <i>Dukkha</i> can be translated as "incapable of satisfying",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sumedho-first_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sumedho-first-89">[web 5]</a></sup> "the unsatisfactory nature and the general insecurity of all <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%85kh%C4%81ra#Conditioned_things" title="Saṅkhāra">conditioned phenomena</a>"; or "painful".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENyanatiloka198065_65-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENyanatiloka198065-65">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201330_66-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201330-66">[60]</a></sup> <i>Dukkha</i> is most commonly translated as "suffering", but this is inaccurate, since it refers not to episodic suffering, but to the intrinsically unsatisfactory nature of temporary states and things, including pleasant but temporary experiences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[note 9]</a></sup> We expect happiness from states and things which are impermanent, and therefore cannot attain real happiness.
</p><p>In Buddhism, dukkha is one of the <a href="/wiki/Three_marks_of_existence" title="Three marks of existence">three marks of existence</a>, along with <a href="/wiki/Impermanence" title="Impermanence">impermanence</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anatt%C4%81" title="Anattā">anattā</a> (non-self).<sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich2005a47,_Quote:_"All_phenomenal_existence_[in_Buddhism]_is_said_to_have_three_interlocking_characteristics:_impermanence,_suffering_and_lack_of_soul_or_essence."_92-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich2005a47,_Quote:_"All_phenomenal_existence_[in_Buddhism]_is_said_to_have_three_interlocking_characteristics:_impermanence,_suffering_and_lack_of_soul_or_essence."-92'>[78]</a></sup> Buddhism, like other major Indian religions, asserts that everything is impermanent (anicca), but, unlike them, also asserts that there is no permanent self or soul in living beings (<i>anattā</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britannicaanatta_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-britannicaanatta-93">[79]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[80]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5sourcesanatta_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-5sourcesanatta-95">[81]</a></sup> The ignorance or misperception (<i><a href="/wiki/Avidy%C4%81_(Buddhism)" title="Avidyā (Buddhism)">avijjā</a></i>) that anything is permanent or that there is self in any being is considered a wrong understanding, and the primary source of clinging and dukkha.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[82]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GombrichScherrer2008p209_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-GombrichScherrer2008p209-97">[83]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HoffmanMahinda2013p162_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-HoffmanMahinda2013p162-98">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p><i>Dukkha</i> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samudaya_sacca" title="Samudaya sacca">arises</a> when we crave (Pali: <i><a href="/wiki/Ta%E1%B9%87h%C4%81" title="Taṇhā">taṇhā</a></i>) and cling to these changing phenomena. The clinging and craving produces <a href="/wiki/Karma_in_Buddhism" title="Karma in Buddhism">karma</a>, which ties us to samsara, the cycle of death and rebirth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERahula2014791–809_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERahula2014791–809-99">[85]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[web 6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[note 10]</a></sup> Craving includes <i>kama-tanha</i>, craving for sense-pleasures; <i><a href="/wiki/Bhava" title="Bhava">bhava</a>-tanha</i>, craving to continue the cycle of life and death, including rebirth; and <i>vibhava-tanha</i>, craving to not experience the world and painful feelings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERahula2014791–809_99-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERahula2014791–809-99">[85]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199870_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199870-102">[86]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAjahn_Sucitto2010Kindle_loc._943–946_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAjahn_Sucitto2010Kindle_loc._943–946-103">[87]</a></sup>
</p><p><i>Dukkha</i> ceases, or can be confined,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrazier2001_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrazier2001-104">[88]</a></sup> when craving and clinging cease or are confined. This also means that no more karma is being produced, and rebirth ends.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nirodha_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nirodha-106">[note 11]</a></sup> Cessation is <i><a href="/wiki/Nirvana_(Buddhism)" title="Nirvana (Buddhism)">nirvana</a></i>, "blowing out", and peace of mind.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERahula2014904–923_107-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERahula2014904–923-107">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199875_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199875-108">[91]</a></sup>
</p><p>By following the Buddhist path to <i><a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">moksha</a></i>, liberation,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2008136_75-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2008136-75">[68]</a></sup> one starts to disengage from craving and clinging to impermanent states and things. The term "path" is usually taken to mean the <a href="/wiki/Noble_Eightfold_Path" title="Noble Eightfold Path">Noble Eightfold Path</a>, but <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhist_Paths_to_liberation" title="Buddhist Paths to liberation">other versions</a> of "the path" can also be found in the Nikayas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBucknell1984_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBucknell1984-109">[92]</a></sup> The Theravada tradition regards insight into the four truths as liberating in itself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarter19873179_83-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarter19873179-83">[74]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="The_cycle_of_rebirth">The cycle of rebirth</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wheel_of_Existence.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="889" decoding="async" height="297" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Wheel_of_Existence.jpg/220px-Wheel_of_Existence.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Wheel_of_Existence.jpg/330px-Wheel_of_Existence.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Wheel_of_Existence.jpg/440px-Wheel_of_Existence.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Wheel_of_Existence.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Traditional <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism" title="Tibetan Buddhism">Tibetan Buddhist</a> <a href="/wiki/Thangka" title="Thangka">Thangka</a> depicting the <a href="/wiki/Bhavacakra" title="Bhavacakra">Wheel of Life</a> with its six realms</div></div></div>
<h4><span id="Sa.E1.B9.83s.C4.81ra"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Saṃsāra">Saṃsāra</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83s%C4%81ra_(Buddhism)" title="Saṃsāra (Buddhism)">Saṃsāra (Buddhism)</a></div>
<p><i>Saṃsāra</i> means "wandering" or "world", with the connotation of cyclic, circuitous change.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier2010604_110-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier2010604-110">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJuergensmeyerRoof2011271–272_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJuergensmeyerRoof2011271–272-111">[94]</a></sup> It refers to the theory of rebirth and "cyclicality of all life, matter, existence", a fundamental assumption of Buddhism, as with all major Indian religions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJuergensmeyerRoof2011271–272_111-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJuergensmeyerRoof2011271–272-111">[94]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200458,_Quote:_"Buddhism_shares_with_Hinduism_the_doctrine_of_Samsara,_whereby_all_beings_pass_through_an_unceasing_cycle_of_birth,_death_and_rebirth_until_they_find_a_means_of_liberation_from_the_cycle._However,_Buddhism_differs_from_Hinduism_in_rejecting_the_assertion_that_every_human_being_possesses_a_changeless_soul_which_constitutes_his_or_her_ultimate_identity,_and_which_transmigrates_from_one_incarnation_to_the_next._112-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200458,_Quote:_"Buddhism_shares_with_Hinduism_the_doctrine_of_Samsara,_whereby_all_beings_pass_through_an_unceasing_cycle_of_birth,_death_and_rebirth_until_they_find_a_means_of_liberation_from_the_cycle._However,_Buddhism_differs_from_Hinduism_in_rejecting_the_assertion_that_every_human_being_possesses_a_changeless_soul_which_constitutes_his_or_her_ultimate_identity,_and_which_transmigrates_from_one_incarnation_to_the_next.-112'>[95]</a></sup> Samsara in Buddhism is considered to be <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dukkha" title="Dukkha">dukkha</a></i>, unsatisfactory and painful,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilson2010_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilson2010-113">[96]</a></sup> perpetuated by desire and <i><a href="/wiki/Avidy%C4%81_(Buddhism)" title="Avidyā (Buddhism)">avidya</a></i> (ignorance), and the resulting <a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">karma</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJuergensmeyerRoof2011271–272_111-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJuergensmeyerRoof2011271–272-111">[94]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcClelland2010172,_240_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcClelland2010172,_240-114">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliamsTribeWynne201218–19,_chapter_1_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliamsTribeWynne201218–19,_chapter_1-115">[98]</a></sup> Liberation from this cycle of existence, <i>nirvana</i>, has been the foundation and the most important historical justification of Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConze201371,_Quote:_&quot;Nirvana_is_the_''raison_d'être''_of_Buddhism,_and_its_ultimate_justification.&quot;_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConze201371,_Quote:_&quot;Nirvana_is_the_''raison_d'être''_of_Buddhism,_and_its_ultimate_justification.&quot;-116">[99]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin1998119_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin1998119-117">[100]</a></sup>
</p><p>Buddhist texts assert that rebirth can occur in six realms of existence, namely three good realms (heavenly, demi-god, human) and three evil realms (animal, hungry ghosts, hellish).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-realms2_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-realms2-119">[note 12]</a></sup> Samsara ends if a person attains <a href="/wiki/Nirvana" title="Nirvana">nirvana</a>, the "blowing out" of the afflictions through insight into <a href="/wiki/Impermanence" title="Impermanence">impermanence</a> and "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anatta" title="Anatta">non-self</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellGimello19927–8,_83–84_120-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellGimello19927–8,_83–84-120">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChoong199928–29,_Quote:_&quot;Seeing_(''passati'')_the_nature_of_things_as_impermanent_leads_to_the_removal_of_the_view_of_self,_and_so_to_the_realisation_of_nirvana.&quot;_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChoong199928–29,_Quote:_&quot;Seeing_(''passati'')_the_nature_of_things_as_impermanent_leads_to_the_removal_of_the_view_of_self,_and_so_to_the_realisation_of_nirvana.&quot;-121">[103]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERahula201451–58_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERahula201451–58-122">[104]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Rebirth">Rebirth</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Rebirth_(Buddhism)" title="Rebirth (Buddhism)">Rebirth (Buddhism)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kushinara1.jpg"><img alt="A very large hill behind two palm trees and a boulevard, where the Buddha is believed to have been cremated" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1563" data-file-width="2500" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Kushinara1.jpg/220px-Kushinara1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Kushinara1.jpg/330px-Kushinara1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Kushinara1.jpg/440px-Kushinara1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kushinara1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ramabhar Stupa in <a href="/wiki/Kushinagar" title="Kushinagar">Kushinagar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh" title="Uttar Pradesh">Uttar Pradesh</a>, India, is regionally believed to be Buddha's cremation site.</div></div></div>
<p>Rebirth refers to a process whereby beings go through a succession of lifetimes as one of many possible forms of <a href="/wiki/Sentient_beings_(Buddhism)" title="Sentient beings (Buddhism)">sentient life</a>, each running from conception to death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown1996107_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown1996107-123">[105]</a></sup> In Buddhist thought, this rebirth does not involve a <a href="/wiki/Soul" title="Soul">soul</a> or any fixed substance. This is because the Buddhist doctrine of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anatta" title="Anatta">anattā</a> (Sanskrit: <i>anātman</i>, no-self doctrine) rejects the concepts of a permanent self or an unchanging, eternal soul found in other religions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Leaman2002p23_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-Leaman2002p23-124">[106]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[107]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Buddhist traditions have traditionally disagreed on what it is in a person that is reborn, as well as how quickly the rebirth occurs after death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709-126">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Neufeldt1986p123_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-Neufeldt1986p123-127">[109]</a></sup> Some Buddhist traditions assert that "no self" doctrine means that there is no enduring self, but there is <i>avacya</i> (inexpressible) personality (<i><a href="/wiki/Pudgalavada" title="Pudgalavada">pudgala</a></i>) which migrates from one life to another.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709_126-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709-126">[108]</a></sup>
</p><p>The majority of Buddhist traditions, in contrast, assert that <a href="/wiki/Vij%C3%B1%C4%81na" title="Vijñāna">vijñāna</a> (a person's consciousness) though evolving, exists as a continuum and is the mechanistic basis of what undergoes the rebirth process.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200274–75_67-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200274–75-67">[61]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709_126-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709-126">[108]</a></sup> The quality of one's rebirth depends on the <a href="/wiki/Merit_(Buddhism)" title="Merit (Buddhism)">merit</a> or demerit gained by one's karma (i.e. actions), as well as that accrued on one's behalf by a family member.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[note 13]</a></sup> Buddhism also developed <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_cosmology" title="Buddhist cosmology">a complex cosmology</a> to explain the various realms or planes of rebirth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilson2010_113-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilson2010-113">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>Each individual rebirth takes place within one of five realms according to theravadins, or six according to other schools – heavenly, demi-gods, humans, animals, hungry ghosts and hellish.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey199834_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey199834-130">[111]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004711_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004711-131">[112]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[note 14]</a></sup>
</p><p>In East Asian and <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism" title="Tibetan Buddhism">Tibetan Buddhism</a>, rebirth is not instantaneous, and there is an intermediate state (Tibetan "<a href="/wiki/Bardo" title="Bardo">bardo</a>") between one life and the next.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez200349–50,_708–709_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez200349–50,_708–709-144">[122]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[123]</a></sup> The orthodox Theravada position rejects the intermediate state, and asserts that rebirth of a being is immediate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez200349–50,_708–709_144-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez200349–50,_708–709-144">[122]</a></sup> However there are passages in the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samyutta_Nikaya" title="Samyutta Nikaya">Samyutta Nikaya</a></i> of the Pali Canon that seem to lend support to the idea that the Buddha taught about an intermediate stage between one life and the next.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004377_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004377-146">[124]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBodhi2000[[Category:Wikipedia_articles_needing_page_number_citations_from_March_2015]]&lt;sup_class="noprint_Inline-Template_"_style="white-space:nowrap;"&gt;&amp;#91;&lt;i&gt;[[Wikipedia:Citing_sources|&lt;span_title="This_citation_requires_a_reference_to_the_specific_page_or_range_of_pages_in_which_the_material_appears.&amp;#32;(March_2015)"&gt;page&amp;nbsp;needed&lt;/span&gt;]]&lt;/i&gt;&amp;#93;&lt;/sup&gt;_147-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBodhi2000[[Category:Wikipedia_articles_needing_page_number_citations_from_March_2015]]&lt;sup_class="noprint_Inline-Template_"_style="white-space:nowrap;"&gt;&amp;#91;&lt;i&gt;[[Wikipedia:Citing_sources|&lt;span_title="This_citation_requires_a_reference_to_the_specific_page_or_range_of_pages_in_which_the_material_appears.&amp;#32;(March_2015)"&gt;page&amp;nbsp;needed&lt;/span&gt;]]&lt;/i&gt;&amp;#93;&lt;/sup&gt;-147'>[125]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Karma">Karma</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Karma_in_Buddhism" title="Karma in Buddhism">Karma in Buddhism</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Karma_in_Buddhism" title="Karma in Buddhism">In Buddhism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">karma</a> (from <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>: "action, work") drives <i><a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83s%C4%81ra" title="Saṃsāra">saṃsāra</a></i> – the endless cycle of suffering and rebirth for each being. Good, skilful deeds (Pāli: <i>kusala</i>) and bad, unskilful deeds (Pāli: <i>akusala</i>) produce "seeds" in the unconscious receptacle (<i>ālaya</i>) that mature later either in this life or in a subsequent <a href="/wiki/Rebirth_(Buddhism)" title="Rebirth (Buddhism)">rebirth</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013131,_32–34_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013131,_32–34-148">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKasulis20061–12_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKasulis20061–12-149">[127]</a></sup> The existence of karma is a core belief in Buddhism, as with all major Indian religions, and it implies neither fatalism nor that everything that happens to a person is caused by karma.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41-150">[128]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[note 15]</a></sup>
</p><p>A central aspect of Buddhist theory of karma is that intent (<i><a href="/wiki/Cetan%C4%81" title="Cetanā">cetanā</a></i>) matters and is essential to bring about a consequence or <i><a href="/wiki/Phala" title="Phala">phala</a></i> "fruit" or <a href="/wiki/Vip%C4%81ka" title="Vipāka">vipāka</a> "result".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKrishan199759–78_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKrishan199759–78-152">[129]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[note 16]</a></sup> However, good or bad karma accumulates even if there is no physical action, and just having ill or good thoughts creates karmic seeds; thus, actions of body, speech or mind all lead to karmic seeds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41_150-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41-150">[128]</a></sup> In the Buddhist traditions, life aspects affected by the law of karma in past and current births of a being include the form of rebirth, realm of rebirth, social class, character and major circumstances of a lifetime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41_150-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41-150">[128]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpiro1982430_with_footnote_1_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpiro1982430_with_footnote_1-157">[133]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[134]</a></sup> It operates like the laws of physics, without external intervention, on every being in all <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samsara_(Buddhism)" title="Samsara (Buddhism)">six realms</a> of existence including human beings and gods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41_150-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41-150">[128]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELopez2001239–248_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELopez2001239–248-159">[135]</a></sup>
</p><p>A notable aspect of the karma theory in Buddhism is merit transfer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-appletonp129_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-appletonp129-160">[136]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpiro1982124–128_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpiro1982124–128-161">[137]</a></sup> A person accumulates merit not only through intentions and ethical living, but also is able to gain merit from others by exchanging goods and services, such as through <i>dāna</i> (charity to monks or nuns).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201345–46_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201345–46-162">[138]</a></sup> Further, a person can transfer one's own good karma to living family members and ancestors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpiro1982124–128_161-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpiro1982124–128-161">[137]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[note 17]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Liberation">Liberation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">Moksha</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nirvana_(Buddhism)" title="Nirvana (Buddhism)">Nirvana (Buddhism)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:050_Mucilinda_with_his_Wives_around_the_Buddha_(32999346203).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3957" data-file-width="3922" decoding="async" height="222" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/050_Mucilinda_with_his_Wives_around_the_Buddha_%2832999346203%29.jpg/220px-050_Mucilinda_with_his_Wives_around_the_Buddha_%2832999346203%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/050_Mucilinda_with_his_Wives_around_the_Buddha_%2832999346203%29.jpg/330px-050_Mucilinda_with_his_Wives_around_the_Buddha_%2832999346203%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/050_Mucilinda_with_his_Wives_around_the_Buddha_%2832999346203%29.jpg/440px-050_Mucilinda_with_his_Wives_around_the_Buddha_%2832999346203%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:050_Mucilinda_with_his_Wives_around_the_Buddha_(32999346203).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An <a href="/wiki/Aniconism" title="Aniconism">aniconic</a> depiction of the Buddha's spiritual liberation (<i>moksha</i>) or awakening (<i>bodhi</i>), at <a href="/wiki/Sanchi" title="Sanchi">Sanchi</a>. The Buddha is not depicted, only symbolized by the Bodhi tree and the empty seat</div></div></div>
<p>The cessation of the <i><a href="/wiki/Kleshas_(Buddhism)" title="Kleshas (Buddhism)">kleshas</a></i> and the attainment of <a href="/wiki/Nirvana" title="Nirvana">nirvana</a> (<i>nibbāna</i>), with which the cycle of rebirth ends, has been the primary and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soteriological" title="Soteriological">soteriological</a> goal of the Buddhist path for monastic life since the time of the Buddha.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2008136_75-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2008136-75">[68]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003589–590_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003589–590-166">[141]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECollins1998135–177,_188,_443_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollins1998135–177,_188,_443-167">[142]</a></sup> The term "path" is usually taken to mean the <a href="/wiki/Noble_Eightfold_Path" title="Noble Eightfold Path">Noble Eightfold Path</a>, but <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhist_Paths_to_liberation" title="Buddhist Paths to liberation">other versions</a> of "the path" can also be found in the Nikayas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[note 18]</a></sup> In some passages in the Pali Canon, a distinction is being made between right knowledge or insight (<i>sammā-ñāṇa</i>), and right liberation or release (<i>sammā-vimutti</i>), as the means to attain cessation and liberation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChoong2000141_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChoong2000141-169">[143]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFuller200555–56_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFuller200555–56-170">[144]</a></sup>
</p><p>Nirvana literally means "blowing out, quenching, becoming extinguished".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Collins2010p63_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-Collins2010p63-171">[145]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECousins19969_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECousins19969-172">[146]</a></sup> In early Buddhist texts, it is the state of restraint and self-control that leads to the "blowing out" and the ending of the cycles of sufferings associated with rebirths and redeaths.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988-173">[147]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich199766_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich199766-174">[148]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[149]</a></sup> Many later Buddhist texts describe nirvana as identical with <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anatta" title="Anatta">anatta</a></i> with complete "emptiness, nothingness".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[150]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[151]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[152]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[note 19]</a></sup> In some texts, the state is described with greater detail, such as passing through the gate of emptiness (<i>sunyata</i>) – realising that there is no soul or self in any living being, then passing through the gate of signlessness (<i>animitta</i>) – realising that nirvana cannot be perceived, and finally passing through the gate of wishlessness (<i>apranihita</i>) – realising that nirvana is the state of not even wishing for nirvana.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003589–590_166-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003589–590-166">[141]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[154]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[note 20]</a></sup>
</p><p>The nirvana state has been described in Buddhist texts partly in a manner similar to other Indian religions, as the state of complete liberation, enlightenment, highest happiness, bliss, fearlessness, freedom, permanence, non-dependent origination, unfathomable, and indescribable.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECollins1998191–233_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollins1998191–233-184">[156]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[157]</a></sup> It has also been described in part differently, as a state of spiritual release marked by "emptiness" and realisation of <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anatta" title="Anatta">non-self</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[158]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[159]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[160]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[note 21]</a></sup>
</p><p>While Buddhism considers the liberation from <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83s%C4%81ra_(Buddhism)" title="Saṃsāra (Buddhism)">saṃsāra</a> as the ultimate spiritual goal, in traditional practice, the primary focus of a vast majority of lay Buddhists has been to seek and accumulate merit through good deeds, donations to monks and various Buddhist rituals in order to gain better rebirths rather than nirvana.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECoogan2003192_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECoogan2003192-192">[163]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200462_138-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200462-138">[117]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[note 22]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dependent_arising">Dependent arising</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Prat%C4%ABtyasamutp%C4%81da" title="Pratītyasamutpāda">Pratītyasamutpāda</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Twelve_Nid%C4%81nas" title="Twelve Nidānas">Twelve Nidānas</a></div>
<p><i>Pratityasamutpada</i>, also called "dependent arising, or dependent origination", is the Buddhist theory to explain the nature and relations of being, becoming, existence and ultimate reality. Buddhism asserts that there is nothing independent, except the state of nirvana.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey199854_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey199854-194">[164]</a></sup> All physical and mental states depend on and arise from other pre-existing states, and in turn from them arise other dependent states while they cease.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[165]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 'dependent arisings' have a causal conditioning, and thus <i>Pratityasamutpada</i> is the Buddhist belief that causality is the basis of <a href="/wiki/Ontology" title="Ontology">ontology</a>, not a creator God nor the ontological Vedic concept called universal Self (<a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">Brahman</a>) nor any other 'transcendent creative principle'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200264,_Quote:_In_the_''Mahatanhasankhaya_Sutta''_the_Buddha_[stresses]_that_things_originate_in_dependence_upon_causal_conditioning,_and_this_emphasis_on_causality_describes_the_central_feature_of_Buddhist_ontology._All_elements_of_samsara_exist_in_some_sense_or_another_relative_to_their_causes_and_conditions._196-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200264,_Quote:_In_the_''Mahatanhasankhaya_Sutta''_the_Buddha_[stresses]_that_things_originate_in_dependence_upon_causal_conditioning,_and_this_emphasis_on_causality_describes_the_central_feature_of_Buddhist_ontology._All_elements_of_samsara_exist_in_some_sense_or_another_relative_to_their_causes_and_conditions.-196">[166]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[167]</a></sup> However, Buddhist thought does not understand causality in terms of Newtonian mechanics; rather it understands it as conditioned arising.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin1998153–155_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin1998153–155-198">[168]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[169]</a></sup> In Buddhism, dependent arising refers to conditions created by a plurality of causes that necessarily co-originate a phenomenon within and across lifetimes, such as karma in one life creating conditions that lead to rebirth in one of the realms of existence for another lifetime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kalupahana1975p54_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kalupahana1975p54-200">[170]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[171]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin1998151–152_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin1998151–152-202">[172]</a></sup>
</p><p>Buddhism applies the theory of dependent arising to explain origination of endless cycles of <i>dukkha</i> and rebirth, through <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Twelve_Nid%C4%81nas" title="Twelve Nidānas">Twelve Nidānas</a> or "twelve links". It states that because <a href="/wiki/Avidy%C4%81_(Buddhism)" title="Avidyā (Buddhism)">Avidyā</a> (ignorance) exists, <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%85kh%C4%81ra" title="Saṅkhāra">Saṃskāras</a> (karmic formations) exist; because Saṃskāras exist therefore <a href="/wiki/Vij%C3%B1%C4%81na" title="Vijñāna">Vijñāna</a> (consciousness) exists; and in a similar manner it links <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/N%C4%81mar%C5%ABpa" title="Nāmarūpa">Nāmarūpa</a> (the sentient body), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%E1%B9%A2a%E1%B8%8D%C4%81yatana" title="Ṣaḍāyatana">Ṣaḍāyatana</a> (our six senses), <a href="/wiki/Spar%C5%9Ba" title="Sparśa">Sparśa</a> (sensory stimulation), <a href="/wiki/Vedan%C4%81" title="Vedanā">Vedanā</a> (feeling), <a href="/wiki/Ta%E1%B9%87h%C4%81" title="Taṇhā">Taṇhā</a> (craving), <a href="/wiki/Up%C4%81d%C4%81na" title="Upādāna">Upādāna</a> (grasping), <a href="/wiki/Bhava" title="Bhava">Bhava</a> (becoming), <a href="/wiki/J%C4%81ti_(Buddhism)" title="Jāti (Buddhism)">Jāti</a> (birth), and <a href="/wiki/Jar%C4%81mara%E1%B9%87a" title="Jarāmaraṇa">Jarāmaraṇa</a> (old age, death, sorrow, and pain).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201365–72_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201365–72-203">[173]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201351–66_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201351–66-204">[174]</a></sup> By breaking the circuitous links of the Twelve Nidanas, Buddhism asserts that liberation from these endless cycles of rebirth and dukkha can be attained.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey199854,_Quote:_&quot;The_main_concrete_application_of_the_abstract_principle_is_in_the_form_of_a_series_of_conditioned_links_(''nidanas''),_culminating_in_the_arising_of_dukkha.&quot;_(...)_&quot;This_[doctrine]_states_the_principle_of_conditionality,_that_all_things,_mental_and_physical,_arise_and_exist_due_to_the_presence_of_certain_conditions,_and_cease_once_their_conditions_are_removed:_nothing_(except_''Nibbana'')_is_independent._The_doctrine_thus_complements_the_teaching_that_no_permanent,_independent_self_can_be_found.&quot;_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey199854,_Quote:_&quot;The_main_concrete_application_of_the_abstract_principle_is_in_the_form_of_a_series_of_conditioned_links_(''nidanas''),_culminating_in_the_arising_of_dukkha.&quot;_(...)_&quot;This_[doctrine]_states_the_principle_of_conditionality,_that_all_things,_mental_and_physical,_arise_and_exist_due_to_the_presence_of_certain_conditions,_and_cease_once_their_conditions_are_removed:_nothing_(except_''Nibbana'')_is_independent._The_doctrine_thus_complements_the_teaching_that_no_permanent,_independent_self_can_be_found.&quot;-205">[175]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Not-Self_and_Emptiness">Not-Self and Emptiness</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/An%C4%81tman" title="Anātman">Anātman</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C5%9A%C5%ABnyat%C4%81" title="Śūnyatā">Śūnyatā</a></div>
<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="float:right; clear: right; margin:0.1em 0 0.1em 1em; background:Azure; border:1px solid DarkGray; font-size:85%; text-align:center;">
<tbody><tr>
<td colspan="5" style="border-bottom:1px solid DarkGray; background:WhiteSmoke; text-align:center; color:RoyalBlue"> <span style="font-size:small;">The <b><a href="/wiki/Skandha" title="Skandha">Five Aggregates</a></b> (<i>pañca khandha</i>)</span><br/>according to the <a href="/wiki/Pali_Canon" title="Pali Canon">Pali Canon</a>.</td>
</tr><tr>
<td colspan="5"> </td></tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="1"> </td>
<td>
<table cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0">
<tbody><tr>

<td rowspan="8" style="border-left:1px dotted Red; border-top:1px dotted Red; border-bottom:1px dotted Red"> </td>
<td style="color:RoyalBlue; border-top:1px dotted Red"><small><a href="/wiki/Mental_factors_(Buddhism)" title="Mental factors (Buddhism)">mental factors (<i>cetasika</i>)</a></small></td>

</tr>

</tr>
<tr><td> </td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="background:OrangeRed"> <br/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samjna" title="Samjna"><b>perception</b><br/>(<i>sañña</i>)</a><br/> </td>
</tr>
<tr><td> </td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="background:Red"> <br/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sankhara" title="Sankhara"><b>formation</b><br/>(<i><span title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration"><i lang="sa-Latn">saṅkhāra</i></span></i>)</a><br/> </td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="3" style="border-bottom:1px dotted Red"> </td>
</tr></tbody></table>
</td>
<td rowspan="1"> </td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="5"> </td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="5" style="border-top:1px solid DarkGray; background:Ivory; text-align:left; color:RoyalBlue">
<dl><dd><ul><li><a href="/wiki/R%C5%ABpa" title="Rūpa">Form</a> is derived from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mahabhuta" title="Mahabhuta">Four Great Elements</a>.</li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vinnana" title="Vinnana">Consciousness</a> arises from <a href="/wiki/Namarupa" title="Namarupa">other aggregates</a>.</li>
<li>Mental Factors arise from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Phassa" title="Phassa">Contact</a> of<br/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vinnana" title="Vinnana">Consciousness</a> and <a href="/wiki/Namarupa" title="Namarupa">other aggregates</a>.</li></ul></dd></dl></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="5" style="background:WhiteSmoke; text-align:left; color:RoyalBlue">
 <small><a class="external text" href="http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/mn/mn.109.than.html" rel="nofollow">Source: MN 109 (Thanissaro, 2001)</a></small>  <span style="color:DarkGray;">|</span>  <small><a href="/wiki/Template:PancaKhandha" title="Template:PancaKhandha">diagram details</a></small></td></tr>
</tbody></table>
<p>A related doctrine in Buddhism is that of <i>anattā</i> (Pali) or <i>anātman</i> (Sanskrit). It is the view that there is no unchanging, permanent self, soul or essence in phenomena.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich200647_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich200647-206">[176]</a></sup> The Buddha and Buddhist philosophers who follow him such as Vasubandhu and Buddhaghosa, generally argue for this view by analyzing the person through the schema of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Five_aggregates" title="Five aggregates">five aggregates</a>, and then attempting to show that none of these five components of personality can be permanent or absolute.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[177]</a></sup> This can be seen in Buddhist discourses such as the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anattalakkhana_Sutta" title="Anattalakkhana Sutta">Anattalakkhana Sutta</a></i>.
</p><p>"Emptiness" or "voidness" (Skt<i>: Śūnyatā</i>, Pali: <i>Suññatā)</i>, is a related concept with many different interpretations throughout the various Buddhisms.
