In early Buddhism, it was commonly stated that all five aggregates are void (<i>rittaka</i>), hollow (<i>tucchaka</i>), coreless (<i>asāraka</i>), for example as in the <i>Pheṇapiṇḍūpama Sutta</i> (SN 22:95).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[178]</a></sup> Similarly, in Theravada Buddhism, it often simply means that the five aggregates are empty of a Self.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[179]</a></sup>
</p><p>Emptiness is a central concept in Mahāyāna Buddhism, especially in <a href="/wiki/Nagarjuna" title="Nagarjuna">Nagarjuna</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Madhyamaka" title="Madhyamaka">Madhyamaka</a> school, and in the <i><a href="/wiki/Prajnaparamita" title="Prajnaparamita">Prajñāpāramitā</a> sutras</i>. In Madhyamaka philosophy, emptiness is the view which holds that all phenomena (<a href="/wiki/Dharma#Dharmas_in_Buddhist_phenomenology" title="Dharma"><i>dharmas</i></a>) are without any <i><a href="/wiki/Svabhava" title="Svabhava">svabhava</a></i> (literally "own-nature" or "self-nature"), and are thus without any underlying essence, and so are "empty" of being independent. This doctrine sought to refute the heterodox theories of <i>svabhava</i> circulating at the time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELindtner1997324_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELindtner1997324-210">[180]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Three_Jewels">The Three Jewels</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Three_Jewels" title="Three Jewels">Three Jewels</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sanchi_Stupa_number_2_KSP_3667_Wheel_and_Triratna.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1680" data-file-width="1050" decoding="async" height="288" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Sanchi_Stupa_number_2_KSP_3667_Wheel_and_Triratna.jpg/180px-Sanchi_Stupa_number_2_KSP_3667_Wheel_and_Triratna.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Sanchi_Stupa_number_2_KSP_3667_Wheel_and_Triratna.jpg/270px-Sanchi_Stupa_number_2_KSP_3667_Wheel_and_Triratna.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Sanchi_Stupa_number_2_KSP_3667_Wheel_and_Triratna.jpg/360px-Sanchi_Stupa_number_2_KSP_3667_Wheel_and_Triratna.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sanchi_Stupa_number_2_KSP_3667_Wheel_and_Triratna.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Dharmachakra" title="Dharmachakra">Dharma Wheel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Triratna" title="Triratna">triratna</a> symbols from <a href="/wiki/Sanchi" title="Sanchi">Sanchi</a> Stupa number 2</div></div></div>
<p>All forms of Buddhism revere and take spiritual refuge in the "three jewels" (<i>triratna</i>): Buddha, Dharma and Sangha.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013244–245_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013244–245-211">[181]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Buddha">Buddha</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Buddhahood" title="Buddhahood">Buddhahood</a></div>
<p>While all varieties of Buddhism revere "Buddha" and "buddhahood", they have different views on what these are. Whatever that may be, "Buddha" is still central to all forms of Buddhism.
</p><p>In Theravada Buddhism, a Buddha is someone who has become awake through their own efforts and insight. They have put an end to their cycle of rebirths and have ended all unwholesome mental states which lead to bad action and thus are morally perfected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Crosby,_Kate_2013_p._16_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-Crosby,_Kate_2013_p._16-212">[182]</a></sup> While subject to the limitations of the human body in certain ways (for example, in the early texts, the Buddha suffers from backaches), a Buddha is said to be "deep, immeasurable, hard-to-fathom as is the great ocean," and also has immense psychic powers (<a href="/wiki/Abhij%C3%B1%C4%81" title="Abhijñā">abhijñā</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201327–28_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201327–28-213">[183]</a></sup>
</p><p>Theravada generally sees Gautama Buddha (the historical Buddha Sakyamuni) as the only Buddha of the current era. While he is no longer in this world, he has left us the Dharma (Teaching), the Vinaya (Discipline) and the Sangha (Community).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[184]</a></sup> There are also said to be two types of Buddhas, a <i>sammasambuddha </i>is also said to teach the Dharma to others, while a <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paccekabuddha" title="Paccekabuddha">paccekabuddha</a></i> (solitary buddha) does not teach.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Crosby,_Kate_2013_p._16_212-1"><a href="#cite_note-Crosby,_Kate_2013_p._16-212">[182]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mahāyāna Buddhism meanwhile, has a vastly expanded <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_cosmology" title="Buddhist cosmology">cosmology</a>, with various <a href="/wiki/Buddhahood" title="Buddhahood">Buddhas</a> and other holy beings (<i>aryas</i>) residing in different realms. Mahāyāna texts not only revere numerous <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_deities#Buddhas" title="Buddhist deities">Buddhas</a> besides <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Sakyamuni</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Amit%C4%81bha" title="Amitābha">Amitabha</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vairochana" title="Vairochana">Vairocana</a>, but also see them as transcendental or supramundane (<i>lokuttara</i>) beings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200821_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200821-215">[185]</a></sup> Mahāyāna Buddhism holds that these other Buddhas in other realms can be contacted and are able to benefit beings in this world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013162_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013162-216">[186]</a></sup> In Mahāyāna, a Buddha is a kind of "spiritual king", a "protector of all creatures" with a lifetime that is countless of eons long, rather than just a human teacher who has transcended the world after death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200827_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200827-217">[187]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Buddha Sakyamuni</a>'s life and death on earth is then usually understood as a "mere appearance" or "a manifestation skilfully projected into earthly life by a long-enlightened transcendent being, who is still available to teach the faithful through visionary experiences."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200827_217-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200827-217">[187]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013164_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013164-218">[188]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Dharma">Dharma</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">Dharma</a></div>
<p>"Dharma" (Pali: Dhamma) in Buddhism refers to the Buddha's teaching, which includes all of the main ideas outlined above. While this teaching reflects the true nature of reality, it is not a belief to be clung to, but a pragmatic teaching to be put into practice. It is likened to a raft which is "for crossing over" (to nirvana) not for holding on to.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201331_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201331-219">[189]</a></sup>
</p><p>It also refers to the universal law and cosmic order which that teaching both reveals and relies upon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[190]</a></sup> It is an everlasting principle which applies to all beings and worlds. In that sense it is also the ultimate truth and reality about the universe, it is thus "the way that things really are."
</p><p>The Dharma is the second of the three jewels which all Buddhists take refuge in. All Buddhas in all worlds, in the past, present and in the future, are believed by Buddhists to understand and teach the Dharma. Indeed, it is part of what makes them a Buddha that they do so.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Sangha">Sangha</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Sangha" title="Sangha">Sangha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bodhisattva" title="Bodhisattva">Bodhisattva</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Arhat" title="Arhat">Arhat</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Praying_monks_and_nuns_in_the_Buddha_Tooth_Relic_Temple_of_Singapore.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3360" data-file-width="5579" decoding="async" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Praying_monks_and_nuns_in_the_Buddha_Tooth_Relic_Temple_of_Singapore.jpg/220px-Praying_monks_and_nuns_in_the_Buddha_Tooth_Relic_Temple_of_Singapore.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Praying_monks_and_nuns_in_the_Buddha_Tooth_Relic_Temple_of_Singapore.jpg/330px-Praying_monks_and_nuns_in_the_Buddha_Tooth_Relic_Temple_of_Singapore.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Praying_monks_and_nuns_in_the_Buddha_Tooth_Relic_Temple_of_Singapore.jpg/440px-Praying_monks_and_nuns_in_the_Buddha_Tooth_Relic_Temple_of_Singapore.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Praying_monks_and_nuns_in_the_Buddha_Tooth_Relic_Temple_of_Singapore.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Buddhist monks and nuns praying in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddha_Tooth_Relic_Temple" title="Buddha Tooth Relic Temple">Buddha Tooth Relic Temple</a> of Singapore</div></div></div>
<p>The third "jewel" which Buddhists take refuge in is the "Sangha", which refers to the monastic community of monks and nuns who follow Gautama Buddha's monastic discipline which was "designed to shape the Sangha as an ideal community, with the optimum conditions for spiritual growth."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201388_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201388-221">[191]</a></sup> The Sangha consists of those who have chosen to follow the Buddha's ideal way of life, which is one of celibate monastic renunciation with minimal material possessions (such as an alms bowl and robes).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199885–88_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199885–88-222">[192]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Sangha is seen as important because they preserve and pass down Buddha Dharma. As Gethin states "the Sangha lives the teaching, preserves the teaching as Scriptures and teaches the wider community. Without the Sangha there is no Buddhism."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199892_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199892-223">[193]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Sangha also acts as a "field of merit" for laypersons, allowing them to make spiritual merit or goodness by donating to the Sangha and supporting them. In return, they keep their duty to preserve and spread the Dharma everywhere for the good of the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199886_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199886-224">[194]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Sangha is also supposed to follow the Vinaya (monastic rule) of the Buddha, thereby serving as an spiritual example for the world and future generations. The Vinaya rules also force the Sangha to live in dependence on the rest of the lay community (they must beg for food etc.) and thus draw the Sangha into a relationship with the lay community.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199893_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199893-225">[195]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ascetic_Sumedha_and_Dipankara_Buddha.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="678" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="117" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Ascetic_Sumedha_and_Dipankara_Buddha.jpg/220px-Ascetic_Sumedha_and_Dipankara_Buddha.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Ascetic_Sumedha_and_Dipankara_Buddha.jpg/330px-Ascetic_Sumedha_and_Dipankara_Buddha.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Ascetic_Sumedha_and_Dipankara_Buddha.jpg/440px-Ascetic_Sumedha_and_Dipankara_Buddha.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ascetic_Sumedha_and_Dipankara_Buddha.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A depiction of Siddhartha Gautama in a previous life prostrating before the past Buddha <a href="/wiki/Dipankara" title="Dipankara">Dipankara</a>. After making a resolve to be a Buddha, and receiving a prediction of future Buddhahood, he becomes a "bodhisattva"</div></div></div>
<p>There is also a separate definition of Sangha, referring to those who have attained any <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Four_stages_of_enlightenment" title="Four stages of enlightenment">stage of awakening</a>, whether or not they are monastics. This sangha is called the <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C4%81vaka#The_community_of_disciples" title="Śrāvaka"><i>āryasaṅgha</i></a> "noble Sangha".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[196]</a></sup> All forms of Buddhism generally reveres these <i><a href="/wiki/Arya_(Buddhism)" title="Arya (Buddhism)">āryas</a></i> (Pali: <i>ariya</i>, "noble ones" or "holy ones") who are spiritually attained beings. Aryas have attained the fruits of the Buddhist path.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[197]</a></sup> Becoming an arya is a goal in most forms of Buddhism. The <i>āryasaṅgha</i> includes holy beings such as <a href="/wiki/Bodhisattva" title="Bodhisattva">bodhisattvas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arhat" title="Arhat">arhats</a> and stream-enterers. 
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bodhisattva_Maitreya_(Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4314" data-file-width="1866" decoding="async" height="393" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Bodhisattva_Maitreya_%28Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art%29.jpg/170px-Bodhisattva_Maitreya_%28Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Bodhisattva_Maitreya_%28Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art%29.jpg/255px-Bodhisattva_Maitreya_%28Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Bodhisattva_Maitreya_%28Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art%29.jpg/340px-Bodhisattva_Maitreya_%28Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bodhisattva_Maitreya_(Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Bodhisattva Maitreya, <a href="/wiki/Gandhara" title="Gandhara">Gandhara</a> (3rd century), Metropolitan Museum of Art</div></div></div>
<p>In early Buddhism and in Theravada Buddhism, an arhat (literally meaning "worthy") is someone who reached the same awakening (<i>bodhi</i>) of a Buddha by following the teaching of a Buddha.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[198]</a></sup> They are seen as having ended rebirth and all the mental defilements. A bodhisattva ("a being bound for awakening") meanwhile, is simply a name for someone who is working towards awakening (<i>bodhi</i>) as a Buddha. According to all the early buddhist schools as well as Theravada, to be considered a bodhisattva one has to have made a vow in front of a living Buddha and also has to have received a confirmation of one's future Buddhahood.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Drewes,_David_2017_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-Drewes,_David_2017-229">[199]</a></sup> In Theravada, the future Buddha is called Metteyya (Maitreya) and he is revered as a bodhisattva currently working for future Buddhahood.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Drewes,_David_2017_229-1"><a href="#cite_note-Drewes,_David_2017-229">[199]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mahāyāna Buddhism generally sees the attainment of the arhat as an inferior one, since it is seen as being done only for the sake of individual liberation. It thus promotes the bodhisattva path as the highest and most worthwhile.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200860_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200860-230">[200]</a></sup> While in Mahāyāna, anyone who has given rise to <a href="/wiki/Bodhicitta" title="Bodhicitta">bodhicitta</a> (the wish to become a Buddha that arises from a sense of compassion for all beings) is considered a bodhisattva,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams2008195–196_231-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams2008195–196-231">[201]</a></sup> some of these holy beings (such as <a href="/wiki/Maitreya" title="Maitreya">Maitreya</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Avalokiteshvara" title="Avalokiteshvara">Avalokiteshvara</a>) have reached very high levels of spiritual attainment and are seen as being very powerful supramundane beings who provide aid to countless beings through their advanced powers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013175–176_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013175–176-232">[202]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Other_key_Mah.C4.81y.C4.81na_views"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_key_Mahāyāna_views">Other key Mahāyāna views</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Yogachara" title="Yogachara">Yogachara</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buddha-nature" title="Buddha-nature">Buddha-nature</a></div>
<p>Mahāyāna Buddhism also differs from Theravada and the other schools of early Buddhism in promoting several unique doctrines which are contained in Mahāyāna sutras and philosophical treatises.
</p><p>One of these is the unique interpretation of emptiness and dependent origination found in the Madhyamaka school. Another very influential doctrine for Mahāyāna is the main philosophical view of the <a href="/wiki/Yogachara" title="Yogachara">Yogācāra</a> school variously, termed <i>Vijñaptimātratā-vāda</i> ("the doctrine that there are only ideas" or "mental impressions") or <i>Vijñānavāda</i> ("the doctrine of consciousness"). According to Mark Siderits, what classical Yogācāra thinkers like Vasubandhu had in mind is that we are only ever aware of mental images or impressions, which may appear as external objects, but "there is actually no such thing outside the mind."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[203]</a></sup> There are several interpretations of this main theory, many scholars see it as a type of Idealism, others as a kind of phenomenology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[204]</a></sup>
</p><p>Another very influential concept unique to Mahāyāna is that of "Buddha-nature" (<i>buddhadhātu</i>) or "Tathagata-womb" (<i>tathāgatagarbha</i>). Buddha-nature is a concept found in some 1st-millennium CE Buddhist texts, such as the <i><a href="/wiki/Tath%C4%81gatagarbha_s%C5%ABtras" title="Tathāgatagarbha sūtras">Tathāgatagarbha sūtras</a></i>. According to Paul Williams these <a href="/wiki/Sutra" title="Sutra">Sutras</a> suggest that 'all sentient beings contain a Tathagata' as their 'essence, core inner nature, Self'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams2008104_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams2008104-235">[205]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[note 23]</a></sup> According to Karl Brunnholzl "the earliest mahayana sutras that are based on and discuss the notion of tathāgatagarbha as the buddha potential that is innate in all sentient beings began to appear in written form in the late second and early third century."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[207]</a></sup> For some, the doctrine seems to conflict with the Buddhist anatta doctrine (non-Self), leading scholars to posit that the <i>Tathāgatagarbha Sutras</i> were written to promote Buddhism to non-Buddhists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams2008104–105,_108–109,_Quote:_&quot;..._[The_''Mahaparinirvana_Sutra'']_refers_to_the_Buddha_using_the_term_&quot;Self&quot;_in_order_to_win_over_non-Buddhist_ascetics.&quot;_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams2008104–105,_108–109,_Quote:_&quot;..._[The_''Mahaparinirvana_Sutra'']_refers_to_the_Buddha_using_the_term_&quot;Self&quot;_in_order_to_win_over_non-Buddhist_ascetics.&quot;-239">[208]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[209]</a></sup> This can be seen in texts like the <i><a href="/wiki/La%E1%B9%85k%C4%81vat%C4%81ra_S%C5%ABtra" title="Laṅkāvatāra Sūtra">Laṅkāvatāra Sūtra</a></i>, which state that Buddha-nature is taught to help those who have fear when they listen to the teaching of anatta.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[210]</a></sup> Buddhist texts like the <i><a href="/wiki/Ratnagotravibh%C4%81ga" title="Ratnagotravibhāga">Ratnagotravibhāga</a></i> clarify that the "Self" implied in <i>Tathagatagarbha</i> doctrine is actually "<a href="/wiki/Anatt%C4%81" title="Anattā">not-self</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams2008112_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams2008112-242">[211]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHookham199196_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHookham199196-243">[212]</a></sup> Various interpretations of the concept have been advanced by Buddhist thinkers throughout the history of Buddhist thought and most attempt to avoid anything like the <a href="/wiki/%C4%80tman_(Hinduism)" title="Ātman (Hinduism)">Hindu Atman</a> doctrine.
</p><p>These Indian Buddhist ideas, in various synthetic ways, form the basis of subsequent Mahāyāna philosophy in Tibetan Buddhism and East Asian Buddhism.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Paths_to_liberation">Paths to liberation</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_paths_to_liberation" title="Buddhist paths to liberation">Buddhist paths to liberation</a></div>
<p>While the Noble Eightfold Path is best-known in the West, a wide variety of paths and models of progress have been used and described in the different Buddhist traditions. However, they generally share basic practices such as <i>sila</i> (ethics), <i>samadhi</i> (meditation, <i>dhyana</i>) and <i>prajña</i> (wisdom), which are known as the three trainings. An important additional practice is a kind and compassionate attitude toward every living being and the world. <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_devotion" title="Buddhist devotion">Devotion</a> is also important in some Buddhist traditions, and in the Tibetan traditions visualisations of deities and mandalas are important. The value of textual study is regarded differently in the various Buddhist traditions. It is central to Theravada and highly important to Tibetan Buddhism, while the Zen tradition takes an ambiguous stance.
</p><p>An important guiding principle of Buddhist practice is the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Way" title="Middle Way">Middle Way</a> (<i>madhyamapratipad</i>). It was a part of Buddha's first sermon, where he presented the <a href="/wiki/Noble_Eightfold_Path" title="Noble Eightfold Path">Noble Eightfold Path</a> that was a 'middle way' between the extremes of asceticism and hedonistic sense pleasures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201323,_81_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201323,_81-244">[213]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown199624,_59_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown199624,_59-245">[214]</a></sup> In Buddhism, states Harvey, the doctrine of "dependent arising" (conditioned arising, <i>pratītyasamutpāda</i>) to explain rebirth is viewed as the 'middle way' between the doctrines that a being has a "permanent soul" involved in rebirth (eternalism) and "death is final and there is no rebirth" (annihilationism).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201372_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201372-246">[215]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez200349,_''antagrahadrsti''_247-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez200349,_''antagrahadrsti''-247">[216]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Paths_to_liberation_in_the_early_texts">Paths to liberation in the early texts</span></h3>
<p>A common presentation style of the path (<i>mārga</i>) to liberation in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_Buddhist_Texts" title="Early Buddhist Texts">Early Buddhist Texts</a> is the "graduated talk", in which the Buddha lays out a step by step training.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[217]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the early texts, numerous different sequences of the gradual path can be found.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_249-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-249">[218]</a></sup> One of the most important and widely used presentations among the various Buddhist schools is The <a href="/wiki/Noble_Eightfold_Path" title="Noble Eightfold Path">Noble Eightfold Path</a>, or "Eightfold Path of the Noble Ones" (Skt. <i>'āryāṣṭāṅgamārga'</i>). This can be found in various discourses, most famously in the <i><a href="/wiki/Dhammacakkappavattana_Sutta" title="Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta">Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta</a></i> (The discourse on the turning of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dharma_Wheel" title="Dharma Wheel">Dharma wheel</a>).
</p><p>Other suttas such as the <i>Tevijja Sutta</i>, and the <i>Cula-Hatthipadopama-sutta</i> give a different outline of the path, though with many similar elements such as ethics and meditation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_249-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-249">[218]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Rupert Gethin, the path to awakening is also frequently summarized by another a short formula: "abandoning the hindrances, practice of the four establishings of mindfulness, and development of the awakening factors."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin2001xiii–xiv_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin2001xiii–xiv-250">[219]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Noble_Eightfold_Path">Noble Eightfold Path</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Noble_Eightfold_Path" title="Noble Eightfold Path">Noble Eightfold Path</a></div>
<p>The Eightfold Path consists of a set of eight interconnected factors or conditions, that when developed together, lead to the cessation of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dukkha" title="Dukkha">dukkha</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAjahn_Sucitto201087–88_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAjahn_Sucitto201087–88-251">[220]</a></sup> These eight factors are: Right View (or Right Understanding), Right Intention (or Right Thought), Right Speech, Right Action, Right Livelihood, Right Effort, Right Mindfulness, and Right Concentration.
</p><p>This Eightfold Path is the fourth of the <a href="/wiki/Four_Noble_Truths" title="Four Noble Truths">Four Noble Truths</a>, and asserts the path to the cessation of <i>dukkha</i> (suffering, pain, unsatisfactoriness).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199881–83_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199881–83-252">[221]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnderson201364–65_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnderson201364–65-253">[222]</a></sup> The path teaches that the way of the enlightened ones stopped their craving, clinging and <a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">karmic</a> accumulations, and thus ended their endless cycles of rebirth and suffering.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2016253–255_254-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2016253–255-254">[223]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBodhi20101–13_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBodhi20101–13-255">[224]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliamsTribeWynne201252_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliamsTribeWynne201252-256">[225]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Noble Eightfold Path is grouped into <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Three_disciplines_of_Buddhism" title="Three disciplines of Buddhism">three basic divisions</a>, as follows:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13-257">[226]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–85_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–85-258">[227]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBodhi201047–48_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBodhi201047–48-259">[228]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Division
</th>
<th>Eightfold factor
</th>
<th><i>Sanskrit, Pali</i>
</th>
<th>Description
</th></tr>
<tr style="background:#cff;">
<td rowspan="2">Wisdom<br/>(Sanskrit: <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wisdom_in_Buddhism" title="Wisdom in Buddhism">prajñā</a></i>,<br/>Pāli: <i>paññā</i>)
</td>
<td>1. Right view
</td>
<td><i>samyag dṛṣṭi,<br/>sammā ditthi</i>
</td>
<td>The belief that there is an afterlife and not everything ends with death, that Buddha taught and followed a successful path to nirvana;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13_257-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13-257">[226]</a></sup> according to Peter Harvey, the right view is held in Buddhism as a belief in the Buddhist principles of <a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">karma</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rebirth_(Buddhism)" title="Rebirth (Buddhism)">rebirth</a>, and the importance of the <a href="/wiki/Four_Noble_Truths" title="Four Noble Truths">Four Noble Truths</a> and the True Realities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–84_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–84-260">[229]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#cff;">
<td>2. Right intention
</td>
<td><i>samyag saṃkalpa,<br/>sammā saṅkappa</i>
</td>
<td>Giving up home and adopting the life of a religious mendicant in order to follow the path;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13_257-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13-257">[226]</a></sup> this concept, states Harvey, aims at peaceful renunciation, into an environment of non-sensuality, non-ill-will (to lovingkindness), away from cruelty (to compassion).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–84_260-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–84-260">[229]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#cfc;">
<td rowspan="3">Moral virtues<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–85_258-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–85-258">[227]</a></sup><br/>(Sanskrit: <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C5%9A%C4%ABla" title="Śīla">śīla</a></i>,<br/>Pāli: <i>sīla</i>)
</td>
<td>3. Right speech
</td>
<td><i>samyag vāc,<br/>sammā vāca</i>
</td>
<td>No lying, no rude speech, no telling one person what another says about him, speaking that which leads to salvation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13_257-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13-257">[226]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#cfc;">
<td>4. Right action
</td>
<td><i>samyag karman,<br/>sammā kammanta</i>
</td>
<td>No killing or injuring, no taking what is not given; no sexual acts in monastic pursuit,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13_257-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13-257">[226]</a></sup> for lay Buddhists no sensual misconduct such as sexual involvement with someone married, or with an unmarried woman protected by her parents or relatives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGowans2013440_261-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGowans2013440-261">[230]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[231]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[232]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#cfc;">
<td>5. Right livelihood
</td>
<td><i>samyag ājīvana,<br/>sammā ājīva</i>
</td>
<td>For monks, beg to feed, only possessing what is essential to sustain life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter198812_264-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter198812-264">[233]</a></sup> For lay Buddhists, the canonical texts state right livelihood as abstaining from wrong livelihood, explained as not becoming a source or means of suffering to sentient beings by cheating them, or harming or killing them in any way.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383,_273–274_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383,_273–274-265">[234]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[235]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#9fff80;">
<td rowspan="3">Meditation<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–85_258-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–85-258">[227]</a></sup><br/>(Sanskrit and Pāli: <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sam%C4%81dhi" title="Samādhi">samādhi</a></i>)
</td>
<td>6. Right effort
</td>
<td><i>samyag vyāyāma,<br/>sammā vāyāma</i>
</td>
<td>Guard against sensual thoughts; this concept, states Harvey, aims at preventing unwholesome states that disrupt meditation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383_267-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383-267">[236]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#9fff80;">
<td>7. Right mindfulness
</td>
<td><i>samyag smṛti,<br/>sammā sati</i>
</td>
<td>Never be absent-minded, conscious of what one is doing; this, states Harvey, encourages mindfulness about impermanence of the body, feelings and mind, as well as to experience the five <a href="/wiki/Skandha" title="Skandha">skandhas</a>, the five hindrances, the four True Realities and seven factors of awakening.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383_267-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383-267">[236]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#9fff80;">
<td>8. Right concentration
</td>
<td><i>samyag samādhi,<br/>sammā samādhi</i>
</td>
<td>Correct meditation or concentration (<i>dhyana</i>), explained as the four jhānas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13_257-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13-257">[226]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bucknellkangp12_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-bucknellkangp12-268">[237]</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Theravada_presentations_of_the_path">Theravada presentations of the path</span></h3>
<p>Theravada Buddhism is a diverse tradition and thus includes different explanations of the path to awakening. However, the teachings of the Buddha are often encapsulated by Theravadins in the basic framework of the Four Noble Truths and the Eighthfold Path.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[238]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[239]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some Theravada Buddhists also follow the presentation of the path laid out in <a href="/wiki/Buddhaghosa" title="Buddhaghosa">Buddhaghosa's</a> <a href="/wiki/Visuddhimagga" title="Visuddhimagga">Visuddhimagga</a>. This presentation is known as the "Seven Purifications" (<i>satta-visuddhi</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[240]</a></sup> This schema and its accompanying outline of "insight knowledges" (<i><a href="/wiki/Vipassan%C4%81-%C3%B1%C4%81%E1%B9%87a" title="Vipassanā-ñāṇa">vipassanā-ñāṇa</a></i>) is used by modern influential Theravadin scholars, such <a href="/wiki/Mahasi_Sayadaw" title="Mahasi Sayadaw">Mahasi Sayadaw</a> (in his "The Progress of Insight") and <a href="/wiki/Nyanatiloka" title="Nyanatiloka">Nyanatiloka Thera</a> (in "The Buddha's Path to Deliverance").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[241]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[242]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mahayana_presentations_of_the_path">Mahayana presentations of the path</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahāyāna</a> Buddhism is based principally upon the path of a <a href="/wiki/Bodhisattva" title="Bodhisattva">Bodhisattva</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENattier2003137–138,_142–146_274-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENattier2003137–138,_142–146-274">[243]</a></sup> A <i>Bodhisattva</i> refers to one who is on the path to buddhahood.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGyatso19951_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGyatso19951-275">[244]</a></sup> The term <i>Mahāyāna</i> was originally a synonym for <i>Bodhisattvayāna</i> or "Bodhisattva Vehicle".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENattier2003174_276-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENattier2003174-276">[245]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993297_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993297-277">[246]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConze20012001_278-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConze20012001-278">[247]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the earliest texts of Mahāyāna Buddhism, the path of a bodhisattva was to awaken the <i>bodhicitta</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson199799_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson199799-279">[248]</a></sup> Between the 1st and 3rd century CE, this tradition introduced the <i>Ten Bhumi</i> doctrine, which means ten levels or stages of awakening.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson199799_279-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson199799-279">[248]</a></sup> This development was followed by the acceptance that it is impossible to achieve Buddhahood in one (current) lifetime, and the best goal is not nirvana for oneself, but Buddhahood after climbing through the ten levels during multiple rebirths.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENattier2003142–152_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENattier2003142–152-280">[249]</a></sup> Mahāyāna scholars then outlined an elaborate path, for monks and laypeople, and the path includes the vow to help teach Buddhist knowledge to other beings, so as to help them cross samsara and liberate themselves, once one reaches the Buddhahood in a future rebirth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENattier2003137–138,_142–146_274-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENattier2003137–138,_142–146-274">[243]</a></sup> One part of this path are the <i><a href="/wiki/P%C4%81ramit%C4%81" title="Pāramitā">pāramitā</a></i> (perfections, to cross over), derived from the <i>Jatakas</i> tales of Buddha's numerous rebirths.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson1997101–102_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson1997101–102-281">[250]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004631–632_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004631–632-282">[251]</a></sup>
</p><p>The doctrine of the bodhisattva bhūmis was also eventually merged with the <a href="/wiki/Vaibh%C4%81%E1%B9%A3ika" title="Vaibhāṣika">Sarvāstivāda Vaibhāṣika</a> schema of the "five paths" by the <a href="/wiki/Yogachara" title="Yogachara">Yogacara</a> school<i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:02_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-:02-283">[252]</a></sup></i> This Mahāyāna "five paths" presentation can be seen in <a href="/wiki/Asanga" title="Asanga">Asanga's</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81y%C4%81nasa%E1%B9%83graha" title="Mahāyānasaṃgraha">Mahāyānasaṃgraha</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:02_283-1"><a href="#cite_note-:02-283">[252]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Mahāyāna texts are inconsistent in their discussion of the <i>pāramitās</i>, and some texts include lists of two, others four, six, ten and fifty-two.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENattier2003151–154_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENattier2003151–154-284">[253]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown2003212_285-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown2003212-285">[254]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ichimura2001p28_286-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ichimura2001p28-286">[255]</a></sup> The six paramitas have been most studied, and these are:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson1997101–102_281-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson1997101–102-281">[250]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ichimura2001p28_286-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ichimura2001p28-286">[255]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGyatso19954–12_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGyatso19954–12-287">[256]</a></sup>
</p>
<ol><li><i><a href="/wiki/D%C4%81na" title="Dāna">Dāna</a> pāramitā</i>: perfection of giving; primarily to monks, nuns and the Buddhist monastic establishment dependent on the alms and gifts of the lay householders, in return for generating religious merit;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004196_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004196-288">[257]</a></sup> some texts recommend ritually transferring the merit so accumulated for better rebirth to someone else</li>
<li><i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C5%9A%C4%ABla" title="Śīla">Śīla</a> pāramitā</i>: perfection of morality; it outlines ethical behaviour for both the laity and the Mahayana monastic community; this list is similar to Śīla in the Eightfold Path (i.e. Right Speech, Right Action, Right Livelihood)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MizunoSekimori1996p28_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-MizunoSekimori1996p28-289">[258]</a></sup></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Kshanti" title="Kshanti"><span title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration"><i lang="sa-Latn">Kṣānti</i></span></a> pāramitā</i>: perfection of patience, willingness to endure hardship</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/V%C4%ABrya" title="Vīrya">Vīrya</a> pāramitā</i>: perfection of vigour; this is similar to Right Effort in the Eightfold Path<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MizunoSekimori1996p28_289-1"><a href="#cite_note-MizunoSekimori1996p28-289">[258]</a></sup></li>
<li><i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dhy%C4%81na_in_Buddhism" title="Dhyāna in Buddhism">Dhyāna</a> pāramitā</i>: perfection of meditation; this is similar to Right Concentration in the Eightfold Path</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Praj%C3%B1%C4%81_(Buddhism)" title="Prajñā (Buddhism)">Prajñā</a> pāramitā</i>: perfection of insight (wisdom), awakening to the characteristics of existence such as karma, rebirths, impermanence, no-self, dependent origination and emptiness;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ichimura2001p28_286-2"><a href="#cite_note-Ichimura2001p28-286">[255]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004631–632,_664–665,_809_290-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004631–632,_664–665,_809-290">[259]</a></sup> this is complete acceptance of the Buddha teaching, then conviction, followed by ultimate realisation that "dharmas are non-arising".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson1997101–102_281-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson1997101–102-281">[250]</a></sup></li></ol>
<p>In Mahāyāna Sutras that include ten <i>pāramitā</i>, the additional four perfections are "skillful means, vow, power and knowledge".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown2003212_285-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown2003212-285">[254]</a></sup> The most discussed <i>pāramitā</i> and the highest rated perfection in Mahayana texts is the "Prajna-paramita", or the "perfection of insight".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown2003212_285-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown2003212-285">[254]</a></sup> This insight in the Mahāyāna tradition, states Shōhei Ichimura, has been the "insight of non-duality or the absence of reality in all things".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[260]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[261]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="East_Asian_Buddhism">East Asian Buddhism</span></h4>
<p><a href="/wiki/East_Asian_Buddhism" title="East Asian Buddhism">East Asian Buddhism</a> in influenced by both the classic Indian Buddhist presentations of the path such as the eighth-fold path as well as classic Indian Mahāyāna presentations such as that found in the <a href="/wiki/Da_zhidu_lun" title="Da zhidu lun">Da zhidu lun</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[262]</a></sup>
</p><p>There many different presentations of <a href="/wiki/Soteriology" title="Soteriology">soteriology</a>, including numerous paths and vehicles (<i>yanas</i>) in the different traditions of East Asian Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[263]</a></sup> There is no single dominant presentation. In <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zen_Buddhism" title="Zen Buddhism">Zen Buddhism</a> for example, one can find outlines of the path such as the <a href="/wiki/Long_Scroll_of_the_Treatise_on_the_Two_Entrances_and_Four_Practices" title="Long Scroll of the Treatise on the Two Entrances and Four Practices">Two Entrances and Four Practices</a><i>,</i> The <a href="/wiki/Five_Ranks" title="Five Ranks">Five ranks</a>, The <a href="/wiki/Ten_Bulls" title="Ten Bulls">Ten Ox-Herding Pictures</a> and <a href="/wiki/Linji_Yixuan#Expressing_the_inexpressible" title="Linji Yixuan">The Three mysterious Gates</a> of Linji.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Indo-Tibetan_Buddhism">Indo-Tibetan Buddhism</span></h4>
<p>In Indo-Tibetan Buddhism, the path to liberation is outlined in the genre known as <a href="/wiki/Lamrim" title="Lamrim">Lamrim</a> ("Stages of the Path"). All the various Tibetan schools have their own Lamrim presentations. This genre can be traced to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atisha" title="Atisha">Atiśa</a>'s 11th-century <i><a href="/wiki/Bodhipathaprad%C4%ABpa" title="Bodhipathapradīpa">A Lamp for the Path to Enlightenment</a></i> (<i>Bodhipathapradīpa</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thubten_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-thubten-295">[264]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Common_Buddhist_practices">Common Buddhist practices</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sermon_in_the_Deer_Park_depicted_at_Wat_Chedi_Liem-KayEss-1.jpeg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="640" data-file-width="475" decoding="async" height="296" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Sermon_in_the_Deer_Park_depicted_at_Wat_Chedi_Liem-KayEss-1.jpeg/220px-Sermon_in_the_Deer_Park_depicted_at_Wat_Chedi_Liem-KayEss-1.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Sermon_in_the_Deer_Park_depicted_at_Wat_Chedi_Liem-KayEss-1.jpeg/330px-Sermon_in_the_Deer_Park_depicted_at_Wat_Chedi_Liem-KayEss-1.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Sermon_in_the_Deer_Park_depicted_at_Wat_Chedi_Liem-KayEss-1.jpeg/440px-Sermon_in_the_Deer_Park_depicted_at_Wat_Chedi_Liem-KayEss-1.jpeg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sermon_in_the_Deer_Park_depicted_at_Wat_Chedi_Liem-KayEss-1.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Sermon in the <a href="/wiki/Sarnath" title="Sarnath">Deer Park</a> depicted at <a href="/wiki/Wat_Chedi_Liam" title="Wat Chedi Liam">Wat Chedi Liam</a>, near <a href="/wiki/Chiang_Mai" title="Chiang Mai">Chiang Mai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Northern_Thailand" title="Northern Thailand">Northern Thailand</a></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hearing_and_learning_the_Dharma">Hearing and learning the Dharma</span></h3>
<p>In various suttas which present the graduated path taught by the Buddha, such as the <i><a href="/wiki/Sama%C3%B1%C3%B1aphala_Sutta" title="Samaññaphala Sutta">Samaññaphala Sutta</a></i> and the <i>Cula-Hatthipadopama Sutta,</i> the first step on the path is hearing the Buddha teach the Dharma.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_249-2"><a href="#cite_note-:0-249">[218]</a></sup> This then said to lead to the acquiring of confidence or faith in the Buddha's teachings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_249-3"><a href="#cite_note-:0-249">[218]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mahayana Buddhist teachers such as <a href="/wiki/Yin_Shun" title="Yin Shun">Yin Shun</a> also state that hearing the Dharma and study of the Buddhist discourses is necessary "if one wants to learn and practice the Buddha Dharma."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[265]</a></sup> Likewise, in Indo-Tibetan Buddhism, the "Stages of the Path" (<i>Lamrim</i>) texts generally place the activity of listening to the Buddhist teachings as an important early practice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[266]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Refuge">Refuge</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Refuge_(Buddhism)" title="Refuge (Buddhism)">Refuge (Buddhism)</a></div>
<p>Traditionally, the first step in most Buddhist schools requires taking of the "Three Refuges", also called the Three Jewels (<a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>: <i>triratna</i>, <a href="/wiki/Pali" title="Pali">Pali</a>: <i>tiratana</i>) as the foundation of one's religious practice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013249_298-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013249-298">[267]</a></sup> This practice may have been influenced by the <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Brahmanical</a> motif of the triple refuge, found in the <i><a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a></i> 9.97.47, <i>Rigveda</i> 6.46.9 and <i><a href="/wiki/Chandogya_Upanishad" title="Chandogya Upanishad">Chandogya Upanishad</a></i> 2.22.3–4.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShults2014108_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShults2014108-299">[268]</a></sup> Tibetan Buddhism sometimes adds a fourth refuge, in the <i><a href="/wiki/Lama" title="Lama">lama</a></i>. The three refuges are believed by Buddhists to be protective and a form of reverence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013249_298-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013249-298">[267]</a></sup>
</p><p>The ancient formula which is repeated for taking refuge affirms that "I go to the Buddha as refuge, I go to the Dhamma as refuge, I go to the Sangha as refuge."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013244_300-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013244-300">[269]</a></sup> Reciting the three refuges, according to Harvey, is considered not as a place to hide, rather a thought that "purifies, uplifts and strengthens the heart".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013244–245_211-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013244–245-211">[181]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id=".C5.9A.C4.ABla_.E2.80.93_Buddhist_ethics"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Śīla_–_Buddhist_ethics"><i>Śīla</i> – Buddhist ethics</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_ethics" title="Buddhist ethics">Buddhist ethics</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Buddhist_alms_in_Si_Phan_Don.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3977" data-file-width="5966" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Buddhist_alms_in_Si_Phan_Don.jpg/220px-Buddhist_alms_in_Si_Phan_Don.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Buddhist_alms_in_Si_Phan_Don.jpg/330px-Buddhist_alms_in_Si_Phan_Don.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Buddhist_alms_in_Si_Phan_Don.jpg/440px-Buddhist_alms_in_Si_Phan_Don.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Buddhist_alms_in_Si_Phan_Don.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Buddhist monks collect alms in Si Phan Don, <a href="/wiki/Laos" title="Laos">Laos</a>. Giving is a key virtue in Buddhism.</div></div></div>
<p><i>Śīla</i> (Sanskrit) or <i>sīla</i> (Pāli) is the concept of "moral virtues", that is the second group and an integral part of the Noble Eightfold Path.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–84_260-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–84-260">[229]</a></sup> It generally consists of right speech, right action and right livelihood.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–84_260-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–84-260">[229]</a></sup>
</p><p>One of the most basic forms of ethics in Buddhism is the taking of "precepts". This includes the Five Precepts for laypeople, Eight or Ten Precepts for monastic life, as well as rules of Dhamma (<i>Vinaya</i> or <i>Patimokkha</i>) adopted by a monastery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams2005c398_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams2005c398-301">[270]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001187–193_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001187–193-302">[271]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other important elements of Buddhist ethics include <a href="/wiki/D%C4%81na" title="Dāna">giving or charity</a> (<i>dāna</i>), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mett%C4%81" title="Mettā">Mettā</a> (Good-Will), Heedfulness (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Appamada" title="Appamada">Appamada</a>), ‘self-respect’ (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hri_(Buddhism)" title="Hri (Buddhism)">Hri</a>) and 'regard for consequences' (<a href="/wiki/Apatrapya" title="Apatrapya">Apatrapya</a>).
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Precepts">Precepts</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Five_precepts" title="Five precepts">Five precepts</a></div>
<p>Buddhist scriptures explain the five precepts (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pali_language" title="Pali language">Pali</a>: <i lang="pi">pañcasīla</i>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sanskrit_language" title="Sanskrit language">Sanskrit</a>: <i lang="sa">pañcaśīla</i>) as the minimal standard of Buddhist morality.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGowans2013440_261-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGowans2013440-261">[230]</a></sup> It is the most important system of morality in Buddhism, together with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Patimokkha" title="Patimokkha">monastic rules</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Goodman_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-Goodman-303">[272]</a></sup>
</p><p>The five precepts are seen as a basic training applicable to all Buddhists. They are:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams2005c398_301-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams2005c398-301">[270]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[273]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey200067_305-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey200067-305">[274]</a></sup>
</p>
<ol><li>"I undertake the training-precept (<i>sikkha-padam</i>) to abstain from onslaught on breathing beings." This includes ordering or causing someone else to kill. The Pali suttas also say one should not "approve of others killing" and that one should be "scrupulous, compassionate, trembling for the welfare of all living beings."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey200069_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey200069-306">[275]</a></sup></li>
<li>"I undertake the training-precept to abstain from taking what is not given." According to Harvey, this also covers fraud, cheating, forgery as well as "falsely denying that one is in debt to someone."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey200070_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey200070-307">[276]</a></sup></li>
<li>"I undertake the training-precept to abstain from misconduct concerning sense-pleasures." This generally refers to <a href="/wiki/Adultery" title="Adultery">adultery</a>, as well as rape and incest. It also applies to sex with those who are legally under the protection of a guardian. It is also interpreted in different ways in the varying Buddhist cultures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey200071–74_308-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey200071–74-308">[277]</a></sup></li>
<li>"I undertake the training-precept to abstain from false speech." According to Harvey this includes "any form of lying, deception or exaggeration...even non-verbal deception by gesture or other indication...or misleading statements."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey200075_309-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey200075-309">[278]</a></sup> The precept is often also seen as including other forms of wrong speech such as "divisive speech, harsh, abusive, angry words, and even idle chatter."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey200076_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey200076-310">[279]</a></sup></li>
<li>"I undertake the training-precept to abstain from alcoholic drink or drugs that are an opportunity for heedlessness." According to Harvey, intoxication is seen as a way to mask rather than face the sufferings of life. It is seen as damaging to one's mental clarity, mindfulness and ability to keep the other four precepts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey200077_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey200077-311">[280]</a></sup></li></ol>
<p>Undertaking and upholding the five precepts is based on the principle of <a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">non-harming</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/P%C4%81li" title="Pāli">Pāli</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sanskrit_language" title="Sanskrit language">Sanskrit</a>: <i lang="sa">ahiṃsa</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown2013616_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown2013616-312">[281]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pali_Canon" title="Pali Canon">Pali Canon</a> recommends one to compare oneself with others, and on the basis of that, not to hurt others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey200033,_71_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey200033,_71-313">[282]</a></sup> Compassion and a belief in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Karma_(Buddhism)" title="Karma (Buddhism)">karmic retribution</a> form the foundation of the precepts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERatanakul2007241_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERatanakul2007241-314">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHorigan1996276_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHorigan1996276-315">[284]</a></sup> Undertaking the five precepts is part of regular lay devotional practice, both at home and at the local temple.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETerwiel2012178–179_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETerwiel2012178–179-316">[285]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey200080_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey200080-317">[286]</a></sup> However, the extent to which people keep them differs per region and time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELedgerwood2008152_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELedgerwood2008152-318">[287]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey200080_317-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey200080-317">[286]</a></sup> They are sometimes referred to as the <i><a href="/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C4%81vakay%C4%81na" title="Śrāvakayāna">śrāvakayāna</a> precepts</i> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81y%C4%81na" title="Mahāyāna">Mahāyāna</a> tradition, contrasting them with the <a href="/wiki/Bodhisattva_Precepts" title="Bodhisattva Precepts"><i>bodhisattva</i> precepts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunayama2004105_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunayama2004105-319">[288]</a></sup>
</p><p>The five precepts are not commandments and transgressions do not invite religious sanctions, but their power has been based on the Buddhist belief in karmic consequences and their impact in the afterlife. Killing in Buddhist belief leads to rebirth in the hell realms, and for a longer time in more severe conditions if the murder victim was a monk. Adultery, similarly, invites a rebirth as prostitute or in hell, depending on whether the partner was unmarried or married.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001187_320-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001187-320">[289]</a></sup> These moral precepts have been voluntarily self-enforced in lay Buddhist culture through the associated belief in karma and rebirth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001187–191_321-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001187–191-321">[290]</a></sup> Within the Buddhist doctrine, the precepts are meant to develop mind and character to make progress on the path to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Enlightenment_(Buddhism)" title="Enlightenment (Buddhism)">enlightenment</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGetz2004673_322-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGetz2004673-322">[291]</a></sup>
</p><p>The monastic life in Buddhism has additional precepts as part of <i>patimokkha</i>, and unlike lay people, transgressions by monks do invite sanctions. Full expulsion from <i>sangha</i> follows any instance of killing, engaging in sexual intercourse, theft or false claims about one's knowledge. Temporary expulsion follows a lesser offence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001192_323-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001192-323">[292]</a></sup> The sanctions vary per monastic fraternity (<i>nikaya</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001192–193_324-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001192–193-324">[293]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lay people and novices in many Buddhist fraternities also uphold <a href="/wiki/Eight_precepts" title="Eight precepts">eight (<i>asta shila</i>)</a> or ten (<i>das shila</i>) from time to time. Four of these are same as for the lay devotee: no killing, no stealing, no lying, and no intoxicants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gombrichpreceptsp76_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-gombrichpreceptsp76-325">[294]</a></sup> The other four precepts are:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorganLawton200762–63_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorganLawton200762–63-326">[295]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gombrichpreceptsp76_325-1"><a href="#cite_note-gombrichpreceptsp76-325">[294]</a></sup>
</p>
<ol><li>No sexual activity;</li>
<li>Abstain from eating at the wrong time (e.g. only eat solid food before noon);</li>
<li>Abstain from jewellery, perfume, adornment, entertainment;</li>
<li>Abstain from sleeping on high bed i.e. to sleep on a mat on the ground.</li></ol>
<p>All eight precepts are sometimes observed by lay people on <i><a href="/wiki/Uposatha" title="Uposatha">uposatha</a></i> days: full moon, new moon, the first and last quarter following the lunar calendar.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gombrichpreceptsp76_325-2"><a href="#cite_note-gombrichpreceptsp76-325">[294]</a></sup> The ten precepts also include to abstain from accepting money.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gombrichpreceptsp76_325-3"><a href="#cite_note-gombrichpreceptsp76-325">[294]</a></sup>
</p><p>In addition to these precepts, Buddhist monasteries have hundreds of rules of conduct, which are a part of its <i>patimokkha</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[296]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[note 24]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Vinaya">Vinaya</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Vinaya" title="Vinaya">Vinaya</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Buddhist_Ordination_Ceremony.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Buddhist_Ordination_Ceremony.jpg/220px-Buddhist_Ordination_Ceremony.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Buddhist_Ordination_Ceremony.jpg/330px-Buddhist_Ordination_Ceremony.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Buddhist_Ordination_Ceremony.jpg/440px-Buddhist_Ordination_Ceremony.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Buddhist_Ordination_Ceremony.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An ordination ceremony at Wat Yannawa in Bangkok. The Vinaya codes regulate the various sangha acts, including ordination.</div></div></div>
<p>Vinaya is the specific code of conduct for a <i>sangha</i> of monks or nuns. It includes the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Patimokkha" title="Patimokkha">Patimokkha</a>, a set of 227 offences including 75 rules of decorum for monks, along with penalties for transgression, in the Theravadin tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich1988109_330-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich1988109-330">[298]</a></sup> The precise content of the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vinaya_Pitaka" title="Vinaya Pitaka">Vinaya Pitaka</a></i> (scriptures on the Vinaya) differs in different schools and tradition, and different monasteries set their own standards on its implementation. The list of <i>pattimokkha</i> is recited every fortnight in a ritual gathering of all monks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich1988109_330-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich1988109-330">[298]</a></sup> Buddhist text with vinaya rules for monasteries have been traced in all Buddhist traditions, with the oldest surviving being the ancient Chinese translations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198893_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198893-331">[299]</a></sup>
</p><p>Monastic communities in the Buddhist tradition cut normal social ties to family and community, and live as "islands unto themselves".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198889–92_332-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198889–92-332">[300]</a></sup> Within a monastic fraternity, a <i>sangha</i> has its own rules.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198889–92_332-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198889–92-332">[300]</a></sup> A monk abides by these institutionalised rules, and living life as the vinaya prescribes it is not merely a means, but very nearly the end in itself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198889–92_332-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198889–92-332">[300]</a></sup> Transgressions by a monk on <i>Sangha</i> vinaya rules invites enforcement, which can include temporary or permanent expulsion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich1988101–107_333-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich1988101–107-333">[301]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Restraint_and_renunciation">Restraint and renunciation</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Buddhist_monk_in_Khao_Luang-Sukhothai.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1175" data-file-width="777" decoding="async" height="333" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Buddhist_monk_in_Khao_Luang-Sukhothai.JPG/220px-Buddhist_monk_in_Khao_Luang-Sukhothai.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Buddhist_monk_in_Khao_Luang-Sukhothai.JPG/330px-Buddhist_monk_in_Khao_Luang-Sukhothai.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Buddhist_monk_in_Khao_Luang-Sukhothai.JPG/440px-Buddhist_monk_in_Khao_Luang-Sukhothai.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Buddhist_monk_in_Khao_Luang-Sukhothai.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Living at the root of a tree (<i>trukkhamulik'anga</i>) is one of the <i>dhutaṅgas</i>, a series of optional ascetic practices for Buddhist monastics.</div></div></div>
<p>Another important practice taught by the Buddha is the restraint of the senses (<i>indriyasamvara</i>). In the various graduated paths, this is usually presented as a practice which is taught prior to formal sitting meditation, and which supports meditation by weakening sense desires that are a <a href="/wiki/Five_hindrances" title="Five hindrances">hindrance</a> to meditation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Anālayo_2003_p._71_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-Anālayo_2003_p._71-334">[302]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Bhikkhu_Analayo" title="Bhikkhu Analayo">Anālayo</a>, sense restraint is when one "guards the sense doors in order to prevent sense impressions from leading to desires and discontent."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Anālayo_2003_p._71_334-1"><a href="#cite_note-Anālayo_2003_p._71-334">[302]</a></sup> This is not an avoidance of sense impression, but a kind of mindful attention towards the sense impressions which does not dwell on their main features or signs (<i>nimitta</i>). This is said to prevent harmful influences from entering the mind.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Anālayo_2003_p._225_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-Anālayo_2003_p._225-335">[303]</a></sup> This practice is said to give rise to an inner peace and happiness which forms a basis for concentration and insight.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Anālayo_2003_p._225_335-1"><a href="#cite_note-Anālayo_2003_p._225-335">[303]</a></sup>
</p><p>A related Buddhist virtue and practice is renunciation, or the intent for desirelessness (<i><a href="/wiki/Nekkhamma" title="Nekkhamma">nekkhamma</a></i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[304]</a></sup> Generally, renunciation is the giving up of actions and desires that are seen as unwholesome on the path, such as lust for sensuality and worldly things.<sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTERhys_DavidsStede1921–1925377"Nekkhamma"_337-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTERhys_DavidsStede1921–1925377"Nekkhamma"-337'>[305]</a></sup> Renunciation can be cultivated in different ways. The practice of giving for example, is one form of cultivating renunciation. Another one is the giving up of lay life and becoming a monastic (<i>bhiksu</i> o <i>bhiksuni</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey1998199_338-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey1998199-338">[306]</a></sup> Practicing <a href="/wiki/Celibacy" title="Celibacy">celibacy</a> (whether for life as a monk, or temporarily) is also a form of renunciation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey200089_339-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey200089-339">[307]</a></sup> Many <a href="/wiki/Jataka_tales" title="Jataka tales">Jataka</a> stories such as the focus on how the Buddha practiced renunciation in past lives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel2013492_340-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel2013492-340">[308]</a></sup>
</p><p>One way of cultivating renunciation taught by the Buddha is the contemplation (<i>anupassana</i>) of the "dangers" (or "negative consequences") of sensual pleasure (<i>kāmānaṃ ādīnava</i>). As part of the graduated discourse, this contemplation is taught after the practice of giving and morality.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[309]</a></sup>
</p><p>Another related practice to renunciation and sense restraint taught by the Buddha is "restraint in eating" or moderation with food, which for monks generally means not eating after noon. Devout laypersons also follow this rule during special days of religious observance (<i><a href="/wiki/Uposatha" title="Uposatha">uposatha</a></i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[310]</a></sup> Observing the Uposatha also includes other practices dealing with renunciation, mainly the <a href="/wiki/Eight_precepts" title="Eight precepts">eight precepts</a>.
</p><p>For Buddhist monastics, renunciation can also be trained through several optional ascetic practices called <i><a href="/wiki/Dhutanga" title="Dhutanga">dhutaṅga</a></i>.
</p><p>In different Buddhist traditions, other related <a href="/wiki/Fasting_in_Buddhism" title="Fasting in Buddhism">practices which focus on fasting</a> are followed.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mindfulness_and_clear_comprehension">Mindfulness and clear comprehension</span></h3>
<p>The training of the faculty called <a href="/wiki/Sati_(Buddhism)" title="Sati (Buddhism)">"mindfulness"</a> (Pali: <i>sati</i>, Sanskrit: <i>smṛti,</i> literally meaning "recollection, remembering") is central in Buddhism. According to Analayo, mindfulness is a full awareness of the present moment which enhances and strengthens memory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[311]</a></sup> The Indian Buddhist philosopher <a href="/wiki/Asanga" title="Asanga">Asanga</a> defined mindfulness thus: "It is non-forgetting by the mind with regard to the object experienced. Its function is non-distraction."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boin-Webb,_Sara_2001_p._9_344-0"><a href="#cite_note-Boin-Webb,_Sara_2001_p._9-344">[312]</a></sup> According to Rupert Gethin, <i>sati</i> is also "an awareness of things in relation to things, and hence an awareness of their relative value."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[313]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are different practices and exercises for training mindfulness in the early discourses, such as the four <i><a href="/wiki/Satipatthana" title="Satipatthana">Satipaṭṭhānas</a></i> (Sanskrit: <i>smṛtyupasthāna</i>, "establishments of mindfulness") and <i><a href="/wiki/Anapanasati" title="Anapanasati">Ānāpānasati</a></i> (Sanskrit: <i>ānāpānasmṛti</i>, "mindfulness of breathing"<i>).</i>
</p><p>A closely related mental faculty, which is often mentioned side by side with mindfulness, is <i><a href="/wiki/Sampaja%C3%B1%C3%B1a" title="Sampajañña">sampajañña</a></i> ("clear comprehension"). This faculty is the ability to comprehend what one is doing and is happening in the mind, and whether it is being influenced by unwholesome states or wholesome ones.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKuan200750_346-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKuan200750-346">[314]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Meditation_.E2.80.93_Sama-am.C4.81dhi_and_dhy.C4.81na"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Meditation_–_Sama-amādhi_and_dhyāna">Meditation – <i>Sama-amādhi</i> and <i>dhyāna</i></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_meditation" title="Buddhist meditation">Buddhist meditation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samadhi" title="Samadhi">Samadhi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samatha" title="Samatha">Samatha</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rupajhana" title="Rupajhana">Rupajhana</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kodo_Sawaki_Zazen.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2551" data-file-width="1786" decoding="async" height="314" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Kodo_Sawaki_Zazen.jpg/220px-Kodo_Sawaki_Zazen.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Kodo_Sawaki_Zazen.jpg/330px-Kodo_Sawaki_Zazen.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Kodo_Sawaki_Zazen.jpg/440px-Kodo_Sawaki_Zazen.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kodo_Sawaki_Zazen.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/K%C5%8Dd%C5%8D_Sawaki" title="Kōdō Sawaki">Kōdō Sawaki</a> practicing <a href="/wiki/Zazen" title="Zazen">Zazen</a> ("sitting dhyana")</div></div></div>
<p>A wide range of meditation practices has developed in the Buddhist traditions, but "meditation" primarily refers to the attainment of <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sam%C4%81dhi_(Buddhism)" title="Samādhi (Buddhism)">samādhi</a></i> and the practice of <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dhy%C4%81na_in_Buddhism" title="Dhyāna in Buddhism">dhyāna</a></i> (Pali: <i>jhāna</i>). <i>Samādhi</i> is a calm, undistracted, unified and concentrated state of awareness. It is defined by Asanga as "one-pointedness of mind on the object to be investigated. Its function consists of giving a basis to knowledge (<i>jñāna</i>)."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boin-Webb,_Sara_2001_p._9_344-1"><a href="#cite_note-Boin-Webb,_Sara_2001_p._9-344">[312]</a></sup>
<i>Dhyāna</i> is "state of perfect equanimity and awareness (<i>upekkhā-sati-parisuddhi</i>)," reached through focused mental training.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[315]</a></sup>
</p><p>The practice of <i>dhyāna</i> aids in maintaining a calm mind, and avoiding disturbance of this calm mind by mindfulness of disturbing thoughts and feelings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200045–46_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200045–46-348">[316]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[note 25]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Origins">Origins</span></h4>
