<p>The earliest evidence of yogis and their meditative tradition, states Karel Werner, is found in the <a href="/wiki/Ke%C5%9Bin" title="Keśin">Keśin</a> hymn 10.136 of the <a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-karelwernerkesinrv_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-karelwernerkesinrv-350">[317]</a></sup> While evidence suggests <a href="/wiki/Meditation" title="Meditation">meditation</a> was practised in the centuries preceding the Buddha,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarrithers198630_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarrithers198630-351">[318]</a></sup> the meditative methodologies described in the Buddhist texts are some of the earliest among texts that have survived into the modern era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198844_352-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198844-352">[319]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiller19968_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiller19968-353">[320]</a></sup> These methodologies likely incorporate what existed before the Buddha as well as those first developed within Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst19931–17_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst19931–17-354">[321]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[note 26]</a></sup>
</p><p>There is no scholarly agreement on the origin and source of the practice of <i>dhyāna.</i> Some scholars, like Bronkhorst, see the <i>four dhyānas</i> as a Buddhist invention.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199399_359-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199399-359">[325]</a></sup> Alexander Wynne argues that the Buddha learned <i>dhyāna</i> from Brahmanical teachers.<sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWynne2007[[Category:Wikipedia_articles_needing_page_number_citations_from_October_2020]]&lt;sup_class="noprint_Inline-Template_"_style="white-space:nowrap;"&gt;&amp;#91;&lt;i&gt;[[Wikipedia:Citing_sources|&lt;span_title="This_citation_requires_a_reference_to_the_specific_page_or_range_of_pages_in_which_the_material_appears.&amp;#32;(October_2020)"&gt;page&amp;nbsp;needed&lt;/span&gt;]]&lt;/i&gt;&amp;#93;&lt;/sup&gt;_360-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWynne2007[[Category:Wikipedia_articles_needing_page_number_citations_from_October_2020]]&lt;sup_class="noprint_Inline-Template_"_style="white-space:nowrap;"&gt;&amp;#91;&lt;i&gt;[[Wikipedia:Citing_sources|&lt;span_title="This_citation_requires_a_reference_to_the_specific_page_or_range_of_pages_in_which_the_material_appears.&amp;#32;(October_2020)"&gt;page&amp;nbsp;needed&lt;/span&gt;]]&lt;/i&gt;&amp;#93;&lt;/sup&gt;-360'>[326]</a></sup>
</p><p>Whatever the case, the Buddha taught meditation with a new focus and interpretation, particularly through the <i>four dhyānas</i> methodology,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993Part_I:_page_5_361-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993Part_I:_page_5-361">[327]</a></sup> in which mindfulness is maintained.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199388_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199388-362">[328]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich2007_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich2007-363">[329]</a></sup> Further, the focus of meditation and the underlying theory of liberation guiding the meditation has been different in Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarrithers198630_351-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarrithers198630-351">[318]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorman199729_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorman199729-364">[330]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich1997131_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich1997131-365">[331]</a></sup> For example, states Bronkhorst, the verse 4.4.23 of the <i>Brihadaranyaka Upanishad</i> with its "become calm, subdued, quiet, patiently enduring, concentrated, one sees soul in oneself" is most probably a meditative state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993Chapter_9,_page_86_366-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993Chapter_9,_page_86-366">[332]</a></sup> The Buddhist discussion of meditation is without the concept of soul and the discussion criticises both the ascetic meditation of Jainism and the "real self, soul" meditation of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199374_(Chapter_8),_102_(Conclusion)_367-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199374_(Chapter_8),_102_(Conclusion)-367">[333]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Four_rupa-jh.C4.81na"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Four_rupa-jhāna">Four <i>rupa-jhāna</i></span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gal_Viharaya_02.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1825" data-file-width="2250" decoding="async" height="178" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Gal_Viharaya_02.jpg/220px-Gal_Viharaya_02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Gal_Viharaya_02.jpg/330px-Gal_Viharaya_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Gal_Viharaya_02.jpg/440px-Gal_Viharaya_02.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gal_Viharaya_02.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Seated Buddha, <a href="/wiki/Gal_Vihara" title="Gal Vihara">Gal Vihara</a>, Polonnawura, Sri Lanka</div></div></div>
<p>Buddhist texts teach various meditation schemas. One of the most prominent is that of the four <i>rupa-jhānas</i> (four meditations in the realm of form), in which body and mind are investigated and lead to a "state of perfect <a href="/wiki/Equanimity" title="Equanimity">equanimity</a> and awareness (<i><a href="/wiki/Upek%E1%B9%A3%C4%81" title="Upekṣā">upekkhā</a>-<a href="/wiki/Sati_(Buddhism)" title="Sati (Buddhism)">sati</a>-<a href="/wiki/Purity_in_Buddhism" title="Purity in Buddhism">parisuddhi</a></i>)."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter19885_368-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter19885-368">[334]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBucknell1993_369-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBucknell1993-369">[335]</a></sup> According to Gethin, they are states of "perfect mindfulness, stillness and lucidity."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[336]</a></sup> In the early texts, the Buddha is depicted as entering jhāna both before his awakening under the bodhi tree and also before his final nirvana (see: the <i>Mahāsaccaka-sutta</i> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81parinibb%C4%81%E1%B9%87a_Sutta" title="Mahāparinibbāṇa Sutta">Mahāparinibbāṇa Sutta</a></i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[337]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[338]</a></sup>While usually interpreted as describing a deepening concentration and one-pointedness, the <i>jhānas</i> can also be interpreted as describing a development from investigating body and mind and abandoning unwholesome states, to perfected equanimity and watchfulness.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArbel2016_373-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArbel2016-373">[339]</a></sup> The stock description of the <i>jhānas</i>, with traditional and alternative interpretations, is as follows:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAbdel2016_374-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAbdel2016-374">[340]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[note 27]</a></sup>
</p>
<ol><li>First <i>jhāna</i>:
<dl><dd><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Right_effort" title="Right effort">Separated</a> (<i>vivicceva</i>) from desire for sensual pleasures, separated (<i>vivicca</i>) from [other] <a href="/wiki/Kleshas_(Buddhism)" title="Kleshas (Buddhism)">unwholesome states</a> (<i>akusalehi dhammehi</i>, unwholesome <i>dhammas</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJohansson198183_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJohansson198183-376">[341]</a></sup>), a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the first <i>jhana</i>, which is [mental] <i><a href="/wiki/P%C4%ABti" title="Pīti">pīti</a></i> ("rapture," "joy") and [bodily] <i><a href="/wiki/Sukha" title="Sukha">sukha</a></i> ("pleasure") "born of <i><a href="/wiki/Viveka" title="Viveka">viveka</a></i> (trad.: "seclusion"; altern. "discrimination" (of dhamma's)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArbel201650-51_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArbel201650-51-377">[342]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[note 28]</a></sup>), accompanied by <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vitarka-vicara" title="Vitarka-vicara">vitarka-vicara</a></i> (trad. initial and sustained attention to a meditative object; altern. initial inquiry and <a href="/wiki/Dhamma_vicaya" title="Dhamma vicaya">subsequent investigation</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWayman199748_381-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWayman199748-381">[345]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESangpoDhammajoti20122413_382-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESangpoDhammajoti20122413-382">[346]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELusthaus200289_383-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELusthaus200289-383">[347]</a></sup> of <i>dhammas</i> (<a href="/wiki/Kleshas_(Buddhism)" title="Kleshas (Buddhism)">defilements</a><sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChen2017"samadhi:_A_calm,_stable_and_concentrative_state_of_mind"_384-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChen2017"samadhi:_A_calm,_stable_and_concentrative_state_of_mind"-384'>[348]</a></sup> and wholesome thoughts<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArbel201673_385-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArbel201673-385">[349]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[note 29]</a></sup>); also: "discursive thought"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[note 30]</a></sup>).</dd></dl></li>
<li>Second <i>jhāna</i>:
<dl><dd>Again, with the stilling of <i>vitarka-vicara</i>, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the second <i>jhana</i>, which is [mental] <i>pīti</i> and [bodily] <i>sukha</i> "born of <a href="/wiki/Samadhi" title="Samadhi">samadhi</a>" (<i>samadhi-ji</i>; trad. born of "concentration"; altern. "knowing but non-discursive [...] awareness,"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArbel201694_396-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArbel201694-396">[358]</a></sup> "bringing the buried latencies or <i><a href="/wiki/Samskara_(Indian_philosophy)" title="Samskara (Indian philosophy)">samskaras</a></i> into full view"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELusthaus2002113_397-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELusthaus2002113-397">[359]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[note 31]</a></sup>), and has <i><a href="/wiki/Passaddhi" title="Passaddhi">sampasadana</a></i> ("stillness,"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArbel201686_400-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArbel201686-400">[361]</a></sup> "inner tranquility"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBucknell1993375-376_392-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBucknell1993375-376-392">[355]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[note 32]</a></sup>) and <i><a href="/wiki/Ekaggata" title="Ekaggata">ekaggata</a></i> (unification of mind,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArbel201686_400-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArbel201686-400">[361]</a></sup> awareness) without <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vitarka-vicara" title="Vitarka-vicara">vitarka-vicara</a></i>;</dd></dl></li>
<li>Third <i>jhāna</i>:
<dl><dd>With the fading away of <i>pīti</i>, a bhikkhu abides in <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Upekkh%C4%81" title="Upekkhā">upekkhā</a></i> (equanimity," "affective detachment"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBucknell1993375-376_392-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBucknell1993375-376-392">[355]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[note 33]</a></sup>), <i><a href="/wiki/Sati_(Buddhism)" title="Sati (Buddhism)">sato</a></i> (mindful) and [with] <i><a href="/wiki/Sampaja%C3%B1%C3%B1a" title="Sampajañña">sampajañña</a></i> ("fully knowing,"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArbel2016115_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArbel2016115-403">[362]</a></sup> "discerning awareness"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELusthaus200290_404-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELusthaus200290-404">[363]</a></sup>). [Still] experiencing <i>sukha</i> with the body, he enters upon and abides in the third <i>jhana</i>, on account of which the noble ones announce: 'abding in [bodily] pleasure, one is equanimous and mindful'.</dd></dl></li>
<li>Fourth <i>jhāna</i>:
<dl><dd>With the abandoning of [the desire for] <i>sukha</i> ("pleasure") and [aversion to] <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dukkha" title="Dukkha">dukkha</a></i> ("pain"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArbel2016124_405-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArbel2016124-405">[364]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELusthaus200290_404-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELusthaus200290-404">[363]</a></sup>) and with the previous disappearance of [the inner movement between] <i>somanassa</i> ("gladness,"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArbel2016125_406-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArbel2016125-406">[365]</a></sup>) and <i>domanassa</i> ("discontent"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArbel2016125_406-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArbel2016125-406">[365]</a></sup>), a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the fourth <i>jhana</i>, which is <i>adukkham asukham</i> ("neither-painfull-nor-pleasurable,"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArbel2016124_405-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArbel2016124-405">[364]</a></sup> "freedom from pleasure and pain"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJohansson198198_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJohansson198198-407">[366]</a></sup>) and has <i>upekkhāsatipārisuddhi</i> (complete purity of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Upekkha" title="Upekkha">equanimity</a> and mindfulness).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[note 34]</a></sup></dd></dl></li></ol>
<p>In the later commentarial tradition, which has survived in present-day <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravāda</a>, <i>dhyāna</i> is equated with "concentration", a state of one-pointed absorption in which there is a diminished awareness of the surroundings. In the contemporary Theravāda-based <a href="/wiki/Vipassana_movement" title="Vipassana movement">Vipassana movement</a>, this absorbed state of mind is regarded as unnecessary and even non-beneficial for the <a href="/wiki/Four_stages_of_awakening" title="Four stages of awakening">first stage of awakening</a>, which has to be reached by mindfulness of the body and <i>vipassanā</i> (insight into impermanence). Since the 1980s, scholars and practitioners have started to question these positions, arguing for a more comprehensive and integrated understanding and approach, based on the oldest descriptions of <i>dhyāna</i> in the <i><a href="/wiki/Sutra" title="Sutra">sutta</a></i>s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERose201660_410-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERose201660-410">[368]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShankman2008_411-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShankman2008-411">[369]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPolak2011_412-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPolak2011-412">[370]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArbel2017_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArbel2017-413">[371]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[note 35]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="The_formless_attaiments">The formless attaiments</span></h4>
<p>Often grouped into the <i>jhāna</i>-scheme are four other meditative states, referred to in the early texts as <i>arupa samāpattis</i> (formless attainments). These are also referred to in commentarial literature as immaterial/formless <i>jhānas</i> (<i>arūpajhānas</i>). The first formless attainment is a place or realm of infinite space (<i>ākāsānañcāyatana</i>) without form or colour or shape. The second is termed the realm of infinite consciousness (<i>viññāṇañcāyatana</i>); the third is the realm of nothingness (<i>ākiñcaññāyatana</i>), while the fourth is the realm of "neither perception nor non-perception".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wayman1984p86_415-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wayman1984p86-415">[372]</a></sup> The four <i>rupa-jhānas</i> in Buddhist practice lead to rebirth in successfully better <i>rupa</i> Brahma heavenly realms, while <i>arupa-jhānas</i> lead into arupa heavens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[373]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[374]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Meditation_and_insight">Meditation and insight</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href='/wiki/Four_Noble_Truths#Substituting_"liberating_insight"' title="Four Noble Truths">Meditation and insight</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">Yoga</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Farsari_Daibutsu.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="824" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="177" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Farsari_Daibutsu.jpg/220px-Farsari_Daibutsu.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Farsari_Daibutsu.jpg/330px-Farsari_Daibutsu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Farsari_Daibutsu.jpg/440px-Farsari_Daibutsu.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Farsari_Daibutsu.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kamakura_Daibutsu" title="Kamakura Daibutsu">Kamakura Daibutsu</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/K%C5%8Dtoku-in" title="Kōtoku-in">Kōtoku-in</a>, Kamakura, Japan</div></div></div>
<p>In the Pali canon, the Buddha outlines two meditative qualities which are mutually supportive: <i><a href="/wiki/Samatha" title="Samatha">samatha</a></i> (Pāli; Sanskrit: <i>śamatha</i>; "calm") and <i><a href="/wiki/Vipassan%C4%81" title="Vipassanā">vipassanā</a></i> (Sanskrit: <i>vipaśyanā</i>, insight).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBodhi2005269–270,_440_''n''._13_418-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBodhi2005269–270,_440_''n''._13-418">[375]</a></sup> The Buddha compares these mental qualities to a "swift pair of messengers" who together help deliver the message of <i>nibbana</i> (SN 35.245).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBodhi20001251–1253_419-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBodhi20001251–1253-419">[376]</a></sup>
</p><p>The various Buddhist traditions generally see Buddhist meditation as being divided into those two main types.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWelch1967396_420-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWelch1967396-420">[377]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[378]</a></sup> Samatha is also called "calming meditation", and focuses on stilling and concentrating the mind i.e. developing samadhi and the four <i>dhyānas</i>. According to Damien Keown, <i>vipassanā</i> meanwhile, focuses on "the generation of penetrating and critical insight (<i>paññā</i>)".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown1996106–107,_context:_Chapter_7_422-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown1996106–107,_context:_Chapter_7-422">[379]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are numerous doctrinal positions and disagreements within the different Buddhist traditions regarding these qualities or forms of meditation. For example, in the Pali <i>Four Ways to Arahantship Sutta</i> (AN 4.170), it is said that one can develop calm and then insight, or insight and then calm, or both at the same time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBodhi2005268,_439_423-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBodhi2005268,_439-423">[380]</a></sup> Meanwhile, in Vasubandhu's <i>Abhidharmakośakārikā</i>, vipaśyanā is said to be practiced once one has reached samadhi by cultivating the four foundations of mindfulness (<i>smṛtyupasthāna</i>s).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[381]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beginning with comments by <a href="/wiki/Louis_de_La_Vall%C3%A9e-Poussin" title="Louis de La Vallée-Poussin">La Vallee Poussin</a>, a series of scholars have argued that these two meditation types reflect a tension between two different ancient Buddhist traditions regarding the use of <i>dhyāna,</i> one which focused on insight based practice and the other which focused purely on <i>dhyāna</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993-425">[382]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-buddhismuskunde.uni-hamburg.de_426-0"><a href="#cite_note-buddhismuskunde.uni-hamburg.de-426">[383]</a></sup> However, other scholars such as Analayo and Rupert Gethin have disagreed with this "two paths" thesis, instead seeing both of these practices as complementary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-buddhismuskunde.uni-hamburg.de_426-1"><a href="#cite_note-buddhismuskunde.uni-hamburg.de-426">[383]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin2001xiv_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin2001xiv-427">[384]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Brahma-vihara">The <i>Brahma-vihara</i></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Brahmavihara" title="Brahmavihara">Brahmavihara</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Phra_Buddha_Jinaraj_-_Phitsanulok.jpg"><img alt="gilded statue of Buddha in Wat Phra Si Rattana Mahathat, Thailand" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1707" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Phra_Buddha_Jinaraj_-_Phitsanulok.jpg/220px-Phra_Buddha_Jinaraj_-_Phitsanulok.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Phra_Buddha_Jinaraj_-_Phitsanulok.jpg/330px-Phra_Buddha_Jinaraj_-_Phitsanulok.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Phra_Buddha_Jinaraj_-_Phitsanulok.jpg/440px-Phra_Buddha_Jinaraj_-_Phitsanulok.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Phra_Buddha_Jinaraj_-_Phitsanulok.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Statue of Buddha in <a href="/wiki/Wat_Phra_Si_Rattana_Mahathat" title="Wat Phra Si Rattana Mahathat">Wat Phra Si Rattana Mahathat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phitsanulok" title="Phitsanulok">Phitsanulok</a>, Thailand</div></div></div>
<p>The four immeasurables or four abodes, also called <i>Brahma-viharas</i>, are virtues or directions for meditation in Buddhist traditions, which helps a person be reborn in the heavenly (Brahma) realm.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993172–174_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993172–174-428">[385]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013154,_326_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013154,_326-429">[386]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[387]</a></sup> These are traditionally believed to be a characteristic of the deity Brahma and the heavenly abode he resides in.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[388]</a></sup>
</p><p>The four <i>Brahma-vihara</i> are:
</p>
<ol><li>Loving-kindness (Pāli: <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mett%C4%81" title="Mettā">mettā</a></i>, Sanskrit: <i>maitrī</i>) is active good will towards all;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013154,_326_429-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013154,_326-429">[386]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFowler199960–62_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFowler199960–62-432">[389]</a></sup></li>
<li>Compassion (Pāli and Sanskrit: <i><a href="/wiki/Karu%E1%B9%87%C4%81" title="Karuṇā">karuṇā</a></i>) results from <i>metta</i>; it is identifying the suffering of others as one's own;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013154,_326_429-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013154,_326-429">[386]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFowler199960–62_432-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFowler199960–62-432">[389]</a></sup></li>
<li>Empathetic joy (Pāli and Sanskrit: <i><a href="/wiki/Mudita" title="Mudita">muditā</a></i>): is the feeling of joy because others are happy, even if one did not contribute to it; it is a form of sympathetic joy;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFowler199960–62_432-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFowler199960–62-432">[389]</a></sup></li>
<li>Equanimity (Pāli: <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Upekkha" title="Upekkha">upekkhā</a></i>, Sanskrit: <i>upekṣā</i>): is even-mindedness and serenity, treating everyone impartially.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013154,_326_429-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013154,_326-429">[386]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFowler199960–62_432-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFowler199960–62-432">[389]</a></sup></li></ol>
<p>According to Peter Harvey, the Buddhist scriptures acknowledge that the four <i>Brahmavihara</i> meditation practices "did not originate within the Buddhist tradition".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[390]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[note 36]</a></sup> The Brahmavihara (sometimes as Brahmaloka), along with the tradition of meditation and the above four immeasurables are found in pre-Buddha and post-Buddha Vedic and Sramanic literature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[392]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[393]</a></sup> Aspects of the Brahmavihara practice for rebirths into the heavenly realm have been an important part of Buddhist meditation tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAronson198060–83_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAronson198060–83-438">[394]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECollins1998304–305,_fn._13_439-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollins1998304–305,_fn._13-439">[395]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Gombrich, the Buddhist usage of the <i>brahma-vihāra</i> originally referred to an awakened state of mind, and a concrete attitude toward other beings which was equal to "living with Brahman" here and now. The later tradition took those descriptions too literally, linking them to cosmology and understanding them as "living with Brahman" by rebirth in the Brahma-world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich199784–85_440-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich199784–85-440">[396]</a></sup> According to Gombrich, "the Buddha taught that kindness – what Christians tend to call love – was a way to salvation."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich199762_441-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich199762-441">[397]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Tantra.2C_visualization_and_the_subtle_body"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Tantra,_visualization_and_the_subtle_body">Tantra, visualization and the subtle body</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tibetan_Tantric_Practice" title="Tibetan Tantric Practice">Tibetan Tantric Practice</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vajrayana#Tantra_techniques" title="Vajrayana">Vajrayana § Tantra_techniques</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Schildering_uit_reeks_over_de_Sarvavid_Vairocana_Mandala_-_Licht,_anoniem,_ca_1799,_MAS.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1208" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="221" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Schildering_uit_reeks_over_de_Sarvavid_Vairocana_Mandala_-_Licht%2C_anoniem%2C_ca_1799%2C_MAS.jpg/220px-Schildering_uit_reeks_over_de_Sarvavid_Vairocana_Mandala_-_Licht%2C_anoniem%2C_ca_1799%2C_MAS.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Schildering_uit_reeks_over_de_Sarvavid_Vairocana_Mandala_-_Licht%2C_anoniem%2C_ca_1799%2C_MAS.jpg/330px-Schildering_uit_reeks_over_de_Sarvavid_Vairocana_Mandala_-_Licht%2C_anoniem%2C_ca_1799%2C_MAS.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Schildering_uit_reeks_over_de_Sarvavid_Vairocana_Mandala_-_Licht%2C_anoniem%2C_ca_1799%2C_MAS.jpg/440px-Schildering_uit_reeks_over_de_Sarvavid_Vairocana_Mandala_-_Licht%2C_anoniem%2C_ca_1799%2C_MAS.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Schildering_uit_reeks_over_de_Sarvavid_Vairocana_Mandala_-_Licht,_anoniem,_ca_1799,_MAS.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An 18th century Mongolian miniature which depicts the generation of the Vairocana Mandala</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D1%82%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%BC%D0%BE.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2993" data-file-width="2232" decoding="async" height="295" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D1%82%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%BC%D0%BE.jpg/220px-%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D1%82%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%BC%D0%BE.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D1%82%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%BC%D0%BE.jpg/330px-%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D1%82%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%BC%D0%BE.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D1%82%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%BC%D0%BE.jpg/440px-%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D1%82%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%BC%D0%BE.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D1%82%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%BC%D0%BE.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A section of the Northern wall mural at the <a href="/wiki/Lukhang" title="Lukhang">Lukhang</a> Temple depicting <i>tummo</i>, the three channels (<i>nadis</i>) and <i>phowa</i></div></div></div>
<p>Some Buddhist traditions, especially those associated with Tantric Buddhism (also known as Vajrayana and Secret Mantra) use images and symbols of deities and Buddhas in meditation. This is generally done by mentally visualizing a Buddha image (or some other mental image, like a symbol, a mandala, a syllable, etc.), and using that image to cultivate calm and insight. One may also visualize and identify oneself with the imagined deity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200487_442-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200487-442">[398]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[399]</a></sup> While visualization practices have been particularly popular in Vajrayana, they may also found in Mahayana and Theravada traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200486–87_444-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200486–87-444">[400]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Tibetan Buddhism, unique tantric techniques which include visualization (but also <a href="/wiki/Mantra" title="Mantra">mantra</a> recitation, <a href="/wiki/Mandala" title="Mandala">mandalas</a>, and other elements) are considered to be much more effective than non-tantric meditations and they are one of the most popular meditation methods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPowers2007250_445-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPowers2007250-445">[401]</a></sup> The methods of <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anuttarayoga_Tantra" title="Anuttarayoga Tantra">Unsurpassable Yoga Tantra</a></i>, (<i>anuttarayogatantra</i>) are in turn seen as the highest and most advanced. Anuttarayoga practice is divided into two stages, the <i>Generation Stage</i> and the <i>Completion Stage.</i> In the Generation Stage, one meditates on emptiness and visualizes oneself as a deity as well as visualizing its mandala. The focus is on developing clear appearance and divine pride (the understanding that oneself and the deity are one).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[402]</a></sup> This method is also known as deity yoga (<i>devata yoga</i>). There are numerous meditation deities (<i><a href="/wiki/Yidam" title="Yidam">yidam</a></i>) used, each with a mandala, a circular symbolic map used in meditation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200488–89_447-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200488–89-447">[403]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the Completion Stage, one meditates on ultimate reality based on the image that has been generated. Completion Stage practices also include techniques such as <i><a href="/wiki/Tummo" title="Tummo">tummo</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Phowa" title="Phowa">phowa</a></i>. These are said to work with <a href="/wiki/Subtle_body" title="Subtle body">subtle body</a> elements, like the energy channels (<i>nadi</i>), vital essences (<i>bindu</i>), "vital winds" (<i>vayu</i>), and <a href="/wiki/Chakra" title="Chakra">chakras</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[404]</a></sup> The subtle body energies are seen as influencing consciousness in powerful ways, and are thus used in order to generate the 'great bliss' (<i>maha-sukha</i>) which is used to attain <a href="/wiki/Luminous_mind" title="Luminous mind">the luminous nature of the mind</a> and realization of the empty and illusory nature of all phenomena ("the illusory body"), which leads to enlightenment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[405]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[406]</a></sup>
</p><p>Completion practices are often grouped into different systems, such as the <a href="/wiki/Six_Dharmas_of_Naropa" title="Six Dharmas of Naropa">six dharmas of Naropa</a>, and the six yogas of <a href="/wiki/Kalachakra" title="Kalachakra">Kalachakra</a>. In Tibetan Buddhism, there are also practices and methods which are sometimes seen as being outside of the two tantric stages, mainly <a href="/wiki/Mahamudra" title="Mahamudra">Mahamudra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dzogchen" title="Dzogchen">Dzogchen</a> (<i>Atiyoga</i>).
</p>
<h4><span id="Practice:_monks.2C_laity"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Practice:_monks,_laity">Practice: monks, laity</span></h4>
<p>According to Peter Harvey, whenever Buddhism has been healthy, not only ordained but also more committed lay people have practised formal meditation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013319_451-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013319-451">[407]</a></sup> Loud devotional chanting however, adds Harvey, has been the most prevalent Buddhist practice and considered a form of meditation that produces "energy, joy, lovingkindness and calm", purifies mind and benefits the chanter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013243–244,_257–258,_318–319_452-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013243–244,_257–258,_318–319-452">[408]</a></sup>
</p><p>Throughout most of Buddhist history, meditation has been primarily practised in Buddhist monastic tradition, and historical evidence suggests that serious meditation by lay people has been an exception.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2013502_453-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2013502-453">[409]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[410]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[411]</a></sup> In recent history, sustained meditation has been pursued by a minority of monks in Buddhist monasteries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2013502–504_456-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2013502–504-456">[412]</a></sup> Western interest in meditation has led to a revival where ancient Buddhist ideas and precepts are adapted to Western mores and interpreted liberally, presenting Buddhism as a meditation-based form of spirituality.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2013502–504_456-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2013502–504-456">[412]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Insight_and_knowledge">Insight and knowledge</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Praj%C3%B1%C4%81_(Buddhism)" title="Prajñā (Buddhism)">Prajñā</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bodhi" title="Bodhi">Bodhi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kensh%C5%8D" title="Kenshō">Kenshō</a>, <a href="/wiki/Satori" title="Satori">Satori</a>, <a href="/wiki/Subitism" title="Subitism">Subitism</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vipassana" title="Vipassana">Vipassana</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Monks_Debating_Practice_At_Sera_Monastery.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2464" data-file-width="2980" decoding="async" height="182" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Monks_Debating_Practice_At_Sera_Monastery.JPG/220px-Monks_Debating_Practice_At_Sera_Monastery.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Monks_Debating_Practice_At_Sera_Monastery.JPG/330px-Monks_Debating_Practice_At_Sera_Monastery.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Monks_Debating_Practice_At_Sera_Monastery.JPG/440px-Monks_Debating_Practice_At_Sera_Monastery.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Monks_Debating_Practice_At_Sera_Monastery.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bhikku" title="Bhikku">Monks</a> debating at <a href="/wiki/Sera_Monastery" title="Sera Monastery">Sera Monastery</a>, Tibet</div></div></div>
<p><i>Prajñā</i> (Sanskrit) or <i>paññā</i> (Pāli) is <a href="/wiki/Wisdom" title="Wisdom">wisdom</a>, or knowledge of the true nature of existence. Another term which is associated with <i>prajñā</i> and sometimes is equivalent to it is <i>vipassanā</i> (Pāli) or <i>vipaśyanā</i> (Sanskrit), which is often translated as "insight". In Buddhist texts, the faculty of insight is often said to be cultivated through the four establishments of mindfulness.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKuan200758_457-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKuan200758-457">[413]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the early texts, <i>Paññā</i> is included as one of the "five faculties" (<i><a href="/wiki/Indriya" title="Indriya">indriya</a></i>) which are commonly listed as important spiritual elements to be cultivated (see for example: AN I 16). <i>Paññā</i> along with samadhi, is also listed as one of the "trainings in the higher states of mind" (<i>adhicittasikkha</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKuan200758_457-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKuan200758-457">[413]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Buddhist tradition regards ignorance (<a href="/wiki/Avidy%C4%81_(Buddhism)" title="Avidyā (Buddhism)"><i>avidyā</i></a>), a fundamental ignorance, misunderstanding or mis-perception of the nature of reality, as one of the basic causes of <i>dukkha</i> and <i>samsara</i>. Overcoming this ignorance is part of the path to awakening. This overcoming includes the contemplation of impermanence and the non-self nature of reality,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200474_458-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200474-458">[414]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConze201339–40_459-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConze201339–40-459">[415]</a></sup> and this develops dispassion for the objects of <a href="/wiki/Up%C4%81d%C4%81na" title="Upādāna">clinging</a>, and liberates a being from <i>dukkha</i> and <i>saṃsāra</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFowler199949–52_460-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFowler199949–52-460">[416]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[417]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199873–75,_146–159,_243_462-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199873–75,_146–159,_243-462">[418]</a></sup>
</p><p><i>Prajñā</i> is important in all Buddhist traditions. It is variously described as wisdom regarding the impermanent and <a href="/wiki/Anatt%C4%81" title="Anattā">not-self</a> nature of dharmas (phenomena), the functioning of karma and rebirth, and knowledge of dependent origination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004664–665_463-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004664–665-463">[419]</a></sup> Likewise, <i>vipaśyanā</i> is described in a similar way, such as in the <i><a href="/wiki/Pa%E1%B9%ADisambhid%C4%81magga" title="Paṭisambhidāmagga">Paṭisambhidāmagga</a></i>, where it is said to be the contemplation of things as impermanent, unsatisfactory and <a href="/wiki/Anatt%C4%81" title="Anattā">not-self</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKuan200759_464-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKuan200759-464">[420]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some scholars such as Bronkhorst and Vetter have argued that the idea that insight leads to liberation was a later development in Buddhism and that there are inconsistencies with the early Buddhist presentation of samadhi and insight.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxxii,_xxxiii_465-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxxii,_xxxiii-465">[421]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199354–55,_96,_99_466-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199354–55,_96,_99-466">[422]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[note 37]</a></sup> However, others such as Collett Cox and <a href="/wiki/Damien_Keown" title="Damien Keown">Damien Keown</a> have argued that insight is a key aspect of the early Buddhist process of liberation, which cooperates with samadhi to remove the obstacles to enlightenment (i.e., the <a href="/wiki/Asava" title="Asava">āsavas</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[424]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470"><a href="#cite_note-470">[425]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Theravāda Buddhism, the focus of vipassanā meditation is to continuously and thoroughly know how phenomena (<i>dhammas</i>) are <a href="/wiki/Impermanence" title="Impermanence">impermanent</a> (<i>annica</i>), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anatta" title="Anatta">not-self</a> (<i>anatta</i>) and <i>dukkha</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471"><a href="#cite_note-471">[426]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[427]</a></sup> The most widely used method in modern Theravāda for the practice of <i>vipassanā</i> is that found in the <i>Satipatthana Sutta</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBond1992167_473-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBond1992167-473">[428]</a></sup> There is some disagreement in contemporary Theravāda regarding samatha and vipassanā. Some in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vipassana_Movement" title="Vipassana Movement">Vipassana Movement</a> strongly emphasize the practice of insight over samatha, and other Theravadins disagree with this.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBond1992167_473-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBond1992167-473">[428]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Mahāyāna Buddhism, the development of insight (<i>vipaśyanā</i>) and tranquility (<i>śamatha</i>) are also taught and practiced. The many different schools of Mahāyāna Buddhism have a large repertoire of meditation techniques to cultivate these qualities. These include visualization of various Buddhas, recitation of a Buddha's name, the use of tantric Buddhist <a href="/wiki/Mantra" title="Mantra">mantras</a> and dharanis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474"><a href="#cite_note-474">[429]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993300_475-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993300-475">[430]</a></sup> Insight in Mahāyāna Buddhism also includes gaining a direct understanding of certain Mahāyāna philosophical views, such as the emptiness view and the consciousness-only view. This can be seen in meditation texts such as Kamalaśīla's <i><a href="/wiki/Bh%C4%81van%C4%81krama" title="Bhāvanākrama">Bhāvanākrama</a></i> ( "Stages of Meditation", 9th century), which teaches insight (<i>vipaśyanā</i>) from the Yogācāra-Madhyamaka perspective.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[431]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Devotion">Devotion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_devotion" title="Buddhist devotion">Buddhist devotion</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:IMG_1016_Lhasa_Barkhor.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1333" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/IMG_1016_Lhasa_Barkhor.jpg/220px-IMG_1016_Lhasa_Barkhor.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/IMG_1016_Lhasa_Barkhor.jpg/330px-IMG_1016_Lhasa_Barkhor.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/IMG_1016_Lhasa_Barkhor.jpg/440px-IMG_1016_Lhasa_Barkhor.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:IMG_1016_Lhasa_Barkhor.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Tibetan Buddhist prostration practice at <a href="/wiki/Jokhang" title="Jokhang">Jokhang</a>, Tibet</div></div></div>
<p>According to Harvey, most forms of Buddhism "consider <i><a href="/wiki/Faith_in_Buddhism" title="Faith in Buddhism">saddhā</a></i> (Skt <i>śraddhā</i>), ‘trustful confidence’ or ‘faith’, as a quality which must be balanced by wisdom, and as a preparation for, or accompaniment of, meditation."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013237_477-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013237-477">[432]</a></sup> Because of this devotion (Skt. bhakti; Pali: bhatti) is an important part of the practice of most Buddhists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey1998170_478-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey1998170-478">[433]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_devotion" title="Buddhist devotion">Devotional practices</a> include ritual prayer, prostration, offerings, pilgrimage, and chanting.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200484–85,_105,_108–109,_112–113,_116,_165,_185_479-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200484–85,_105,_108–109,_112–113,_116,_165,_185-479">[434]</a></sup> Buddhist devotion is usually focused on some object, image or location that is seen as holy or spiritually influential. Examples of objects of devotion include paintings or statues of Buddhas and bodhisattvas, stupas, and bodhi trees.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013239–240_480-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013239–240-480">[435]</a></sup> Public group chanting for devotional and ceremonial is common to all Buddhist traditions and goes back to ancient India where chanting aided in the memorization of the orally transmitted teachings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013243_481-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013243-481">[436]</a></sup> Rosaries called malas are used in all Buddhist traditions to count repeated chanting of common formulas or mantras. Chanting is thus a type of devotional group meditation which leads to tranquility and communicates the Buddhist teachings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013243–244_482-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013243–244-482">[437]</a></sup>
</p><p>In East Asian Pure Land Buddhism, devotion to the Buddha Amitabha is the main practice. In Nichiren Buddhism, devotion to the Lotus Sutra is the main practice. Devotional practices such as pujas have been a common practice in Theravada Buddhism, where offerings and group prayers are made to deities and particularly images of Buddha.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-483"><a href="#cite_note-483">[438]</a></sup> According to Karel Werner and other scholars, devotional worship has been a significant practice in <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a> Buddhism, and deep devotion is part of Buddhist traditions starting from the earliest days.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484"><a href="#cite_note-484">[439]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor2004108–109,_Quote:_"(...)_both_textual_and_archaeological_evidence_shows_that_devotion_has_long_been_a_part_of_Buddhism._The_practice_of_venerating_relics_and_images_has_long_played_a_central_role_even_in_Buddhist_traditions_that_strongly_emphasize_that_Gautama_Buddha_was_a_human_being_(...)"._485-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor2004108–109,_Quote:_"(...)_both_textual_and_archaeological_evidence_shows_that_devotion_has_long_been_a_part_of_Buddhism._The_practice_of_venerating_relics_and_images_has_long_played_a_central_role_even_in_Buddhist_traditions_that_strongly_emphasize_that_Gautama_Buddha_was_a_human_being_(...)".-485'>[440]</a></sup>
</p><p>Guru devotion is a central practice of Tibetan Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wolter2007p59_486-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wolter2007p59-486">[441]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-487"><a href="#cite_note-487">[442]</a></sup> The guru is considered essential and to the Buddhist devotee, the guru is the "enlightened teacher and ritual master" in Vajrayana spiritual pursuits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wolter2007p59_486-1"><a href="#cite_note-Wolter2007p59-486">[441]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-berkwitz130_488-0"><a href="#cite_note-berkwitz130-488">[443]</a></sup> For someone seeking Buddhahood, the guru is the Buddha, the Dharma and the Sangha, wrote the 12th-century Buddhist scholar Sadhanamala.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-berkwitz130_488-1"><a href="#cite_note-berkwitz130-488">[443]</a></sup>
</p><p>The veneration of and obedience to teachers is also important in Theravada and Zen Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489"><a href="#cite_note-489">[444]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Vegetarianism_and_animal_ethics">Vegetarianism and animal ethics</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_vegetarianism" title="Buddhist vegetarianism">Buddhist vegetarianism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vegetarian_meal_at_Buddhist_temple_(3810298969).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4272" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Vegetarian_meal_at_Buddhist_temple_%283810298969%29.jpg/220px-Vegetarian_meal_at_Buddhist_temple_%283810298969%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Vegetarian_meal_at_Buddhist_temple_%283810298969%29.jpg/330px-Vegetarian_meal_at_Buddhist_temple_%283810298969%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Vegetarian_meal_at_Buddhist_temple_%283810298969%29.jpg/440px-Vegetarian_meal_at_Buddhist_temple_%283810298969%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vegetarian_meal_at_Buddhist_temple_(3810298969).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Vegetarian meal at Buddhist temple. East Asian Buddhism tends to promote vegetarianism.</div></div></div>
<p>Based on the Indian principle of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ahi%E1%B9%83s%C4%81" title="Ahiṃsā">ahimsa</a> (non-harming), the Buddha's ethics strongly condemn the harming of all sentient beings, including all animals.  He thus condemned the animal sacrifice of the Brahmins as well hunting, and killing animals for food.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2000157–158_490-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2000157–158-490">[445]</a></sup> This led to various policies by Buddhist kings such as Asoka meant to protect animals, such as the establishing of 'no slaughter days' and the banning of hunting on certain circumstances.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2000158_491-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2000158-491">[446]</a></sup>
</p><p>However, early Buddhist texts depict the Buddha as allowing monastics to eat meat. This seems to be because monastics begged for their food and thus were supposed to accept whatever food was offered to them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2000156–159_492-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2000156–159-492">[447]</a></sup> This was tempered by the rule that meat had to be "three times clean" which meant that "they had not seen, had not heard, and had no reason to suspect that the animal had been killed so that the meat could be given to them".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Phelps,_Norm_2004_p._76_493-0"><a href="#cite_note-Phelps,_Norm_2004_p._76-493">[448]</a></sup> Also, while the Buddha did not explicitly promote vegetarianism in his discourses, he did state that gaining one's livelihood from the meat trade was unethical.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[449]</a></sup> However, this rule was not a promotion of a specific diet, but a rule against the actual killing of animals for food.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[450]</a></sup> There was also a famed schism which occurred in the Buddhist community when <a href="/wiki/Devadatta" title="Devadatta">Devadatta</a> attempted to make vegetarianism compulsory and the Buddha disagreed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Phelps,_Norm_2004_p._76_493-1"><a href="#cite_note-Phelps,_Norm_2004_p._76-493">[448]</a></sup>
</p><p>In contrast to this, various Mahayana sutras and texts like the <a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81y%C4%81na_Mah%C4%81parinirv%C4%81%E1%B9%87a_S%C5%ABtra" title="Mahāyāna Mahāparinirvāṇa Sūtra">Mahaparinirvana sutra</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C5%9A%C5%ABra%E1%B9%85gama_S%C5%ABtra" title="Śūraṅgama Sūtra">Surangama sutra</a> and the <a href="/wiki/La%E1%B9%85k%C4%81vat%C4%81ra_S%C5%ABtra" title="Laṅkāvatāra Sūtra">Lankavatara sutra</a> state that the Buddha promoted vegetarianism out of compassion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-496"><a href="#cite_note-496">[451]</a></sup> Indian Mahayana thinkers like Shantideva promoted the avoidance of meat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2000163_497-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2000163-497">[452]</a></sup> Throughout history, the issue of whether Buddhists should be vegetarian has remained a much debated topic and there is a variety of opinions on this issue among modern Buddhists.
</p><p>In the East Asian Buddhism, most monastics are expected to be vegetarian, and the practice is seen as very virtuous and it is taken up by some devout laypersons. Most Theravadins in <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a> and <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a> do not practice vegetarianism and eat whatever is offered by the lay community, who are mostly also not vegetarians. But there are exceptions, some monks choose to be vegetarian and some abbots like <a href="/wiki/Ajahn_Sumedho" title="Ajahn Sumedho">Ajahn Sumedho</a> have encouraged the lay community to donate vegetarian food to the monks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-498"><a href="#cite_note-498">[453]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mahasi_Sayadaw" title="Mahasi Sayadaw">Mahasi Sayadaw</a> meanwhile, has recommended vegetarianism as the best way to make sure one's meal is pure in three ways.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2000161_499-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2000161-499">[454]</a></sup> Also, the new religious movement <a href="/wiki/Santi_Asoke" title="Santi Asoke">Santi Asoke</a>, promotes vegetarianism. According to Peter Harvey, in the Theravada world, vegetarianism is "universally admired, but little practiced".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2000161_499-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2000161-499">[454]</a></sup> Because of the rule against killing, in many Buddhist countries, most butchers and others who work in the meat trade are non-Buddhists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2000162_500-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2000162-500">[455]</a></sup>
</p><p>Likewise, most Tibetan Buddhists have historically tended not to be vegetarian, however, there have been some strong debates and pro-vegetarian arguments by some pro-vegetarian Tibetans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[456]</a></sup> Some influential figures have spoken and written in favor of vegetarianism throughout history, including well known figures like <a href="/wiki/Shabkar_Tsokdruk_Rangdrol" title="Shabkar Tsokdruk Rangdrol">Shabkar</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ogyen_Trinley_Dorje" title="Ogyen Trinley Dorje">17th Karmapa Ogyen Trinley Dorje</a>, who has mandated vegetarianism in all his monasteries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502"><a href="#cite_note-502">[457]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Buddhist_texts">Buddhist texts</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_texts" title="Buddhist texts">Buddhist texts</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nava_Jetavana_Temple_-_Shravasti_-_013_First_Council_at_Rajagaha_(9241729223).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1977" data-file-width="3399" decoding="async" height="128" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Nava_Jetavana_Temple_-_Shravasti_-_013_First_Council_at_Rajagaha_%289241729223%29.jpg/220px-Nava_Jetavana_Temple_-_Shravasti_-_013_First_Council_at_Rajagaha_%289241729223%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Nava_Jetavana_Temple_-_Shravasti_-_013_First_Council_at_Rajagaha_%289241729223%29.jpg/330px-Nava_Jetavana_Temple_-_Shravasti_-_013_First_Council_at_Rajagaha_%289241729223%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Nava_Jetavana_Temple_-_Shravasti_-_013_First_Council_at_Rajagaha_%289241729223%29.jpg/440px-Nava_Jetavana_Temple_-_Shravasti_-_013_First_Council_at_Rajagaha_%289241729223%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nava_Jetavana_Temple_-_Shravasti_-_013_First_Council_at_Rajagaha_(9241729223).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A depiction of the supposed <a href="/wiki/First_Buddhist_council" title="First Buddhist council">First Buddhist council</a> at <a href="/wiki/Rajgir" title="Rajgir">Rajgir</a>. Communal recitation was one of the original ways of transmitting and preserving Early Buddhist texts.</div></div></div>
<p>Buddhism, like all Indian religions, was initially an <a href="/wiki/Oral_tradition" title="Oral tradition">oral tradition</a> in ancient times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lopez2004busc1_503-0"><a href="#cite_note-lopez2004busc1-503">[458]</a></sup> The Buddha's words, the early doctrines, concepts, and their traditional interpretations were orally transmitted from one generation to the next. The earliest oral texts were transmitted in Middle <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_languages" title="Indo-Aryan languages">Indo-Aryan languages</a> called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prakrits" title="Prakrits">Prakrits</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Pali" title="Pali">Pali</a>, through the use of communal recitation and other <a href="/wiki/Mnemonic" title="Mnemonic">mnemonic</a> techniques.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199839–41_504-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199839–41-504">[459]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first Buddhist canonical texts were likely written down in Sri Lanka, about 400 years after the Buddha died.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lopez2004busc1_503-1"><a href="#cite_note-lopez2004busc1-503">[458]</a></sup> The texts were part of the <i><a href="/wiki/Tripi%E1%B9%ADaka" title="Tripiṭaka">Tripitakas</a></i>, and many versions appeared thereafter claiming to be the words of the Buddha. Scholarly Buddhist commentary texts, with named authors, appeared in India, around the 2nd century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lopez2004busc1_503-2"><a href="#cite_note-lopez2004busc1-503">[458]</a></sup> These texts were written in Pali or Sanskrit, sometimes regional languages, as <a href="/wiki/Palm-leaf_manuscript" title="Palm-leaf manuscript">palm-leaf manuscripts</a>, birch bark, painted scrolls, carved into temple walls, and later on paper.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lopez2004busc1_503-3"><a href="#cite_note-lopez2004busc1-503">[458]</a></sup>
</p><p>Unlike what the <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Bible</a> is to <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a> is to <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, but like all major ancient Indian religions, there is no consensus among the different Buddhist traditions as to what constitutes the scriptures or a common canon in Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lopez2004busc1_503-4"><a href="#cite_note-lopez2004busc1-503">[458]</a></sup> The general belief among Buddhists is that the canonical corpus is vast.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505"><a href="#cite_note-505">[460]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin2008xiv_506-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin2008xiv-506">[461]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEliot193516_507-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEliot193516-507">[462]</a></sup> This corpus includes the ancient <i>Sutras</i> organised into <i><a href="/wiki/Nik%C4%81ya" title="Nikāya">Nikayas</a></i> or <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%80gama_(Buddhism)" title="Āgama (Buddhism)">Agamas</a></i>, itself the part of three basket of texts called the <i>Tripitakas</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508"><a href="#cite_note-508">[463]</a></sup> Each Buddhist tradition has its own collection of texts, much of which is translation of ancient Pali and Sanskrit Buddhist texts of India. The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Buddhist_canon" title="Chinese Buddhist canon">Chinese Buddhist canon</a>, for example, includes 2184 texts in 55 volumes, while the <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhist_canon" title="Tibetan Buddhist canon">Tibetan canon</a> comprises 1108 texts – all claimed to have been spoken by the Buddha – and another 3461 texts composed by Indian scholars revered in the Tibetan tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lopez2004busc2_509-0"><a href="#cite_note-lopez2004busc2-509">[464]</a></sup> The Buddhist textual history is vast; over 40,000 manuscripts – mostly Buddhist, some non-Buddhist – were discovered in 1900 in the Dunhuang Chinese cave alone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lopez2004busc2_509-1"><a href="#cite_note-lopez2004busc2-509">[464]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Buddhist_texts">Early Buddhist texts</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_Buddhist_Texts" title="Early Buddhist Texts">Early Buddhist Texts</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fragmentary_Buddhist_text_-_Gandhara_birchbark_scrolls_(1st_C),_part_31_-_BL_Or._14915.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1280" data-file-width="1920" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Fragmentary_Buddhist_text_-_Gandhara_birchbark_scrolls_%281st_C%29%2C_part_31_-_BL_Or._14915.jpg/220px-Fragmentary_Buddhist_text_-_Gandhara_birchbark_scrolls_%281st_C%29%2C_part_31_-_BL_Or._14915.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Fragmentary_Buddhist_text_-_Gandhara_birchbark_scrolls_%281st_C%29%2C_part_31_-_BL_Or._14915.jpg/330px-Fragmentary_Buddhist_text_-_Gandhara_birchbark_scrolls_%281st_C%29%2C_part_31_-_BL_Or._14915.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Fragmentary_Buddhist_text_-_Gandhara_birchbark_scrolls_%281st_C%29%2C_part_31_-_BL_Or._14915.jpg/440px-Fragmentary_Buddhist_text_-_Gandhara_birchbark_scrolls_%281st_C%29%2C_part_31_-_BL_Or._14915.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fragmentary_Buddhist_text_-_Gandhara_birchbark_scrolls_(1st_C),_part_31_-_BL_Or._14915.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhara birchbark scroll fragments (c. 1st century) from British Library Collection</div></div></div><p>
The Early Buddhist Texts refers to the literature which is considered by modern scholars to be the earliest Buddhist material. The first four <a href="/wiki/Pali" title="Pali">Pali</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nikayas" title="Nikayas">Nikayas</a>, and the corresponding Chinese <a href="/wiki/%C4%80gama_(Buddhism)" title="Āgama (Buddhism)">Āgamas</a> are generally considered to be among the earliest material.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199842–43_510-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199842–43-510">[465]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESujatoBrahmali20159–10_511-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESujatoBrahmali20159–10-511">[466]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-512"><a href="#cite_note-512">[467]</a></sup> Apart from these, there are also fragmentary collections of EBT materials in other languages such as <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saka_language" title="Saka language">Khotanese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Classical_Tibetan" title="Classical Tibetan">Tibetan</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G%C4%81ndh%C4%81r%C4%AB_language" title="Gāndhārī language">Gāndhārī</a>. The modern study of <a href="/wiki/Pre-sectarian_Buddhism" title="Pre-sectarian Buddhism">early Buddhism</a> often relies on comparative scholarship using these various early Buddhist sources to identify parallel texts and common doctrinal content.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-513"><a href="#cite_note-513">[468]</a></sup> One feature of these early texts are literary structures which reflect oral transmission, such as widespread repetition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-514"><a href="#cite_note-514">[469]</a></sup><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1045330069" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></p><table class="sidebar nomobile nowraplinks" style="text-align: centre;"><tbody><tr><th class="sidebar-title" style="padding: 0.4em 0;background:#ccccff;"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/P%C4%81li_Canon" title="Pāli Canon">Pāli Canon</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-image"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Illustrated_Sinhalese_covers_(inside)_showing_the_events_Wellcome_L0031774.jpg"><img alt="Illustrated Sinhalese covers (inside) showing the events Wellcome L0031774.jpg" data-file-height="2652" data-file-width="4254" decoding="async" height="94" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Illustrated_Sinhalese_covers_%28inside%29_showing_the_events_Wellcome_L0031774.jpg/150px-Illustrated_Sinhalese_covers_%28inside%29_showing_the_events_Wellcome_L0031774.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Illustrated_Sinhalese_covers_%28inside%29_showing_the_events_Wellcome_L0031774.jpg/225px-Illustrated_Sinhalese_covers_%28inside%29_showing_the_events_Wellcome_L0031774.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Illustrated_Sinhalese_covers_%28inside%29_showing_the_events_Wellcome_L0031774.jpg/300px-Illustrated_Sinhalese_covers_%28inside%29_showing_the_events_Wellcome_L0031774.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a></td></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="background:#ddddff; </div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:PaliCanon" title="Template:PaliCanon"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:PaliCanon" title="Template talk:PaliCanon"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:PaliCanon&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Tripitakas">The Tripitakas</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Tripi%E1%B9%ADaka" title="Tripiṭaka">Tripiṭaka</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pali_Canon" title="Pali Canon">Pali Canon</a></div>
<p>After the development of the different <a href="/wiki/Early_Buddhist_schools" title="Early Buddhist schools">early Buddhist schools</a>, these schools began to develop their own textual collections, which were termed <i>Tripiṭakas</i> (Triple Baskets).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarder2000282–283_515-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarder2000282–283-515">[470]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many early <i>Tripiṭakas</i>, like the Pāli <i>Tipitaka</i>, were divided into three sections: <i><a href="/wiki/Vinaya" title="Vinaya">Vinaya Pitaka</a></i> (focuses on <a href="/wiki/Monasticism" title="Monasticism">monastic rule</a>), <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sutta_Pitaka" title="Sutta Pitaka">Sutta Pitaka</a></i> (Buddhist discourses) and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abhidhamma" title="Abhidhamma">Abhidhamma Pitaka</a>,</i> which contain expositions and commentaries on the doctrine.
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/P%C4%81li_Canon" title="Pāli Canon">Pāli <i>Tipitaka</i></a> (also known as the Pali Canon) of the Theravada School constitutes the only complete collection of Buddhist texts in an <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_languages" title="Indo-Aryan languages">Indic language</a> which has survived until today.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-516"><a href="#cite_note-516">[471]</a></sup> However, many <i>Sutras</i>, <i>Vinayas</i> and <i>Abhidharma</i> works from other schools survive in Chinese translation, as part of the Chinese Buddhist Canon. According to some sources, some early schools of Buddhism had five or seven <i>pitakas</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESkilling1992114_517-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESkilling1992114-517">[472]</a></sup>
</p><p>Much of the material in the <a href="/wiki/Pali_Canon" title="Pali Canon">Pali Canon</a> is not specifically "Theravadin", but is instead the collection of teachings that this school preserved from the early, non-sectarian body of teachings. According to Peter Harvey, it contains material at odds with later Theravadin orthodoxy. He states: "The Theravadins, then, may have <i>added</i> texts to the Canon for some time, but they do not appear to have tampered with what they already had from an earlier period."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey19959_518-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey19959-518">[473]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Abhidharma_and_the_commentaries">Abhidharma and the commentaries</span></h3>
<p>A distinctive feature of many Tripitaka collections is the inclusion of a genre called <a href="/wiki/Abhidharma" title="Abhidharma">Abhidharma</a>, which dates from the 3rd century BCE and later. According to Collett Cox, the genre began as explanations and elaborations of the teachings in the suttas but over time evolved into an independent system of doctrinal exposition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-519"><a href="#cite_note-519">[474]</a></sup>
</p><p>Over time, the various Abhidharma traditions developed various disagreements which each other on points of doctrine, which were discussed in the different Abhidharma texts of these schools.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199854–55_56-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199854–55-56">[51]</a></sup> The major Abhidharma collections which modern scholars have the most information about are those of the <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravāda</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sarvastivada" title="Sarvastivada">Sarvāstivāda</a> schools.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199848_520-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199848-520">[475]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Sri Lanka and South India, the <a href="/wiki/Therav%C4%81da_Abhidhamma" title="Theravāda Abhidhamma">Theravāda Abhidhamma</a> system was the most influential. In addition to the Abhidharma project, some of the schools also began accumulating a literary tradition of scriptural commentary on their respective Tripitakas. These commentaries were particularly important in the <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravāda</a> school, and the Pali commentaries (<i><a href="/wiki/Atthakatha" title="Atthakatha">Aṭṭhakathā</a></i>) remain influential today. Both Abhidhamma and the Pali commentaries influenced the <i><a href="/wiki/Visuddhimagga" title="Visuddhimagga">Visuddhimagga</a>,</i> an important 5th-century text by the Theravada scholar <a href="/wiki/Buddhaghosa" title="Buddhaghosa">Buddhaghosa</a>, who also translated and compiled many of the <i>Aṭṭhakathās</i> from older Sinhalese sources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521"><a href="#cite_note-521">[476]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199855_522-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199855-522">[477]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Sarvastivada" title="Sarvastivada">Sarvāstivāda</a> school was one of the most influential Abhidharma traditions in North India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-523"><a href="#cite_note-523">[478]</a></sup> The magnum opus of this tradition was the massive Abhidharma commentary called the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mahavibhasa" title="Mahavibhasa"><i>Mahāvibhaṣa</i></a> ('Great Commentary'), compiled at a great synod in Kashmir during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Kanishka_II" title="Kanishka II">Kanishka II</a> (c. 158–176).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-524"><a href="#cite_note-524">[479]</a></sup> The <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abhidharmako%C5%9Bak%C4%81rik%C4%81" title="Abhidharmakośakārikā">Abhidharmakosha</a></i> of <a href="/wiki/Vasubandhu" title="Vasubandhu">Vasubandhu</a> is another very influential Abhidharma work from the northern tradition, which continues to be studied in <a href="/wiki/East_Asian_Buddhism" title="East Asian Buddhism">East Asian Buddhism</a> and in Tibetan Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199856_525-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199856-525">[480]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Mah.C4.81y.C4.81na_texts"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Mahāyāna_texts">Mahāyāna texts</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mahayana_sutras" title="Mahayana sutras">Mahayana sutras</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg"><img alt="Tripiṭaka Koreana in South Korea, over 81,000 wood printing blocks stored in racks" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg/220px-Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg/330px-Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg/440px-Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Tripitaka_Koreana" title="Tripitaka Koreana">Tripiṭaka Koreana</a> in South Korea, an edition of the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Buddhist_canon" title="Chinese Buddhist canon">Chinese Buddhist canon</a> carved and preserved in over 81,000 wood printing blocks</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Mahayana_sutras" title="Mahayana sutras">Mahāyāna sūtras</a> are a very broad genre of Buddhist scriptures that the <a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahāyāna</a> Buddhist tradition holds are original teachings of <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">the Buddha</a>. Modern historians generally hold that the first of these texts were composed probably around the 1st century BCE or 1st century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Buddhism_2004,_page_293_526-0"><a href="#cite_note-Buddhism_2004,_page_293-526">[481]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993252_527-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993252-527">[482]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004494_528-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004494-528">[483]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Mahāyāna, these texts are generally given greater authority than the early Āgamas and Abhidharma literature, which are called "<a href="/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C4%81vakay%C4%81na" title="Śrāvakayāna">Śrāvakayāna</a>" or "<a href="/wiki/Hinayana" title="Hinayana">Hinayana</a>" to distinguish them from Mahāyāna sūtras.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-529"><a href="#cite_note-529">[484]</a></sup> Mahāyāna traditions mainly see these different classes of texts as being designed for different types of persons, with different levels of spiritual understanding. The Mahāyāna sūtras are mainly seen as being for those of "greater" capacity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-530"><a href="#cite_note-530">[485]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="this claim needs a non-sectarian source (September 2019)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The Mahāyāna sūtras often claim to articulate the Buddha's deeper, more advanced doctrines, reserved for those who follow the <a href="/wiki/Bodhisattva" title="Bodhisattva">bodhisattva</a> path.
