That path is explained as being built upon the motivation to liberate all living beings from unhappiness. Hence the name <i>Mahāyāna</i> (lit., <i>the Great Vehicle</i>). Besides the teaching of the bodhisattva, Mahāyāna texts also contain expanded cosmologies and mythologies, with many more Buddhas and powerful bodhisattvas, as well as new spiritual practices and ideas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-531"><a href="#cite_note-531">[486]</a></sup>
</p><p>The modern Theravada school does not treat the Mahāyāna sūtras as authoritative or authentic teachings of the Buddha.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPowers2007111_532-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPowers2007111-532">[487]</a></sup> Likewise, these texts were not recognized as authoritative by many early Buddhist schools and in some cases, communities such as the <a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81s%C4%81%E1%B9%83ghika" title="Mahāsāṃghika">Mahāsāṃghika</a> school split up due to this disagreement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533"><a href="#cite_note-533">[488]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Konchog-wangdu.jpeg"><img alt="Buddhist monk Geshe Konchog Wangdu in red robe reads Mahayana sutras on stand" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="250" data-file-width="224" decoding="async" height="190" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Konchog-wangdu.jpeg/170px-Konchog-wangdu.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f5/Konchog-wangdu.jpeg 1.5x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Konchog-wangdu.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Buddhist monk Geshe Konchog Wangdu reads Mahayana sutras from an old woodblock copy of the Tibetan Kanjur.</div></div></div>
<p>Recent scholarship has discovered many early Mahāyāna texts which shed light into the development of Mahāyāna. Among these is the <i><a href="/wiki/Salistamba_Sutra" title="Salistamba Sutra">Śālistamba Sutra</a></i> which survives in Tibetan and Chinese translation. This text contains numerous sections which are remarkably similar to Pali suttas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-karlpotter1996p26_534-0"><a href="#cite_note-karlpotter1996p26-534">[489]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-535"><a href="#cite_note-535">[490]</a></sup> The <i>Śālistamba Sutra</i> was cited by Mahāyāna scholars such as the 8th-century Yasomitra to be authoritative.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-536"><a href="#cite_note-536">[491]</a></sup> This suggests that Buddhist literature of different traditions shared a common core of Buddhist texts in the early centuries of its history, until Mahāyāna literature diverged about and after the 1st century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-karlpotter1996p26_534-1"><a href="#cite_note-karlpotter1996p26-534">[489]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mahāyāna also has a very large literature of philosophical and exegetical texts. These are often called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shastras" title="Shastras"><i>śāstra</i></a> (treatises) or <i>vrittis</i> (commentaries). Some of this literature was also written in verse form (<i>karikās</i>), the most famous of which is the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mulamadhyamakakarika" title="Mulamadhyamakakarika">Mūlamadhyamika-karikā</a></i> (Root Verses on the Middle Way) by <a href="/wiki/Nagarjuna" title="Nagarjuna">Nagarjuna</a>, the foundational text of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Madhyamika" title="Madhyamika">Madhyamika</a> school.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tantric_texts">Tantric texts</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tantras_(Buddhism)" title="Tantras (Buddhism)">Tantras (Buddhism)</a></div><p>During the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empire</a>, a new class of Buddhist sacred literature began to develop, which are called the <a href="/wiki/Tantras_(Buddhism)" title="Tantras (Buddhism)">Tantras</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-537"><a href="#cite_note-537">[492]</a></sup> By the 8th century, the tantric tradition was very influential in India and beyond. Besides drawing on a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81y%C4%81na" title="Mahāyāna">Mahāyāna</a> Buddhist framework, these texts also borrowed deities and material from other Indian religious traditions, such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C5%9Aaiva" title="Śaiva">Śaiva</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pancharatra" title="Pancharatra">Pancharatra</a> traditions, local god/goddess cults, and local spirit worship (such as <a href="/wiki/Yaksha" title="Yaksha">yaksha</a> or <a href="/wiki/N%C4%81ga" title="Nāga">nāga</a> spirits).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-538"><a href="#cite_note-538">[493]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-539"><a href="#cite_note-539">[494]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some features of these texts include the widespread use of mantras, meditation on the <a href="/wiki/Lung_(Tibetan_Buddhism)#Subtle_Body" title="Lung (Tibetan Buddhism)">subtle body</a>, worship of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fierce_deities" title="Fierce deities">fierce deities</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Antinomian" title="Antinomian">antinomian</a> and <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/transgressive" title="wikt:transgressive">transgressive</a> practices such as ingesting <a href="/wiki/Alcohol_(drug)" title="Alcohol (drug)">alcohol</a> and performing sexual rituals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliamsTribeWynne2012chapter_7_540-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliamsTribeWynne2012chapter_7-540">[495]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-541"><a href="#cite_note-541">[496]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-542"><a href="#cite_note-542">[497]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Buddhism" title="History of Buddhism">History of Buddhism</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Buddhism" title="Timeline of Buddhism">Timeline of Buddhism</a>.</div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mah%C4%81k%C4%81%C5%9Byapa_meets_an_%C4%80j%C4%ABvika_and_learns_of_the_parinirvana,_Gandhara_sculpture_2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1777" data-file-width="1115" decoding="async" height="271" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Mah%C4%81k%C4%81%C5%9Byapa_meets_an_%C4%80j%C4%ABvika_and_learns_of_the_parinirvana%2C_Gandhara_sculpture_2.jpg/170px-Mah%C4%81k%C4%81%C5%9Byapa_meets_an_%C4%80j%C4%ABvika_and_learns_of_the_parinirvana%2C_Gandhara_sculpture_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Mah%C4%81k%C4%81%C5%9Byapa_meets_an_%C4%80j%C4%ABvika_and_learns_of_the_parinirvana%2C_Gandhara_sculpture_2.jpg/255px-Mah%C4%81k%C4%81%C5%9Byapa_meets_an_%C4%80j%C4%ABvika_and_learns_of_the_parinirvana%2C_Gandhara_sculpture_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Mah%C4%81k%C4%81%C5%9Byapa_meets_an_%C4%80j%C4%ABvika_and_learns_of_the_parinirvana%2C_Gandhara_sculpture_2.jpg/340px-Mah%C4%81k%C4%81%C5%9Byapa_meets_an_%C4%80j%C4%ABvika_and_learns_of_the_parinirvana%2C_Gandhara_sculpture_2.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mah%C4%81k%C4%81%C5%9Byapa_meets_an_%C4%80j%C4%ABvika_and_learns_of_the_parinirvana,_Gandhara_sculpture_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81k%C4%81%C5%9Byapa" title="Mahākāśyapa">Mahākāśyapa</a> meets an <a href="/wiki/%C4%80j%C4%ABvika" title="Ājīvika">Ājīvika</a> ascetic, one of the common Śramaṇa groups in ancient India</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Historical_roots">Historical roots</span></h3>
<p>Historically, the roots of Buddhism lie in the religious thought of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iron_Age_India" title="Iron Age India">Iron Age India</a> around the middle of the first millennium BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin2008xv_543-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin2008xv-543">[498]</a></sup> This was a period of great intellectual ferment and socio-cultural change known as the <a href="/wiki/History_of_India#Sramanic_period_–_second_urbanisation_(600–200_BCE)" title="History of India">"Second urbanisation"</a>, marked by the growth of towns and trade, the composition of the <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a> and the historical emergence of the <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Arama%E1%B9%87a" title="Śramaṇa">Śramaṇa</a> traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-544"><a href="#cite_note-544">[499]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198826–41_545-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198826–41-545">[500]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-548"><a href="#cite_note-548">[note 38]</a></sup>
</p><p>New ideas developed both in the <a href="/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion" title="Historical Vedic religion">Vedic tradition</a> in the form of the Upanishads, and outside of the Vedic tradition through the Śramaṇa movements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-549"><a href="#cite_note-549">[503]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-550"><a href="#cite_note-550">[504]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Olivelle1992_551-0"><a href="#cite_note-Olivelle1992-551">[505]</a></sup> The term Śramaṇa refers to several Indian religious movements parallel to but separate from the <a href="/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion" title="Historical Vedic religion">historical Vedic religion</a>, including Buddhism, <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a> and others such as <a href="/wiki/%C4%80j%C4%ABvika" title="Ājīvika">Ājīvika</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-552"><a href="#cite_note-552">[506]</a></sup>
</p><p>Several Śramaṇa movements are known to have existed in India before the 6th century BCE (pre-Buddha, pre-<a href="/wiki/Mahavira" title="Mahavira">Mahavira</a>), and these influenced both the <a href="/wiki/%C4%80stika_and_n%C4%81stika" title="Āstika and nāstika">āstika and nāstika</a> traditions of <a href="/wiki/Indian_philosophy" title="Indian philosophy">Indian philosophy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reginaldray247_553-0"><a href="#cite_note-reginaldray247-553">[507]</a></sup> According to Martin Wilshire, the Śramaṇa tradition evolved in India over two phases, namely <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pratyekabuddha" title="Pratyekabuddha">Paccekabuddha</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C4%81vaka" title="Śrāvaka">Savaka</a> phases, the former being the tradition of individual ascetic and the latter of disciples, and that Buddhism and <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a> ultimately emerged from these.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wiltshire293_554-0"><a href="#cite_note-wiltshire293-554">[508]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion" title="Historical Vedic religion">Brahmanical</a> and non-Brahmanical ascetic groups shared and used several similar ideas,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2010123–125_555-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2010123–125-555">[509]</a></sup> but the Śramaṇa traditions also drew upon already established Brahmanical concepts and philosophical roots, states Wiltshire, to formulate their own doctrines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reginaldray247_553-1"><a href="#cite_note-reginaldray247-553">[507]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wiltshire226_556-0"><a href="#cite_note-wiltshire226-556">[510]</a></sup> Brahmanical motifs can be found in the oldest Buddhist texts, using them to introduce and explain Buddhist ideas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShults2014126_557-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShults2014126-557">[511]</a></sup> For example, prior to Buddhist developments, the Brahmanical tradition internalised and variously reinterpreted the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Srauta" title="Srauta">three Vedic sacrificial fires</a> as concepts such as Truth, Rite, Tranquility or Restraint.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShults2014127_558-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShults2014127-558">[512]</a></sup> Buddhist texts also refer to the three Vedic sacrificial fires, reinterpreting and explaining them as ethical conduct.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShults2014125–129_559-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShults2014125–129-559">[513]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Śramaṇa religions challenged and broke with the Brahmanic tradition on core assumptions such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atman_(Hinduism)" title="Atman (Hinduism)">Atman</a> (soul, self), <a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">Brahman</a>, the nature of afterlife, and they rejected the authority of the <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedas</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Upanishad" title="Upanishad">Upanishads</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-560"><a href="#cite_note-560">[514]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJaini200147–48_561-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJaini200147–48-561">[515]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Siderits2007p16_562-0"><a href="#cite_note-Siderits2007p16-562">[516]</a></sup> Buddhism was one among several Indian religions that did so.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Siderits2007p16_562-1"><a href="#cite_note-Siderits2007p16-562">[516]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Indian_Buddhism">Indian Buddhism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Buddhism_in_India" title="History of Buddhism in India">History of Buddhism in India</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ajanta_Chaitya_10_plan.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2192" data-file-width="1871" decoding="async" height="258" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Ajanta_Chaitya_10_plan.jpg/220px-Ajanta_Chaitya_10_plan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Ajanta_Chaitya_10_plan.jpg/330px-Ajanta_Chaitya_10_plan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Ajanta_Chaitya_10_plan.jpg/440px-Ajanta_Chaitya_10_plan.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ajanta_Chaitya_10_plan.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ajanta_Caves" title="Ajanta Caves">Ajanta Caves</a>, Cave 10, a first period type <a href="/wiki/Chaitya" title="Chaitya">chaitya</a> worship hall with <a href="/wiki/Stupa" title="Stupa">stupa</a> but no idols</div></div></div>
<p>The history of Indian Buddhism may be divided into five periods:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa19937_563-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa19937-563">[517]</a></sup> Early Buddhism (occasionally called <a href="/wiki/Pre-sectarian_Buddhism" title="Pre-sectarian Buddhism">pre-sectarian Buddhism</a>), <a href="/wiki/Nikaya_Buddhism" title="Nikaya Buddhism">Nikaya Buddhism</a> or Sectarian Buddhism: The period of the early Buddhist schools, Early <a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahayana Buddhism</a>, Late Mahayana, and the era of <a href="/wiki/Vajrayana" title="Vajrayana">Vajrayana</a> or the "Tantric Age".
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-sectarian_Buddhism">Pre-sectarian Buddhism</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Pre-sectarian_Buddhism" title="Pre-sectarian Buddhism">Pre-sectarian Buddhism</a></div>
<p>According to <a href="/wiki/Lambert_Schmithausen" title="Lambert Schmithausen">Lambert Schmithausen</a> Pre-sectarian Buddhism is "the canonical period prior to the development of different schools with their different positions."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-564"><a href="#cite_note-564">[518]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_Buddhist_Texts" title="Early Buddhist Texts">early Buddhist Texts</a> include the four principal Pali <a href="/wiki/Nik%C4%81ya" title="Nikāya">Nikāyas</a> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-565"><a href="#cite_note-565">[note 39]</a></sup> (and their parallel <a href="/wiki/%C4%80gama_(Buddhism)" title="Āgama (Buddhism)">Agamas</a> found in the Chinese canon) together with the main body of monastic rules, which survive in the various versions of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Patimokkha" title="Patimokkha">patimokkha</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESujatoBrahmali201539–41_566-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESujatoBrahmali201539–41-566">[519]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin2008xviii_567-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin2008xviii-567">[520]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey19983_568-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey19983-568">[521]</a></sup> However, these texts were revised over time, and it is unclear what constitutes the earliest layer of Buddhist teachings. One method to obtain information on the oldest core of Buddhism is to compare the oldest extant versions of the Theravadin Pāli Canon and other texts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-571"><a href="#cite_note-571">[note 40]</a></sup> The reliability of the early sources, and the possibility to draw out a core of oldest teachings, is a matter of dispute.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi–xxxvii_572-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi–xxxvii-572">[524]</a></sup> According to Vetter, inconsistencies remain, and other methods must be applied to resolve those inconsistencies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988ix_569-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988ix-569">[522]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-577"><a href="#cite_note-577">[note 41]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Schmithausen, three positions held by scholars of Buddhism can be distinguished:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993vii_578-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993vii-578">[529]</a></sup>
</p>
<ol><li>"Stress on the fundamental homogeneity and substantial authenticity of at least a considerable part of the Nikayic materials;"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-583"><a href="#cite_note-583">[note 42]</a></sup></li>
<li>"Scepticism with regard to the possibility of retrieving the doctrine of earliest Buddhism;"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-586"><a href="#cite_note-586">[note 43]</a></sup></li>
<li>"Cautious optimism in this respect."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-593"><a href="#cite_note-593">[note 44]</a></sup></li></ol>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Core_teachings">The Core teachings</span></h5>
<p>According to Mitchell, certain basic teachings appear in many places throughout the early texts, which has led most scholars to conclude that Gautama Buddha must have taught something similar to the <a href="/wiki/Four_Noble_Truths" title="Four Noble Truths">Four Noble Truths</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Noble_Eightfold_Path" title="Noble Eightfold Path">Noble Eightfold Path</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nirvana_(Buddhism)" title="Nirvana (Buddhism)">Nirvana</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Three_marks_of_existence" title="Three marks of existence">three marks of existence</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Skandha" title="Skandha">five aggregates</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prat%C4%ABtyasamutp%C4%81da" title="Pratītyasamutpāda">dependent origination</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karma_in_Buddhism" title="Karma in Buddhism">karma</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rebirth_(Buddhism)" title="Rebirth (Buddhism)">rebirth</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMitchell200234_594-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMitchell200234-594">[536]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to N. Ross Reat, all of these doctrines are shared by the Theravada Pali texts and the Mahasamghika school's <i><a href="/wiki/Salistamba_Sutra" title="Salistamba Sutra">Śālistamba Sūtra</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-595"><a href="#cite_note-595">[537]</a></sup> A recent study by Bhikkhu Analayo concludes that the Theravada <i><a href="/wiki/Majjhima_Nik%C4%81ya" title="Majjhima Nikāya">Majjhima Nikaya</a></i> and Sarvastivada <i><a href="/wiki/Madhyama_Agama" title="Madhyama Agama">Madhyama Agama</a></i> contain mostly the same major doctrines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-596"><a href="#cite_note-596">[538]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Richard_G._Salomon_(professor_of_Asian_studies)" title="Richard G. Salomon (professor of Asian studies)">Richard Salomon</a>, in his study of the <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Gandharan_texts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Gandharan texts (page does not exist)">Gandharan texts</a> (which are the earliest manuscripts containing early discourses), has confirmed that their teachings are "consistent with non-Mahayana Buddhism, which survives today in the Theravada school of Sri Lanka and Southeast Asia, but which in ancient times was represented by eighteen separate schools."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-597"><a href="#cite_note-597">[539]</a></sup>
</p><p>However, some scholars argue that critical analysis reveals discrepancies among the various doctrines found in these early texts, which point to alternative possibilities for early Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESkorupski19905_598-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESkorupski19905-598">[540]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst19984,_11_599-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst19984,_11-599">[541]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchopen2002_600-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchopen2002-600">[542]</a></sup> The authenticity of certain teachings and doctrines have been questioned. For example, some scholars think that karma was not central to the teaching of the historical Buddha, while other disagree with this position.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMatthews1986124_601-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMatthews1986124-601">[543]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199814_602-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199814-602">[544]</a></sup> Likewise, there is scholarly disagreement on whether insight was seen as liberating in early Buddhism or whether it was a later addition to the practice of the four <i>jhānas</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchmithausen1981_573-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmithausen1981-573">[525]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199377–78,_Section_8.4.3_603-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199377–78,_Section_8.4.3-603">[545]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter19885,_Quote:_[T]hey_do_not_teach_that_one_is_released_by_knowing_the_four_noble_truths,_but_by_practising_the_fourth_noble_truth,_the_eightfold_path,_which_culminates_in_right_samadhi_604-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter19885,_Quote:_[T]hey_do_not_teach_that_one_is_released_by_knowing_the_four_noble_truths,_but_by_practising_the_fourth_noble_truth,_the_eightfold_path,_which_culminates_in_right_samadhi-604">[546]</a></sup> Scholars such as Bronkhorst also think that the four noble truths may not have been formulated in earliest Buddhism, and did not serve in earliest Buddhism as a description of "liberating insight".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993107_605-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993107-605">[547]</a></sup> According to Vetter, the description of the Buddhist path may initially have been as simple as the term "the middle way".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988_173-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988-173">[147]</a></sup> In time, this short description was elaborated, resulting in the description of the eightfold path.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988_173-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988-173">[147]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Ashokan_Era_and_the_early_schools">Ashokan Era and the early schools</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Early_Buddhist_schools" title="Early Buddhist schools">Early Buddhist schools</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_councils" title="Buddhist councils">Buddhist councils</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sanchi_Stupa_No_3.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3073" data-file-width="4609" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Sanchi_Stupa_No_3.jpg/220px-Sanchi_Stupa_No_3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Sanchi_Stupa_No_3.jpg/330px-Sanchi_Stupa_No_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Sanchi_Stupa_No_3.jpg/440px-Sanchi_Stupa_No_3.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sanchi_Stupa_No_3.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sanchi" title="Sanchi">Sanchi</a> Stupa No. 3, near <a href="/wiki/Vidisha" title="Vidisha">Vidisha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madhya_Pradesh" title="Madhya Pradesh">Madhya Pradesh</a>, India</div></div></div>
<p>According to numerous Buddhist scriptures, soon after the <a href="/wiki/Parinirvana" title="Parinirvana"><span title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration"><i lang="sa-Latn">parinirvāṇa</i></span></a> (from Sanskrit: "highest extinguishment") of Gautama Buddha, the <a href="/wiki/First_Buddhist_council" title="First Buddhist council">first Buddhist council</a> was held to collectively recite the teachings to ensure that no errors occurred in oral transmission. Many modern scholars question the historicity of this event.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201388–90_606-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201388–90-606">[548]</a></sup> However, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Gombrich" title="Richard Gombrich">Richard Gombrich</a> states that the monastic assembly recitations of the Buddha's teaching likely began during Buddha's lifetime, and they served a similar role of codifying the teachings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams2005175–176_607-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams2005175–176-607">[549]</a></sup>
</p><p>The so called <a href="/wiki/Second_Buddhist_council" title="Second Buddhist council">Second Buddhist council</a> resulted in the first schism in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sangha_(Buddhism)" title="Sangha (Buddhism)">Sangha</a>. Modern scholars believe that this was probably caused when a group of reformists called <a href="/wiki/Sthavira_nik%C4%81ya" title="Sthavira nikāya">Sthaviras</a> ("elders") sought to modify the Vinaya (monastic rule), and this caused a split with the conservatives who rejected this change, they were called <a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81s%C4%81%E1%B9%83ghika" title="Mahāsāṃghika">Mahāsāṃghikas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201389–90_608-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201389–90-608">[550]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-609"><a href="#cite_note-609">[551]</a></sup> While most scholars accept that this happened at some point, there is no agreement on the dating, especially if it dates to before or after the reign of Ashoka.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-610"><a href="#cite_note-610">[552]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Asoka%CC%A0_Buddhist_Missions.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1284" data-file-width="1252" decoding="async" height="226" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Asoka%CC%A0_Buddhist_Missions.png/220px-Asoka%CC%A0_Buddhist_Missions.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Asoka%CC%A0_Buddhist_Missions.png/330px-Asoka%CC%A0_Buddhist_Missions.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Asoka%CC%A0_Buddhist_Missions.png/440px-Asoka%CC%A0_Buddhist_Missions.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Asoka%CC%A0_Buddhist_Missions.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of the Buddhist missions during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Ashoka" title="Ashoka">Ashoka</a> according to the Edicts of Ashoka</div></div></div>
<p>Buddhism may have spread only slowly throughout India until the time of the <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">Mauryan</a> emperor <a href="/wiki/Ashoka" title="Ashoka">Ashoka</a> (304–232 BCE), who was a public supporter of the religion. The support of Aśoka and his descendants led to the construction of more <a href="/wiki/Stupa" title="Stupa">stūpas</a> (such as at <a href="/wiki/Sanchi" title="Sanchi">Sanchi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bharhut" title="Bharhut">Bharhut</a>), temples (such as the <a href="/wiki/Mahabodhi_Temple" title="Mahabodhi Temple">Mahabodhi Temple</a>) and to its spread throughout the Maurya Empire and into neighbouring lands such as <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a> and to the island of <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a>.
</p><p>During and after the Mauryan period (322–180 BCE), the Sthavira community gave rise to several schools, one of which was the <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a> school which tended to congregate in the south and another which was the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sarv%C4%81stiv%C4%81da" title="Sarvāstivāda">Sarvāstivāda</a> school, which was mainly in north India. Likewise, the <a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81s%C4%81%E1%B9%83ghika" title="Mahāsāṃghika">Mahāsāṃghika</a> groups also eventually split into different Sanghas. Originally, these schisms were caused by disputes over monastic disciplinary codes of various fraternities, but eventually, by about 100 CE if not earlier, schisms were being caused by doctrinal disagreements too.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey199874–75_611-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey199874–75-611">[553]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following (or leading up to) the schisms, each Saṅgha started to accumulate their own version of <a href="/wiki/Tripi%E1%B9%ADaka" title="Tripiṭaka">Tripiṭaka</a> (triple basket of texts).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britannicatipitaka_58-1"><a href="#cite_note-britannicatipitaka-58">[53]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Crandall2012p56_612-0"><a href="#cite_note-Crandall2012p56-612">[554]</a></sup> In their Tripiṭaka, each school included the Suttas of the Buddha, a Vinaya basket (disciplinary code) and some schools also added an <a href="/wiki/Abhidharma" title="Abhidharma">Abhidharma</a> basket which were texts on detailed scholastic classification, summary and interpretation of the Suttas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britannicatipitaka_58-2"><a href="#cite_note-britannicatipitaka-58">[53]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201390–91_613-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201390–91-613">[555]</a></sup> The doctrine details in the Abhidharmas of various Buddhist schools differ significantly, and these were composed starting about the third century BCE and through the 1st millennium CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201390–93_614-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201390–93-614">[556]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-615"><a href="#cite_note-615">[557]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2004485_616-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2004485-616">[558]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-Ashokan_expansion">Post-Ashokan expansion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road_transmission_of_Buddhism" title="Silk Road transmission of Buddhism">Silk Road transmission of Buddhism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ExtentOfBuddhismAndTrade.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1760" data-file-width="3489" decoding="async" height="111" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/ExtentOfBuddhismAndTrade.jpg/220px-ExtentOfBuddhismAndTrade.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/ExtentOfBuddhismAndTrade.jpg/330px-ExtentOfBuddhismAndTrade.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/ExtentOfBuddhismAndTrade.jpg/440px-ExtentOfBuddhismAndTrade.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ExtentOfBuddhismAndTrade.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Extent of Buddhism and trade routes in the 1st century CE</div></div></div>
<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Edicts_of_Ashoka" title="Edicts of Ashoka">edicts of Aśoka</a>, the Mauryan emperor sent emissaries to various countries west of India to spread "Dharma", particularly in eastern provinces of the neighbouring <a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucid Empire</a>, and even farther to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hellenistic_civilization" title="Hellenistic civilization">Hellenistic</a> kingdoms of the Mediterranean. It is a matter of disagreement among scholars whether or not these emissaries were accompanied by Buddhist missionaries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich2005a135_617-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich2005a135-617">[559]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Buddhist_Expansion.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="473" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="203" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Buddhist_Expansion.svg/220px-Buddhist_Expansion.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Buddhist_Expansion.svg/330px-Buddhist_Expansion.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Buddhist_Expansion.svg/440px-Buddhist_Expansion.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Buddhist_Expansion.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Buddhist expansion throughout Asia</div></div></div>
<p>In central and west Asia, Buddhist influence grew, through Greek-speaking Buddhist monarchs and ancient Asian trade routes, a phenomenon known as <a href="/wiki/Greco-Buddhism" title="Greco-Buddhism">Greco-Buddhism</a>. An example of this is evidenced in Chinese and Pali Buddhist records, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Milinda_Panha" title="Milinda Panha">Milindapanha</a></i> and the <a href="/wiki/Greco-Buddhist_art" title="Greco-Buddhist art">Greco-Buddhist art</a> of <a href="/wiki/Gandhara" title="Gandhara">Gandhāra</a>. The <i>Milindapanha</i> describes a conversation between a Buddhist monk and the 2nd-century BCE Greek king <a href="/wiki/Menander_I" title="Menander I">Menander</a>, after which Menander abdicates and himself goes into monastic life in the pursuit of nirvana.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor2004103,_119_618-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor2004103,_119-618">[560]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-619"><a href="#cite_note-619">[561]</a></sup> Some scholars have questioned the <i>Milindapanha</i> version, expressing doubts whether Menander was Buddhist or just favourably disposed to Buddhist monks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-620"><a href="#cite_note-620">[562]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kushan_empire" title="Kushan empire">Kushan empire</a> (30–375 CE) came to control the Silk Road trade through Central and South Asia, which brought them to interact with <a href="/wiki/Gandharan_Buddhism" title="Gandharan Buddhism">Gandharan Buddhism</a> and the Buddhist institutions of these regions. The Kushans patronised Buddhism throughout their lands, and many Buddhist centers were built or renovated (the Sarvastivada school was particularly favored), especially by Emperor Kanishka (128–151 CE).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-621"><a href="#cite_note-621">[563]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Heirman,_Ann_p._57_622-0"><a href="#cite_note-Heirman,_Ann_p._57-622">[564]</a></sup> Kushan support helped Buddhism to expand into a world religion through their trade routes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Liu2010p42_623-0"><a href="#cite_note-Liu2010p42-623">[565]</a></sup> Buddhism spread to <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Khotan" title="Kingdom of Khotan">Khotan</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Tarim_Basin" title="Tarim Basin">Tarim Basin</a>, and China, eventually to other parts of the far east.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Heirman,_Ann_p._57_622-1"><a href="#cite_note-Heirman,_Ann_p._57-622">[564]</a></sup> Some of the earliest written documents of the Buddhist faith are the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gandharan_Buddhist_texts" title="Gandharan Buddhist texts">Gandharan Buddhist texts</a>, dating from about the 1st century CE, and connected to the <a href="/wiki/Dharmaguptaka" title="Dharmaguptaka">Dharmaguptaka</a> school.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarder2000278_624-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarder2000278-624">[566]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-625"><a href="#cite_note-625">[567]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-626"><a href="#cite_note-626">[568]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Persia" title="Muslim conquest of Persia">Islamic conquest</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_Plateau" title="Iranian Plateau">Iranian Plateau</a> in the 7th-century, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquests_of_Afghanistan" title="Muslim conquests of Afghanistan">Muslim conquests of Afghanistan</a> and the later establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Ghaznavids" title="Ghaznavids">Ghaznavid kingdom</a> with Islam as the state religion in Central Asia between the 10th- and 12th-century led to the decline and disappearance of Buddhism from most of these regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kudara2002_627-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kudara2002-627">[569]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Mah.C4.81y.C4.81na_Buddhism"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Mahāyāna_Buddhism">Mahāyāna Buddhism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81y%C4%81na" title="Mahāyāna">Mahāyāna</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BuddhistTriad.JPG"><img alt="stone statue group, a Buddhist triad depicting, left to right, a Kushan, the future buddha Maitreya, Gautama Buddha, the bodhisattva Avalokiteśvara, and a Buddhist monk. 2nd–3rd century. Guimet Museum" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="970" data-file-width="1587" decoding="async" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/BuddhistTriad.JPG/220px-BuddhistTriad.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/BuddhistTriad.JPG/330px-BuddhistTriad.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/BuddhistTriad.JPG/440px-BuddhistTriad.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BuddhistTriad.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A Buddhist triad depicting, left to right, a <a href="/wiki/Kushan_Empire" title="Kushan Empire">Kushan</a>, the future buddha <a href="/wiki/Maitreya" title="Maitreya">Maitreya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Gautama Buddha</a>, the bodhisattva <a href="/wiki/Avalokite%C5%9Bvara" title="Avalokiteśvara">Avalokiteśvara</a>, and a <a href="/wiki/Bhikkhu" title="Bhikkhu">monk</a>. Second–third century. <a href="/wiki/Guimet_Museum" title="Guimet Museum">Guimet Museum</a></div></div></div>
<p>The origins of Mahāyāna ("Great Vehicle") Buddhism are not well understood and there are various competing theories about how and where this movement arose. Theories include the idea that it began as various groups venerating certain texts or that it arose as a strict forest ascetic movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Drewes,_David_2010_628-0"><a href="#cite_note-Drewes,_David_2010-628">[570]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first Mahāyāna works were written sometime between the 1st century BCE and the 2nd century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993252_527-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993252-527">[482]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Drewes,_David_2010_628-1"><a href="#cite_note-Drewes,_David_2010-628">[570]</a></sup> Much of the early extant evidence for the origins of Mahāyāna comes from early Chinese translations of Mahāyāna texts, mainly those of <a href="/wiki/Lokaksema_(Buddhist_monk)" title="Lokaksema (Buddhist monk)">Lokakṣema</a>. (2nd century CE).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-China_Buswell_2004_630-0"><a href="#cite_note-China_Buswell_2004-630">[note 45]</a></sup> Some scholars have traditionally considered the earliest <a href="/wiki/Mahayana_sutras" title="Mahayana sutras">Mahāyāna sūtras</a> to include the first versions of the <a href="/wiki/Prajnaparamita" title="Prajnaparamita">Prajnaparamita</a> series, along with texts concerning <a href="/wiki/Akshobhya" title="Akshobhya">Akṣobhya</a>, which were probably composed in the 1st century BCE in the south of India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993252–253,_263,_268_631-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993252–253,_263,_268-631">[572]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-South_633-0"><a href="#cite_note-South-633">[note 46]</a></sup>
</p><p>There is no evidence that Mahāyāna ever referred to a separate formal school or sect of Buddhism, with a separate monastic code (Vinaya), but rather that it existed as a certain set of ideals, and later doctrines, for bodhisattvas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENattier2003193–194_634-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENattier2003193–194-634">[574]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams20084–5_635-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams20084–5-635">[575]</a></sup> Records written by Chinese monks visiting India indicate that both Mahāyāna and non-Mahāyāna monks could be found in the same monasteries, with the difference that Mahāyāna monks worshipped figures of Bodhisattvas, while non-Mahayana monks did not.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200097_636-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200097-636">[576]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nalanda.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1571" data-file-width="2209" decoding="async" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Nalanda.jpg/220px-Nalanda.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Nalanda.jpg/330px-Nalanda.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Nalanda.jpg/440px-Nalanda.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nalanda.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Site of <a href="/wiki/Nalanda" title="Nalanda">Nalanda</a> University, a great center of Mahāyāna thought</div></div></div>
<p>Mahāyāna initially seems to have remained a small minority movement that was in tension with other Buddhist groups, struggling for wider acceptance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-637"><a href="#cite_note-637">[577]</a></sup> However, during the fifth and sixth centuries CE, there seems to have been a rapid growth of Mahāyāna Buddhism, which is shown by a large increase in epigraphic and manuscript evidence in this period. However, it still remained a minority in comparison to other Buddhist schools.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-638"><a href="#cite_note-638">[578]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mahāyāna Buddhist institutions continued to grow in influence during the following centuries, with large monastic university complexes such as <a href="/wiki/Nalanda" title="Nalanda">Nalanda</a> (established by the 5th-century CE Gupta emperor, <a href="/wiki/Kumaragupta_I" title="Kumaragupta I">Kumaragupta I</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Vikramashila" title="Vikramashila">Vikramashila</a> (established under <a href="/wiki/Dharmapala_(emperor)" title="Dharmapala (emperor)">Dharmapala</a> c. 783 to 820) becoming quite powerful and influential. During this period of Late Mahāyāna, four major types of thought developed: Mādhyamaka, Yogācāra, Buddha-nature (<i>Tathāgatagarbha</i>), and the <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_logico-epistemology#The_Dignāga-Dharmakīrti_tradition" title="Buddhist logico-epistemology">epistemological tradition of Dignaga and Dharmakirti</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa19938–9_639-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa19938–9-639">[579]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Dan_Lusthaus" title="Dan Lusthaus">Dan Lusthaus</a>, Mādhyamaka and Yogācāra have a great deal in common, and the commonality stems from early Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELusthaus2002236–237_640-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELusthaus2002236–237-640">[580]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Late_Indian_Buddhism_and_Tantra">Late Indian Buddhism and Tantra</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Vajrayana" title="Vajrayana">Vajrayana</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Thangka_Depicting_Vajrabhairava,_ca._1740,_Sotheby%27s.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="1441" decoding="async" height="305" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Thangka_Depicting_Vajrabhairava%2C_ca._1740%2C_Sotheby%27s.jpg/220px-Thangka_Depicting_Vajrabhairava%2C_ca._1740%2C_Sotheby%27s.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Thangka_Depicting_Vajrabhairava%2C_ca._1740%2C_Sotheby%27s.jpg/330px-Thangka_Depicting_Vajrabhairava%2C_ca._1740%2C_Sotheby%27s.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Thangka_Depicting_Vajrabhairava%2C_ca._1740%2C_Sotheby%27s.jpg/440px-Thangka_Depicting_Vajrabhairava%2C_ca._1740%2C_Sotheby%27s.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Thangka_Depicting_Vajrabhairava,_ca._1740,_Sotheby%27s.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Vajrayana adopted deities such as <a href="/wiki/Bhairava" title="Bhairava">Bhairava</a>, known as <a href="/wiki/Yamantaka" title="Yamantaka">Yamantaka</a> in Tibetan Buddhism.</div></div></div>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta period</a> (4th–6th centuries) and the empire of <a href="/wiki/Harsha" title="Harsha">Harṣavardana</a> (c. 590–647 CE), Buddhism continued to be influential in India, and large Buddhist learning institutions such as <a href="/wiki/Nalanda" title="Nalanda">Nalanda</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Valabhi_University" title="Valabhi University">Valabahi</a> Universities were at their peak.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarder2000442_641-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarder2000442-641">[581]</a></sup> Buddhism also flourished under the support of the <a href="/wiki/Pala_Empire" title="Pala Empire">Pāla Empire</a> (8th–12th centuries). Under the Guptas and Palas, Tantric Buddhism or Vajrayana developed and rose to prominence. It promoted new practices such as the use of <a href="/wiki/Mantra" title="Mantra">mantras</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dharani" title="Dharani">dharanis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mudra" title="Mudra">mudras</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mandala" title="Mandala">mandalas</a> and the visualization of deities and Buddhas and developed a new class of literature, the <a href="/wiki/Tantras_(Buddhism)" title="Tantras (Buddhism)">Buddhist Tantras</a>. This new esoteric form of Buddhism can be traced back to groups of wandering yogi magicians called <a href="/wiki/Mahasiddha" title="Mahasiddha">mahasiddhas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-642"><a href="#cite_note-642">[582]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-643"><a href="#cite_note-643">[583]</a></sup>
</p><p>The question of the origins of early Vajrayana has been taken up by various scholars. <a href="/wiki/David_Seyfort_Ruegg" title="David Seyfort Ruegg">David Seyfort Ruegg</a> has suggested that Buddhist tantra employed various elements of a "pan-Indian religious substrate" which is not specifically Buddhist, Shaiva or Vaishnava.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-644"><a href="#cite_note-644">[584]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Indologist <a href="/wiki/Alexis_Sanderson" title="Alexis Sanderson">Alexis Sanderson</a>, various classes of Vajrayana literature developed as a result of royal courts sponsoring both Buddhism and <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Saivism</a>. Sanderson has argued that Buddhist tantras can be shown to have borrowed practices, terms, rituals and more form Shaiva tantras. He argues that Buddhist texts even directly copied various Shaiva tantras, especially the Bhairava Vidyapitha tantras.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-645"><a href="#cite_note-645">[585]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-646"><a href="#cite_note-646">[586]</a></sup> Ronald M. Davidson meanwhile, argues that Sanderson's claims for direct influence from Shaiva <i>Vidyapitha</i> texts are problematic because "the chronology of the <i>Vidyapitha</i> tantras is by no means so well established"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-647"><a href="#cite_note-647">[587]</a></sup> and that the Shaiva tradition also appropriated non-Hindu deities, texts and traditions. Thus while "there can be no question that the Buddhist tantras were heavily influenced by <a href="/wiki/Kapalika" title="Kapalika">Kapalika</a> and other Saiva movements" argues Davidson, "the influence was apparently mutual."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-648"><a href="#cite_note-648">[588]</a></sup>
</p><p>Already during this later era, Buddhism was losing state support in other regions of India, including the lands of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Karkota_Empire" title="Karkota Empire">Karkotas</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Gurjara-Pratihara_dynasty" title="Gurjara-Pratihara dynasty">Pratiharas</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Rashtrakuta_dynasty" title="Rashtrakuta dynasty">Rashtrakutas</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pandya_dynasty" title="Pandya dynasty">Pandyas</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Pallava_dynasty" title="Pallava dynasty">Pallavas</a>. This loss of support in favor of Hindu faiths like <a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnavism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaivism</a>, is the beginning of the long and complex period of the <a href="/wiki/Decline_of_Buddhism_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="Decline of Buddhism in the Indian subcontinent">Decline of Buddhism in the Indian subcontinent</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-649"><a href="#cite_note-649">[589]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquests_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="Muslim conquests in the Indian subcontinent">Islamic invasions and conquest of India</a> (10th to 12th century), further damaged and destroyed many Buddhist institutions, leading to its eventual near disappearance from India by the 1200s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECollins2000184–185_650-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollins2000184–185-650">[590]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Spread_to_East_and_Southeast_Asia">Spread to East and Southeast Asia</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Prasat_Bayon_2014.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Prasat_Bayon_2014.JPG/220px-Prasat_Bayon_2014.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Prasat_Bayon_2014.JPG/330px-Prasat_Bayon_2014.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Prasat_Bayon_2014.JPG/440px-Prasat_Bayon_2014.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Prasat_Bayon_2014.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Angkor_Thom" title="Angkor Thom">Angkor Thom</a> build by <a href="/wiki/Khmer_Empire" title="Khmer Empire">Khmer</a> King <a href="/wiki/Jayavarman_VII" title="Jayavarman VII">Jayavarman VII</a> (c. 1120–1218)</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road_transmission_of_Buddhism" title="Silk Road transmission of Buddhism">Silk Road transmission of Buddhism</a> to China is most commonly thought to have started in the late 2nd or the 1st century CE, though the literary sources are all open to question.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZürcher197222–27_651-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZürcher197222–27-651">[591]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hill_653-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hill-653">[note 47]</a></sup> The first documented translation efforts by foreign <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhist_monk" title="Buddhist monk">Buddhist monks</a> in China were in the 2nd century CE, probably as a consequence of the expansion of the <a href="/wiki/Kushan_Empire" title="Kushan Empire">Kushan Empire</a> into the Chinese territory of the <a href="/wiki/Tarim_Basin" title="Tarim Basin">Tarim Basin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZürcher197223_654-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZürcher197223-654">[593]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first documented Buddhist texts translated into Chinese are those of the Parthian <a href="/wiki/An_Shigao" title="An Shigao">An Shigao</a> (148–180 CE).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-655"><a href="#cite_note-655">[594]</a></sup> The first known <a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahāyāna</a> scriptural texts are translations into Chinese by the Kushan monk <a href="/wiki/Lokaksema_(Buddhist_monk)" title="Lokaksema (Buddhist monk)">Lokakṣema</a> in <a href="/wiki/Luoyang" title="Luoyang">Luoyang</a>, between 178 and 189 CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200830_656-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200830-656">[595]</a></sup> From China, Buddhism was introduced into its neighbours <a href="/wiki/Korea" title="Korea">Korea</a> (4th century), <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a> (6th–7th centuries), and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a> (c. 1st–2nd centuries).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dykstra,_Yoshiko_Kurata_2001_p._100_657-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dykstra,_Yoshiko_Kurata_2001_p._100-657">[596]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-658"><a href="#cite_note-658">[597]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the Chinese <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang dynasty</a> (618–907), <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Esoteric_Buddhism" title="Chinese Esoteric Buddhism">Chinese Esoteric Buddhism</a> was introduced from India and <a href="/wiki/Chan_Buddhism" title="Chan Buddhism">Chan Buddhism</a> (Zen) became a major religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-659"><a href="#cite_note-659">[598]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-660"><a href="#cite_note-660">[599]</a></sup> Chan continued to grow in the <a href="/wiki/Song_dynasty" title="Song dynasty">Song dynasty</a> (960–1279) and it was during this era that it strongly influenced Korean Buddhism and Japanese Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-661"><a href="#cite_note-661">[600]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pure_Land_Buddhism" title="Pure Land Buddhism">Pure Land Buddhism</a> also became popular during this period and was often practised together with Chan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-662"><a href="#cite_note-662">[601]</a></sup> It was also during the Song that the entire <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Buddhist_canon" title="Chinese Buddhist canon">Chinese canon</a> was printed using over 130,000 wooden printing blocks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013223_663-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013223-663">[602]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the Indian period of Esoteric Buddhism (from the 8th century onwards), Buddhism spread from India to Tibet and <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a>. Johannes Bronkhorst states that the esoteric form was attractive because it allowed both a secluded monastic community as well as the social rites and rituals important to laypersons and to kings for the maintenance of a political state during succession and wars to resist invasion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst2011242–246_664-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst2011242–246-664">[603]</a></sup> During the Middle Ages, Buddhism slowly declined in India,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-665"><a href="#cite_note-665">[604]</a></sup> while it vanished from Persia and Central Asia as Islam became the state religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-larsfogelin6_666-0"><a href="#cite_note-larsfogelin6-666">[605]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-667"><a href="#cite_note-667">[606]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a> school arrived in Sri Lanka sometime in the 3rd century BCE. Sri Lanka became a base for its later spread to <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a> after the 5th century CE (<a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a> and coastal <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-668"><a href="#cite_note-668">[607]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESkilling1997_669-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESkilling1997-669">[608]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada Buddhism</a> was the dominant religion in <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Burma</a> during the Mon <a href="/wiki/Hanthawaddy_Kingdom" title="Hanthawaddy Kingdom">Hanthawaddy Kingdom</a> (1287–1552).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-670"><a href="#cite_note-670">[609]</a></sup> It also became dominant in the <a href="/wiki/Khmer_Empire" title="Khmer Empire">Khmer Empire</a> during the 13th and 14th centuries and in the Thai <a href="/wiki/Sukhothai_Kingdom" title="Sukhothai Kingdom">Sukhothai Kingdom</a> during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Ram_Khamhaeng" title="Ram Khamhaeng">Ram Khamhaeng</a> (1237/1247–1298).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-671"><a href="#cite_note-671">[610]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-672"><a href="#cite_note-672">[611]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Schools_and_traditions">Schools and traditions</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Schools_of_Buddhism" title="Schools of Buddhism">Schools of Buddhism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Buddhism#Common_Era" title="Timeline of Buddhism">Timeline of Buddhism § Common Era</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Buddhist_sects.png"><img alt="color map showing Buddhism is a major religion worldwide" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1249" data-file-width="1365" decoding="async" height="201" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Buddhist_sects.png/220px-Buddhist_sects.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Buddhist_sects.png/330px-Buddhist_sects.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Buddhist_sects.png/440px-Buddhist_sects.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Buddhist_sects.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Distribution of major Buddhist traditions</div></div></div>
<p>Buddhists generally classify themselves as either <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravāda</a> or <a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahāyāna</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown199612_673-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown199612-673">[612]</a></sup> This classification is also used by some scholars<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmith2006_674-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmith2006-674">[613]</a></sup> and is the one ordinarily used in the English language.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-675"><a href="#cite_note-675">[web 8]</a></sup> An alternative scheme used by some scholars divides Buddhism into the following three traditions or geographical or cultural areas: Theravāda (or "Southern Buddhism", "South Asian Buddhism"), <a href="/wiki/East_Asian_Buddhism" title="East Asian Buddhism">East Asian Buddhism</a> (or just "Eastern Buddhism") and <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism" title="Tibetan Buddhism">Indo-Tibetan Buddhism</a> (or "Northern Buddhism").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-alternative_scheme_676-0"><a href="#cite_note-alternative_scheme-676">[note 48]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Buddhism_in_Belgium.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1232" data-file-width="1840" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Buddhism_in_Belgium.JPG/220px-Buddhism_in_Belgium.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Buddhism_in_Belgium.JPG/330px-Buddhism_in_Belgium.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Buddhism_in_Belgium.JPG/440px-Buddhism_in_Belgium.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Buddhism_in_Belgium.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Buddhists of various traditions, Yeunten Ling Tibetan Institute</div></div></div>
<p>Some scholars<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-other_schemes_677-0"><a href="#cite_note-other_schemes-677">[note 49]</a></sup> use other schemes. Buddhists themselves have a variety of other schemes. <a href="/wiki/Hinayana" title="Hinayana">Hinayana</a> (literally "lesser or inferior vehicle") is sometimes used by Mahāyāna followers to name the family of early philosophical schools and traditions from which contemporary Theravāda emerged, but as the Hinayana term is considered derogatory, a variety of other terms are used instead, including: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shravakayana" title="Shravakayana">Śrāvakayāna</a>, Nikaya Buddhism, early Buddhist schools, sectarian Buddhism and conservative Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kwmorganp410_678-0"><a href="#cite_note-kwmorganp410-678">[614]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-679"><a href="#cite_note-679">[615]</a></sup>
</p><p>Not all traditions of Buddhism share the same philosophical outlook, or treat the same concepts as central. Each tradition, however, does have its own core concepts, and some comparisons can be drawn between them:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-680"><a href="#cite_note-680">[616]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-681"><a href="#cite_note-681">[617]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li>Both Theravāda and Mahāyāna accept and revere <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">the Buddha Sakyamuni</a> as the founder, Mahāyāna also reveres numerous other Buddhas, such as <a href="/wiki/Amit%C4%81bha" title="Amitābha">Amitabha</a> or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vairochana" title="Vairochana">Vairocana</a> as well as many other bodhisattvas not revered in Theravāda.</li>
<li>Both accept the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Way" title="Middle Way">Middle Way</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prat%C4%ABtyasamutp%C4%81da" title="Pratītyasamutpāda">Dependent origination</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Four_Noble_Truths" title="Four Noble Truths">Four Noble Truths</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Noble_Eightfold_Path" title="Noble Eightfold Path">Noble Eightfold Path</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Refuge_(Buddhism)" title="Refuge (Buddhism)">Three Jewels</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Three_marks_of_existence" title="Three marks of existence">Three marks of existence</a> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Bodhipakkhiy%C4%81dhamm%C4%81" title="Bodhipakkhiyādhammā">Bodhipakṣadharmas</a></i> (aids to awakening).</li>
<li>Mahāyāna focuses mainly on the <a href="/wiki/Bodhisattva" title="Bodhisattva">bodhisattva path</a> to Buddhahood which it sees as universal and to be practiced by all persons, while Theravāda does not focus on teaching this path and teaches the attainment of <a href="/wiki/Arhat" title="Arhat">arhatship</a> as a worthy goal to strive towards. The bodhisattva path is not denied in Theravāda, it is generally seen as a long and difficult path suitable for only a few.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-682"><a href="#cite_note-682">[618]</a></sup> Thus the Bodhisattva path is normative in Mahāyāna, while it is an optional path for a heroic few in Theravāda.<sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2013"Bodhisattva,_Career_in_the_Theravada"_683-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2013"Bodhisattva,_Career_in_the_Theravada"-683'>[619]</a></sup></li>
<li>Mahāyāna sees the arhat's nirvana as being imperfect and inferior or preliminary to full Buddhahood. It sees arhatship as selfish, since bodhisattvas vow to save all beings while arhats save only themselves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-684"><a href="#cite_note-684">[620]</a></sup> Theravāda meanwhile does not accept that the arhat's nirvana is an inferior or preliminary attainment, nor that it is a selfish deed to attain arhatship since not only are arhats described as compassionate but they have destroyed the root of greed, the sense of "I am".<sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2013"Bodhisattva,_Career_in_the_Theravada"_683-1'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2013"Bodhisattva,_Career_in_the_Theravada"-683'>[619]</a></sup></li>
<li>Mahāyāna accepts the authority of the many Mahāyāna sutras along with the other Nikaya texts like the Agamas and the Pali canon (though it sees Mahāyāna texts as primary), while Theravāda does not accept that the Mahāyāna sutras are <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhavacana" title="Buddhavacana">buddhavacana</a></i> (word of the Buddha) at all.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-685"><a href="#cite_note-685">[621]</a></sup></li></ul>
<h3><span id="Therav.C4.81da_school"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Theravāda_school">Theravāda school</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Therav%C4%81da" title="Theravāda">Theravāda</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vipassana4.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1365" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Vipassana4.jpg/220px-Vipassana4.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Vipassana4.jpg/330px-Vipassana4.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Vipassana4.jpg/440px-Vipassana4.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vipassana4.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Monastics and white clad laypersons celebrate Vesak, Vipassakna Dhaurak, Cambodia.</div></div></div>
<p>The Theravāda tradition bases itself on the Pāli Canon, considers itself to be the more orthodox form of Buddhism and tends to be more conservative in doctrine and monastic discipline.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-686"><a href="#cite_note-686">[622]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-687"><a href="#cite_note-687">[623]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich200637_688-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich200637-688">[624]</a></sup> The Pāli Canon is the only complete Buddhist canon surviving in an ancient Indian language. This language, Pāli, serves as the school's sacred language and lingua franca.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-689"><a href="#cite_note-689">[625]</a></sup> Besides the Pāli Canon, Theravāda scholastics also often rely on a <a href="/wiki/Pali_literature" title="Pali literature">post-canonical Pāli literature</a> which comments on and interprets the Pāli Canon. These later works such as the <i><a href="/wiki/Visuddhimagga" title="Visuddhimagga">Visuddhimagga</a></i>, a doctrinal <i><a href="/wiki/Summa" title="Summa">summa</a></i> written in the fifth century by the exegete <a href="/wiki/Buddhaghosa" title="Buddhaghosa">Buddhaghosa</a> also remain influential today.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-690"><a href="#cite_note-690">[626]</a></sup>
</p><p>Theravāda derives from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mahaviharavasin" title="Mahaviharavasin">Mahāvihāra (Tāmraparṇīya)</a> sect, a Sri Lankan branch of the <a href="/wiki/Vibhajyav%C4%81da" title="Vibhajyavāda">Vibhajyavāda</a> <a href="/wiki/Sthavira_nik%C4%81ya" title="Sthavira nikāya">Sthaviras</a>, which began to establish itself on the island from the 3rd century BCE onwards.
</p><p>Theravāda flourished in south India and Sri Lanka in ancient times; from there it spread for the first time into mainland Southeast Asia about the 11th century into its elite urban centres.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECollins199818_691-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollins199818-691">[627]</a></sup> By the 13th century, Theravāda had spread widely into the rural areas of mainland Southeast Asia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECollins199818_691-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollins199818-691">[627]</a></sup> displacing Mahayana Buddhism and some traditions of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-692"><a href="#cite_note-692">[628]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-693"><a href="#cite_note-693">[629]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-694"><a href="#cite_note-694">[630]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the modern era, Buddhist figures such as <a href="/wiki/Anagarika_Dharmapala" title="Anagarika Dharmapala">Anagarika Dhammapala</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mongkut" title="Mongkut">King Mongkut</a> sought to re-focus the tradition on the Pāli Canon, as well as emphasize the rational and "scientific" nature of Theravāda while also opposing "superstition".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel200816–17_695-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel200816–17-695">[631]</a></sup> This movement, often termed <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_modernism" title="Buddhist modernism">Buddhist modernism</a>, has influenced most forms of modern Theravāda. Another influential modern turn in Theravāda is the <a href="/wiki/Vipassana_movement" title="Vipassana movement">Vipassana Movement</a>, which led to the widespread adoption of meditation by laypersons.
</p><p>Theravāda is primarily practised today in <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Sri_Lanka" title="Buddhism in Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Burma" title="Buddhism in Burma">Burma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Laos" title="Buddhism in Laos">Laos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Thailand" title="Buddhism in Thailand">Thailand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Cambodia" title="Buddhism in Cambodia">Cambodia</a> as well as small portions of China, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Vietnam" title="Buddhism in Vietnam">Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Malaysia" title="Buddhism in Malaysia">Malaysia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Bangladesh" title="Buddhism in Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>. It has a growing presence in the west, especially as part of the Vipassana Movement.
</p>
<h3><span id="Mah.C4.81y.C4.81na_traditions"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Mahāyāna_traditions">Mahāyāna traditions</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81y%C4%81na" title="Mahāyāna">Mahāyāna</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chinese_Buddhist_Monks_Ceremony_Hangzhou.jpeg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="683" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Chinese_Buddhist_Monks_Ceremony_Hangzhou.jpeg/220px-Chinese_Buddhist_Monks_Ceremony_Hangzhou.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Chinese_Buddhist_Monks_Ceremony_Hangzhou.jpeg/330px-Chinese_Buddhist_Monks_Ceremony_Hangzhou.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Chinese_Buddhist_Monks_Ceremony_Hangzhou.jpeg/440px-Chinese_Buddhist_Monks_Ceremony_Hangzhou.jpeg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chinese_Buddhist_Monks_Ceremony_Hangzhou.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Chinese Buddhist monks performing a formal ceremony in Hangzhou, Zhejiang Province, China</div></div></div>
<p>Mahāyāna ("Great Vehicle") refers to all forms of Buddhism which consider the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mahayana_Sutras" title="Mahayana Sutras">Mahāyāna Sutras</a> as authoritative scriptures and accurate rendering of Buddha's words.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-karlpotter1996p26_534-2"><a href="#cite_note-karlpotter1996p26-534">[489]</a></sup> These traditions have been the more liberal form of Buddhism allowing different and new interpretations that emerged over time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chengp60_696-0"><a href="#cite_note-chengp60-696">[632]</a></sup> The focus of Mahāyāna is the path of the bodhisattva (<i>bodhisattvayāna</i>), though what this path means is interpreted in many different ways.
</p><p>The first Mahāyāna texts date to sometime between the 1st century BCE and the 2st century CE. It remained a minority movement until the time of the Guptas and Palas, when great Mahāyāna monastic centres of learning such as <a href="/wiki/Nalanda_University" title="Nalanda University">Nālandā University</a> were established as evidenced by records left by three Chinese visitors to India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-scharfe2002p144_697-0"><a href="#cite_note-scharfe2002p144-697">[633]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-698"><a href="#cite_note-698">[634]</a></sup> These universities supported Buddhist scholarship, as well as studies into non-Buddhist traditions and secular subjects such as medicine. They hosted visiting students who then spread Buddhism to East and Central Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-scharfe2002p144_697-1"><a href="#cite_note-scharfe2002p144-697">[633]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-higham2014p121_699-0"><a href="#cite_note-higham2014p121-699">[635]</a></sup>
</p><p>Native Mahāyāna Buddhism is practised today in China, Japan, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Korea" title="Buddhism in Korea">Korea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Singapore" title="Buddhism in Singapore">Singapore</a>, parts of Russia and most of <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a> (also commonly referred to as "Eastern Buddhism"). The Buddhism practised in Tibet, the Himalayan regions, and Mongolia is also a form of Mahāyāna, but is also different in many ways due to its adoption of tantric practices and is discussed below under the heading of "Vajrayāna" (also commonly referred to as "Northern Buddhism"). 
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:408px;max-width:408px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ch%C3%B6d_practitioners_at_Boudhanath_stupa.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="4912" data-file-width="7360" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Ch%C3%B6d_practitioners_at_Boudhanath_stupa.jpg/200px-Ch%C3%B6d_practitioners_at_Boudhanath_stupa.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Ch%C3%B6d_practitioners_at_Boudhanath_stupa.jpg/300px-Ch%C3%B6d_practitioners_at_Boudhanath_stupa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Ch%C3%B6d_practitioners_at_Boudhanath_stupa.jpg/400px-Ch%C3%B6d_practitioners_at_Boudhanath_stupa.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Tibetan Buddhists practicing <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%B6d" title="Chöd">Chöd</a> with various ritual implements, such as the <a href="/wiki/Damaru" title="Damaru">Damaru</a> drum, hand-bell, and <a href="/wiki/Kangling" title="Kangling">Kangling</a> (thighbone trumpet)</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Impermanence.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3600" data-file-width="5400" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Impermanence.jpg/200px-Impermanence.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Impermanence.jpg/300px-Impermanence.jpg
