1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Impermanence.jpg/400px-Impermanence.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Ruins of a temple at the <a href="/wiki/Erdene_Zuu_Monastery" title="Erdene Zuu Monastery">Erdene Zuu Monastery</a> complex in <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>There are a variety of strands in Eastern Buddhism, of which "the Pure Land school of Mahāyāna is the most widely practised today."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClarkeBeyer200986_700-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClarkeBeyer200986-700">[636]</a></sup> In most of China, these different strands and traditions are generally fused together. Vietnamese Mahāyāna is similarly very eclectic. <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Japan" title="Buddhism in Japan">In Japan in particular</a>, they form separate denominations with the five major ones being: <a href="/wiki/Nichiren_Buddhism" title="Nichiren Buddhism">Nichiren</a>, peculiar to Japan; <a href="/wiki/Pure_Land_Buddhism" title="Pure Land Buddhism">Pure Land</a>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shingon" title="Shingon">Shingon</a>, a form of Vajrayana; <a href="/wiki/Tendai" title="Tendai">Tendai</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Zen" title="Zen">Zen</a>. In Korea, nearly all Buddhists belong to the <a href="/wiki/Jogye_Order" title="Jogye Order">Chogye school</a>, which is officially Son (Zen), but with substantial elements from other traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004430,_435_701-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004430,_435-701">[637]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Vajray.C4.81na_traditions"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Vajrayāna_traditions">Vajrayāna traditions</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Vajrayana" title="Vajrayana">Vajrayana</a></div>
<p>The goal and philosophy of the Vajrayāna remains Mahāyānist, but its methods are seen by its followers as far more powerful, so as to lead to Buddhahood in just one lifetime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013189_702-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013189-702">[638]</a></sup> The practice of using <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mantras" title="Mantras">mantras</a> was adopted from <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>, where they were first used in the <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013180_703-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013180-703">[639]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism" title="Tibetan Buddhism">Tibetan Buddhism</a> preserves the Vajrayana teachings of eighth-century India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-White_2000_21_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-White_2000_21-15">[15]</a></sup> Tantric Buddhism is largely concerned with ritual and meditative practices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams1989185_704-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams1989185-704">[640]</a></sup> A central feature of Buddhist Tantra is <a href="/wiki/Deity_yoga" title="Deity yoga">deity yoga</a> which includes visualisation and identification with an enlightened <a href="/wiki/Yidam" title="Yidam">yidam</a> or meditation deity and its associated <a href="/wiki/Mandala" title="Mandala">mandala</a>. Another element of Tantra is the need for ritual initiation or empowerment (abhiṣeka) by a <a href="/wiki/Guru" title="Guru">Guru</a> or <a href="/wiki/Lama" title="Lama">Lama</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliamsTribeWynne2012198,_231_705-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliamsTribeWynne2012198,_231-705">[641]</a></sup> Some Tantras like the <a href="/wiki/Guhyasam%C4%81ja_Tantra" title="Guhyasamāja Tantra">Guhyasamāja Tantra</a> features new forms of antinomian ritual practice such as the use taboo substances like alcohol, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Karmamudra" title="Karmamudra">sexual yoga</a>, and charnel ground practices which evoke <a href="/wiki/Wrathful_deities" title="Wrathful deities">wrathful deities</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliamsTribeWynne2012212_706-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliamsTribeWynne2012212-706">[642]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2004781_707-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2004781-707">[643]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Monasteries_and_temples">Monasteries and temples</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_architecture" title="Buddhist architecture">Buddhist architecture</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Various types of Buddhist buildings</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:97px;max-width:97px"><div 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Kinkaku-ji_the_Golden_Temple_in_Kyoto_overlooking_the_lake_-_high_rez.JPG/268px-Kinkaku-ji_the_Golden_Temple_in_Kyoto_overlooking_the_lake_-_high_rez.JPG 2x" width="134"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:152px;max-width:152px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:100px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sakya_tibet2.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2447" data-file-width="3655" decoding="async" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Sakya_tibet2.jpg/150px-Sakya_tibet2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Sakya_tibet2.jpg/225px-Sakya_tibet2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Sakya_tibet2.jpg/300px-Sakya_tibet2.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Buddhist institutions are often housed and centered around <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monasteries" title="Monasteries">monasteries</a> (Sanskrit:<i><a href="/wiki/Vih%C4%81ra" title="Vihāra">viharas</a></i>) and temples. Buddhist monastics originally followed a life of wandering, never staying in one place for long. During the three month rainy season (<i><a href="/wiki/Vassa" title="Vassa">vassa</a></i>) they would gather together in one place for a period of intense practice and then depart again.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa199368_708-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa199368-708">[644]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDutt198853_709-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDutt198853-709">[645]</a></sup> Some of the earliest Buddhist monasteries were at groves (<i>vanas</i>) or woods (<i>araññas</i>), such as <a href="/wiki/Jetavana" title="Jetavana">Jetavana</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sarnath" title="Sarnath">Sarnath's Deer Park</a>. There originally seems to have been two main types of monasteries, monastic settlements (<i>sangharamas</i>) were built and supported by donors, and woodland camps (<i>avasas</i>) were set up by monks. Whatever structures were built in these locales were made out of wood and were sometimes temporary structures built for the rainy season.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa199334_710-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa199334-710">[646]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDutt198855_711-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDutt198855-711">[647]</a></sup>
</p><p>Over time, the wandering community slowly adopted more settled <a href="/wiki/Cenobitic_monasticism" title="Cenobitic monasticism">cenobitic</a> forms of monasticism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDutt198857–59_712-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDutt198857–59-712">[648]</a></sup> Also, these monasteries slowly evolved from the simpler collections of rustic dwellings of early Buddhism into larger more permanent structures meant to house the entire community, who now lived in a more collective fashion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDutt198892–94_713-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDutt198892–94-713">[649]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_era" title="Gupta era">Gupta era</a>, even larger monastic university complexes (like Nalanda) arose, with larger and more artistically ornate structures, as well as large land grants and accumulated wealth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDutt1988197–198_714-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDutt1988197–198-714">[650]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are many different forms of Buddhist structures. Classic Indian Buddhist institutions mainly made use of the following structures: monasteries, rock-hewn cave complexes (such as the <a href="/wiki/Ajanta_Caves" title="Ajanta Caves">Ajanta Caves</a>), <a href="/wiki/Stupa" title="Stupa">stupas</a> (funerary mounds which contained relics), and temples such as the <a href="/wiki/Mahabodhi_Temple" title="Mahabodhi Temple">Mahabodhi Temple</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-715"><a href="#cite_note-715">[651]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Southeast Asia, the most widespread institutions are centered on <a href="/wiki/Wat" title="Wat">wats</a>, which refers to an establishment with various buildings such as an ordination hall, a library, monks' quarters and stupas. East Asian Buddhist institutions also use various structures including monastic halls, temples, lecture halls, bell towers and <a href="/wiki/Pagoda" title="Pagoda">pagodas</a>. In <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_temples_in_Japan" title="Buddhist temples in Japan">Japanese Buddhist temples</a>, these different structures are usually grouped together in an area termed the <a href="/wiki/Shichid%C5%8D_garan" title="Shichidō garan">garan</a>. In Indo-Tibetan Buddhism, Buddhist institutions are generally housed in <a href="/wiki/Gompa" title="Gompa">gompas</a>. They include monastic quarters, stupas and prayer halls with Buddha images.
</p><p>The complexity of Buddhist institutions varies, ranging from minimalist and rustic forest monasteries to large monastic centers like <a href="/wiki/Tawang_Monastery" title="Tawang Monastery">Tawang Monastery</a>. The core of traditional Buddhist institutions is the monastic community (<i>Sangha)</i> who manage and lead religious services. They are supported by the lay community who visit temples and monasteries for religious services and holidays.
</p><p>In the modern era, the Buddhist "meditation centre", which is mostly used by laypersons and often also staffed by them, has also become widespread.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-716"><a href="#cite_note-716">[652]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Buddhism_in_the_modern_era">Buddhism in the modern era</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_by_country" title="Buddhism by country">Buddhism by country</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Buddhism" title="Western Buddhism">Western Buddhism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_modernism" title="Buddhist modernism">Buddhist modernism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D0%A5%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA.JPG"><img alt="Buddhist monk in Siberia in robes leaning on railing looking at temple" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3456" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/%D0%A5%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA.JPG/220px-%D0%A5%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/%D0%A5%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA.JPG/330px-%D0%A5%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/%D0%A5%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA.JPG/440px-%D0%A5%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D0%A5%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Buryats" title="Buryats">Buryat</a> Buddhist monk in <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Colonial_era">Colonial era</span></h3>
<p>Buddhism has faced various challenges and changes during the colonisation of Buddhist states by Christian countries and its persecution under modern states. Like other religions, the findings of modern science has challenged its basic premises. One response to some of these challenges has come to be called <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_modernism" title="Buddhist modernism">Buddhist modernism</a>. Early Buddhist modernist figures such as the American convert <a href="/wiki/Henry_Steel_Olcott" title="Henry Steel Olcott">Henry Olcott</a> (1832–1907) and <a href="/wiki/Anagarika_Dharmapala" title="Anagarika Dharmapala">Anagarika Dharmapala</a>  (1864–1933) reinterpreted and promoted Buddhism as a scientific and rational religion which they saw as compatible with modern science.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013378_717-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013378-717">[653]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/East_Asian_Buddhism" title="East Asian Buddhism">East Asian Buddhism</a> meanwhile suffered under various wars which ravaged China during the modern era, such as the <a href="/wiki/Taiping_Rebellion" title="Taiping Rebellion">Taiping rebellion</a> and <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> (which also affected <a href="/wiki/Korean_Buddhism" title="Korean Buddhism">Korean Buddhism</a>). During the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="Republic of China (1912–1949)">Republican period</a> (1912–49), a new movement called <a href="/wiki/Humanistic_Buddhism" title="Humanistic Buddhism">Humanistic Buddhism</a> was developed by figures such as <a href="/wiki/Taixu" title="Taixu">Taixu</a> (1899–1947), and though Buddhist institutions were destroyed during the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a> (1966–76), there has been a revival of the religion in China after 1977.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013409–410_718-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013409–410-718">[654]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Japan" title="Buddhism in Japan">Japanese Buddhism</a> also went through a period of modernisation during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Meiji_period" title="Meiji period">Meiji period</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013403_719-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013403-719">[655]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a> meanwhile, the arrival of <a href="/wiki/Communism" title="Communism">Communist</a> repression to <a href="/wiki/Tibet" title="Tibet">Tibet</a> (1966–1980) and <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a>  (between 1924 and 1990) had a strong negative impact on Buddhist institutions, though the situation has improved somewhat since the 80s and 90s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013414–417_720-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013414–417-720">[656]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Buddhism_in_the_West">Buddhism in the West</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:214px;max-width:214px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:212px;max-width:212px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1893parliament.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1582" data-file-width="3462" decoding="async" height="96" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/1893parliament.jpg/210px-1893parliament.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/1893parliament.jpg/315px-1893parliament.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/1893parliament.jpg/420px-1893parliament.jpg 2x" width="210"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">1893 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Parliament_of_Religions" title="World Parliament of Religions">World Parliament of Religions</a> in <a href="/wiki/Chicago" title="Chicago">Chicago</a>, <a href="/wiki/Illinois" title="Illinois">Illinois</a>, United States</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:212px;max-width:212px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Buddharama_Nukari.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="875" data-file-width="1238" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Buddharama_Nukari.jpg/210px-Buddharama_Nukari.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Buddharama_Nukari.jpg/315px-Buddharama_Nukari.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Buddharama_Nukari.jpg/420px-Buddharama_Nukari.jpg 2x" width="210"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Interior of the Thai Buddhist wat in <a href="/wiki/Nukari" title="Nukari">Nukari</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nurmij%C3%A4rvi" title="Nurmijärvi">Nurmijärvi</a>, Finland</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>While there were some encounters of Western travellers or missionaries such as St. <a href="/wiki/Francis_Xavier" title="Francis Xavier">Francis Xavier</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ippolito_Desideri" title="Ippolito Desideri">Ippolito Desideri</a> with Buddhist cultures, it was not until the 19th century that Buddhism began to be studied by Western scholars. It was the work of pioneering scholars such as <a href="/wiki/Eug%C3%A8ne_Burnouf" title="Eugène Burnouf">Eugène Burnouf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Max_M%C3%BCller" title="Max Müller">Max Müller</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hermann_Oldenberg" title="Hermann Oldenberg">Hermann Oldenberg</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thomas_William_Rhys_Davids" title="Thomas William Rhys Davids">Thomas William Rhys Davids</a> that paved the way for modern <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_studies" title="Buddhist studies">Buddhist studies</a> in the West. The English words such as Buddhism, "Boudhist", "Bauddhist" and Buddhist were coined in the early 19th-century in the West,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-721"><a href="#cite_note-721">[657]</a></sup> while in 1881, Rhys Davids founded the <a href="/wiki/Pali_Text_Society" title="Pali Text Society">Pali Text Society</a> – an influential Western resource of Buddhist literature in the Pali language and one of the earliest publisher of a journal on <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_studies" title="Buddhist studies">Buddhist studies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-722"><a href="#cite_note-722">[658]</a></sup> It was also during the 19th century that Asian Buddhist immigrants (mainly from China and Japan) began to arrive in Western countries such as the United States and Canada, bringing with them their Buddhist religion. This period also saw the first Westerners to formally convert to Buddhism, such as <a href="/wiki/Helena_Blavatsky" title="Helena Blavatsky">Helena Blavatsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Henry_Steel_Olcott" title="Henry Steel Olcott">Henry Steel Olcott</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:10_723-0"><a href="#cite_note-:10-723">[659]</a></sup> An important event in the introduction of Buddhism to the West was the 1893 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Parliament_of_Religions" title="World Parliament of Religions">World Parliament of Religions</a>, which for the first time saw well-publicized speeches by major Buddhist leaders alongside other religious leaders.
</p><p>The 20th century saw a prolific growth of new Buddhist institutions in Western countries, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhist_Society,_London" title="Buddhist Society, London">Buddhist Society, London</a> (1924), <a href="/wiki/Das_Buddhistische_Haus" title="Das Buddhistische Haus">Das Buddhistische Haus</a> (1924) and <a href="/wiki/Datsan_Gunzechoinei" title="Datsan Gunzechoinei">Datsan Gunzechoinei</a> in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg" title="Saint Petersburg">St Petersburg</a>. The publication and translations of Buddhist literature in Western languages thereafter accelerated. After the <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">second world war</a>, further immigration from Asia, globalisation, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Secularisation" title="Secularisation">secularisation</a> on Western culture as well a renewed interest in Buddhism among the 60s <a href="/wiki/Counterculture" title="Counterculture">counterculture</a> led to further growth in Buddhist institutions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-724"><a href="#cite_note-724">[660]</a></sup> Influential figures on post-war <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_the_West" title="Buddhism in the West">Western Buddhism</a> include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shunryu_Suzuki" title="Shunryu Suzuki">Shunryu Suzuki</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jack_Kerouac" title="Jack Kerouac">Jack Kerouac</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alan_Watts" title="Alan Watts">Alan Watts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%ADch_Nh%E1%BA%A5t_H%E1%BA%A1nh" title="Thích Nhất Hạnh">Thích Nhất Hạnh</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/14th_Dalai_Lama" title="14th Dalai Lama">14th Dalai Lama</a>. While Buddhist institutions have grown, some of the central premises of Buddhism such as the cycles of rebirth and <a href="/wiki/Four_Noble_Truths" title="Four Noble Truths">Four Noble Truths</a> have been problematic in the West.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKonik2009ix_725-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKonik2009ix-725">[661]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHayes2013172_726-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHayes2013172-726">[662]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELamb2001258_727-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELamb2001258-727">[663]</a></sup> In contrast, states Christopher Gowans, for "most ordinary [Asian] Buddhists, today as well as in the past, their basic moral orientation is governed by belief in karma and rebirth".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGowans201418–23,_76–88_728-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGowans201418–23,_76–88-728">[664]</a></sup> Most Asian Buddhist laypersons, states Kevin Trainor, have historically pursued Buddhist rituals and practices seeking better rebirth,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown200960–63,_74–85,_185–187_729-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown200960–63,_74–85,_185–187-729">[665]</a></sup> not nirvana or freedom from rebirth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFowler199965_730-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFowler199965-730">[666]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nouvelle_g%C3%A9ographie_universelle_-_la_terre_et_les_hommes_(1876)_(14592652167).jpg"><img alt="Buddha statue in 1896, Bamiyan" data-file-height="1928" data-file-width="2848" decoding="async" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Nouvelle_g%C3%A9ographie_universelle_-_la_terre_et_les_hommes_%281876%29_%2814592652167%29.jpg/220px-Nouvelle_g%C3%A9ographie_universelle_-_la_terre_et_les_hommes_%281876%29_%2814592652167%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Nouvelle_g%C3%A9ographie_universelle_-_la_terre_et_les_hommes_%281876%29_%2814592652167%29.jpg/330px-Nouvelle_g%C3%A9ographie_universelle_-_la_terre_et_les_hommes_%281876%29_%2814592652167%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Nouvelle_g%C3%A9ographie_universelle_-_la_terre_et_les_hommes_%281876%29_%2814592652167%29.jpg/440px-Nouvelle_g%C3%A9ographie_universelle_-_la_terre_et_les_hommes_%281876%29_%2814592652167%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Destroyed_Statue,_July_17,_2005_at_15-53.jpg"><img alt="After statue destroyed by Islamist Taliban in 2001" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Destroyed_Statue%2C_July_17%2C_2005_at_15-53.jpg/220px-Destroyed_Statue%2C_July_17%2C_2005_at_15-53.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Destroyed_Statue%2C_July_17%2C_2005_at_15-53.jpg/330px-Destroyed_Statue%2C_July_17%2C_2005_at_15-53.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Destroyed_Statue%2C_July_17%2C_2005_at_15-53.jpg/440px-Destroyed_Statue%2C_July_17%2C_2005_at_15-53.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Buddhas_of_Bamiyan" title="Buddhas of Bamiyan">Buddhas of Bamiyan</a>, Afghanistan in 1896 (top) and after destruction in 2001 by the <a href="/wiki/Taliban" title="Taliban">Taliban</a> Islamists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-731"><a href="#cite_note-731">[667]</a></sup></div></div></div></div>
<p>Buddhism has spread across the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHenderson200242_732-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHenderson200242-732">[668]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETamney199868_733-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETamney199868-733">[669]</a></sup> and Buddhist texts are increasingly translated into local languages. While <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_the_West" title="Buddhism in the West">Buddhism in the West</a> is often seen as exotic and progressive, in the East it is regarded as familiar and traditional. In countries such as <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bhutan" title="Bhutan">Bhutan</a>, it is recognised as the <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">state religion</a> and receives government support.
</p><p>In certain regions such as Afghanistan and Pakistan, militants have targeted violence and destruction of historic Buddhist monuments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-734"><a href="#cite_note-734">[670]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-735"><a href="#cite_note-735">[671]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Neo-Buddhism_movements">Neo-Buddhism movements</span></h3>
<p>A number of modern movements in Buddhism emerged during the second half of the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEParanjpe1998351_736-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEParanjpe1998351-736">[672]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPavāra2009xv–xviii_737-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPavāra2009xv–xviii-737">[673]</a></sup> These <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_modernism" title="Buddhist modernism">new forms of Buddhism</a> are diverse and significantly depart from traditional beliefs and practices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-738"><a href="#cite_note-738">[674]</a></sup>
</p><p>In India, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/B.R._Ambedkar" title="B.R. Ambedkar">B.R. Ambedkar</a> launched the Navayana tradition – literally, "new vehicle". Ambedkar's Buddhism rejects the foundational doctrines and historic practices of traditional Theravada and Mahayana traditions, such as monk lifestyle after renunciation, karma, rebirth, samsara, meditation, nirvana, Four Noble Truths and others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish201325_739-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish201325-739">[675]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEQueen2013524–529_740-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEQueen2013524–529-740">[676]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Skaria_2015_741-0"><a href="#cite_note-Skaria_2015-741">[677]</a></sup> Ambedkar's Navayana Buddhism considers these as superstitions and re-interprets the original Buddha as someone who taught about <a href="/wiki/Class_conflict" title="Class conflict">class struggle</a> and social equality.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zelliot_742-0"><a href="#cite_note-Zelliot-742">[678]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish201324–26_743-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish201324–26-743">[679]</a></sup> Ambedkar urged low caste Indian <a href="/wiki/Dalit" title="Dalit">Dalits</a> to convert to his Marxism-inspired<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Skaria_2015_741-1"><a href="#cite_note-Skaria_2015-741">[677]</a></sup> reinterpretation called the <a href="/wiki/Navayana" title="Navayana">Navayana</a> Buddhism, also known as Bhimayana Buddhism. Ambedkar's effort led to the expansion of Navayana Buddhism in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-744"><a href="#cite_note-744">[680]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zelliot_742-1"><a href="#cite_note-Zelliot-742">[678]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Thai <a href="/wiki/Mongkut" title="Mongkut">King Mongkut</a> (r. 1851–68), and his son <a href="/wiki/Chulalongkorn" title="Chulalongkorn">King Chulalongkorn</a> (r. 1868–1910), were responsible for modern reforms of <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Thailand" title="Buddhism in Thailand">Thai Buddhism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013385_745-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013385-745">[681]</a></sup> Modern Buddhist movements include <a href="/wiki/Secular_Buddhism" title="Secular Buddhism">Secular Buddhism</a> in many countries, <a href="/wiki/Won_Buddhism" title="Won Buddhism">Won Buddhism</a> in Korea, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dhammakaya_movement" title="Dhammakaya movement">Dhammakaya movement</a> in Thailand and several Japanese organisations, such as <a href="/wiki/Shinnyo-en" title="Shinnyo-en">Shinnyo-en</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rissh%C5%8D_K%C5%8Dsei_Kai" title="Risshō Kōsei Kai">Risshō Kōsei Kai</a> or <a href="/wiki/Soka_Gakkai" title="Soka Gakkai">Soka Gakkai</a>.
</p><p>Some of these movements have brought internal disputes and strife within regional Buddhist communities. For example, the Dhammakaya movement in Thailand teaches a "true self" doctrine, which traditional Theravada monks consider as heretically denying the fundamental <i>anatta</i> (<a href="/wiki/Anatt%C4%81" title="Anattā">not-self</a>) doctrine of Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams2008125–128_746-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams2008125–128-746">[682]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-747"><a href="#cite_note-747">[683]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-748"><a href="#cite_note-748">[684]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sexual_abuse_and_misconduct">Sexual abuse and misconduct</span></h3>
<p>Buddhism has not been immune from sexual abuse and misconduct scandals, with victims coming forward in various Buddhist schools such as <a href="/wiki/Zen" title="Zen">Zen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism" title="Tibetan Buddhism">Tibetan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-749"><a href="#cite_note-749">[685]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-750"><a href="#cite_note-750">[686]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-751"><a href="#cite_note-751">[687]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-752"><a href="#cite_note-752">[688]</a></sup> "There are huge cover ups in the Catholic church, but what has happened within Tibetan Buddhism is totally along the same lines," says Mary Finnigan, an author and journalist who has been chronicling such alleged abuses since the mid-80s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-753"><a href="#cite_note-753">[689]</a></sup> One notably covered <a href="/wiki/Sogyal_Rinpoche#Abuse_allegations" title="Sogyal Rinpoche">case</a> in media of various Western countries was that of <a href="/wiki/Sogyal_Rinpoche" title="Sogyal Rinpoche">Sogyal Rinpoche</a> which began in 1994,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-754"><a href="#cite_note-754">[690]</a></sup> and ended with his retirement from his position as <a href="/wiki/Rigpa_(organization)" title="Rigpa (organization)">Rigpa</a>'s spiritual director in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-755"><a href="#cite_note-755">[691]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Cultural_influence">Cultural influence</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Buddhism" title="Culture of Buddhism">Culture of Buddhism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Potala_Palace,_Tibet.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1152" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Potala_Palace%2C_Tibet.jpg/220px-Potala_Palace%2C_Tibet.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Potala_Palace%2C_Tibet.jpg/330px-Potala_Palace%2C_Tibet.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Potala_Palace%2C_Tibet.jpg/440px-Potala_Palace%2C_Tibet.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Potala_Palace,_Tibet.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lhasa's <a href="/wiki/Potala_Palace" title="Potala Palace">Potala Palace</a>, today a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a>, pictured in 2019</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mahabodhitemple.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="1944" decoding="async" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Mahabodhitemple.jpg/220px-Mahabodhitemple.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Mahabodhitemple.jpg/330px-Mahabodhitemple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Mahabodhitemple.jpg/440px-Mahabodhitemple.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mahabodhitemple.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>India's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mahabodhi_temple" title="Mahabodhi temple">Mahabodhi temple</a>, built under the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empire</a>, 6th century CE</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ChuaMotCot1.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/ChuaMotCot1.JPG/220px-ChuaMotCot1.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/ChuaMotCot1.JPG/330px-ChuaMotCot1.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/ChuaMotCot1.JPG/440px-ChuaMotCot1.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ChuaMotCot1.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/One_Pillar_Pagoda" title="One Pillar Pagoda">One Pillar Pagoda</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a>, Vietnam</div></div></div>
<p>Buddhism has had a profound influence on various cultures, especially in Asia. <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_philosophy" title="Buddhist philosophy">Buddhist philosophy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_art" title="Buddhist art">Buddhist art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_architecture" title="Buddhist architecture">Buddhist architecture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_cuisine" title="Buddhist cuisine">Buddhist cuisine</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhist_festivals" title="Buddhist festivals">Buddhist festivals</a> continue to be influential elements of the modern <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Asia" title="Culture of Asia">Culture of Asia</a>, especially in <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East Asia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/East_Asian_cultural_sphere" title="East Asian cultural sphere">Sinosphere</a> as well as in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Indosphere" title="Indosphere">Indosphere</a>. According to Litian Fang, Buddhism has "permeated a wide range of fields, such as politics, ethics, philosophy, literature, art and customs," in these Asian regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-756"><a href="#cite_note-756">[692]</a></sup>
</p><p>Buddhist teachings influenced the development of modern <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a> as well as other <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Asia" title="Religion in Asia">Asian religions</a> like <a href="/wiki/Taoism" title="Taoism">Taoism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a>. For example, various scholars have argued that key Hindu thinkers such as <a href="/wiki/Adi_Shankara" title="Adi Shankara">Adi Shankara</a> and <a href="/wiki/Patanjali" title="Patanjali">Patanjali</a>, author of the <a href="/wiki/Yoga_Sutras_of_Patanjali" title="Yoga Sutras of Patanjali">Yoga sutras</a>, were influenced by Buddhist ideas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-757"><a href="#cite_note-757">[693]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-758"><a href="#cite_note-758">[694]</a></sup> Likewise, Buddhist practices were influential in the early development of Indian <a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">Yoga</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-759"><a href="#cite_note-759">[695]</a></sup>
</p><p>Buddhist philosophers like <a href="/wiki/Dign%C4%81ga" title="Dignāga">Dignaga</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dharmakirti" title="Dharmakirti">Dharmakirti</a> were very influential in the development of <a href="/wiki/Indian_logic" title="Indian logic">Indian logic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pramana" title="Pramana">epistemology</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-760"><a href="#cite_note-760">[696]</a></sup> Buddhist educational institutions like <a href="/wiki/Nalanda" title="Nalanda">Nalanda</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vikramashila" title="Vikramashila">Vikramashila</a> preserved various disciplines of classical Indian knowledge such as <a href="/wiki/Grammar" title="Grammar">grammar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Astronomy" title="Astronomy">astronomy</a>/<a href="/wiki/Astrology" title="Astrology">astrology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Medicine" title="Medicine">medicine</a> and taught foreign students from Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDutt1988332–333_761-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDutt1988332–333-761">[697]</a></sup>
</p><p>Buddhist institutions were major centers for the study and practice of traditional forms of medicine, including <a href="/wiki/Ayurveda" title="Ayurveda">Ayurveda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine" title="Traditional Chinese medicine">Chinese medicine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Tibetan_medicine" title="Traditional Tibetan medicine">Tibetan medicine</a>. According to Pierce Salguero, Buddhist monasteries had "ample opportunity and motivation to combine imported and local therapies, and the institutional contexts in which to accumulate oral and tacit knowledge of what was efficacious."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_762-0"><a href="#cite_note-:2-762">[698]</a></sup> The most important of these Buddhist centers of medical practice (such as <a href="/wiki/Nalanda" title="Nalanda">Nālandā</a>) produced medical texts, <a href="/wiki/Materia_medica" title="Materia medica">materia medica</a>, <a href="/wiki/Medication" title="Medication">pharmaceuticals</a> and trained doctors which were widely disseminated across the Buddhist world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_762-1"><a href="#cite_note-:2-762">[698]</a></sup> Nālandā University was also said to have been the site of the composition of the <i>Aṣṭāṅgahṛdaya-saṃhitā</i>, an influential medical work by the physician <a href="/wiki/Vagbhata" title="Vagbhata">Vāgbhaṭa</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:13_763-0"><a href="#cite_note-:13-763">[699]</a></sup> Buddhists spread these traditional approaches to health, sometimes called "Buddhist medicine", throughout East and Southeast Asia, where they remain influential today in regions like Sri Lanka, Burma, Tibet and Thailand.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-764"><a href="#cite_note-764">[700]</a></sup>
</p><p>In an effort to preserve their sacred scriptures, Buddhist institutions such as temples and monasteries housed schools which educated the populace and promoted <a href="/wiki/Writing" title="Writing">writing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Literacy" title="Literacy">literacy</a>. This led to high levels of literacy among some traditional Buddhist societies such as Burma. According to David Steinberg, "Early British observers claimed that Burma was the most literate state between Suez and Japan, and one British traveler in the early nineteenth century believed that Burmese women had a higher percentage of literacy than British women."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-765"><a href="#cite_note-765">[701]</a></sup>
</p><p>Buddhist institutions were also at the forefront of the adoption of Chinese technologies related to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bookmaking" title="Bookmaking">bookmaking</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Papermaking" title="Papermaking">papermaking</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Woodblock_printing" title="Woodblock printing">block printing</a> which Buddhists often deployed on a large scale. Examples of the early Buddhist adoption of these technologies are a Buddhist charm which is the first surviving printed text, the Chinese <a href="/wiki/Diamond_Sutra" title="Diamond Sutra">Diamond Sutra</a> (c. 868) which is the first full printed book and the first hand colored print, which is an illustration of Guanyin dated to 947.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-766"><a href="#cite_note-766">[702]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px"><div style="width: 235px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;"><div style="margin:18px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:COLLECTIE_TROPENMUSEUM_Temperaschilderij_voorstellende_de_Borobudur_als_bedevaartsoord_TMnr_75-2.jpg" title="A painting by G. B. Hooijer (c. 1916–1919) reconstructing a scene of Borobudur, the largest Buddhist temple in the world"><img alt="A painting by G. B. Hooijer (c. 1916–1919) reconstructing a scene of Borobudur, the largest Buddhist temple in the world" data-file-height="554" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="139" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/COLLECTIE_TROPENMUSEUM_Temperaschilderij_voorstellende_de_Borobudur_als_bedevaartsoord_TMnr_75-2.jpg/200px-COLLECTIE_TROPENMUSEUM_Temperaschilderij_voorstellende_de_Borobudur_als_bedevaartsoord_TMnr_75-2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/COLLECTIE_TROPENMUSEUM_Temperaschilderij_voorstellende_de_Borobudur_als_bedevaartsoord_TMnr_75-2.jpg/300px-COLLECTIE_TROPENMUSEUM_Temperaschilderij_voorstellende_de_Borobudur_als_bedevaartsoord_TMnr_75-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/COLLECTIE_TROPENMUSEUM_Temperaschilderij_voorstellende_de_Borobudur_als_bedevaartsoord_TMnr_75-2.jpg/400px-COLLECTIE_TROPENMUSEUM_Temperaschilderij_voorstellende_de_Borobudur_als_bedevaartsoord_TMnr_75-2.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>A painting by G. B. Hooijer (c. 1916–1919) reconstructing a scene of <a href="/wiki/Borobudur" title="Borobudur">Borobudur</a>, the largest Buddhist temple in the world
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 235px"><div style="width: 235px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 230px;"><div style="margin:17.5px auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jingangjing.jpg" title="Frontispiece of the Chinese Diamond Sūtra, the oldest known dated printed book in the world"><img alt="Frontispiece of the Chinese Diamond Sūtra, the oldest known dated printed book in the world" data-file-height="3438" data-file-width="4917" decoding="async" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Jingangjing.jpg/200px-Jingangjing.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Jingangjing.jpg/300px-Jingangjing.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Jingangjing.jpg/400px-Jingangjing.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Book_frontispiece" title="Book frontispiece">Frontispiece</a> of the Chinese <i>Diamond Sūtra</i>, the oldest known dated <a href="/wiki/Woodblock_printing" title="Woodblock printing">printed</a> book in the world
</p>
</div>
</div></li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_influence">Modern influence</span></h3>
<p>In the Western world, Buddhism has had a strong influence on modern <a href="/wiki/New_Age" title="New Age">New Age</a> spirituality and other alternative spiritualities. This began with its influence on 20th century <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Theosophists" title="Theosophists">Theosophists</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Helena_Blavatsky" title="Helena Blavatsky">Helena Blavatsky</a>, which were some of the first Westerners to take Buddhism seriously as a spiritual tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-767"><a href="#cite_note-767">[703]</a></sup>
</p><p>More recently, Buddhist meditation practices have influenced the development of modern <a href="/wiki/Psychology" title="Psychology">psychology</a>, particularly the practice of <a href="/wiki/Mindfulness-based_stress_reduction" title="Mindfulness-based stress reduction">Mindfulness-based stress reduction</a> (MBSR) and other similar <a href="/wiki/Mindfulness" title="Mindfulness">mindfulness</a> based modalities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-768"><a href="#cite_note-768">[704]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-769"><a href="#cite_note-769">[705]</a></sup> The influence of <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_and_psychology" title="Buddhism and psychology">Buddhism on psychology</a> can also be seen in certain forms of modern <a href="/wiki/Psychoanalysis" title="Psychoanalysis">psychoanalysis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-770"><a href="#cite_note-770">[706]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-771"><a href="#cite_note-771">[707]</a></sup>
</p><p>Buddhism also influenced the modern <a href="/wiki/Avant-garde" title="Avant-garde">avant-garde</a> movements during the 1950s and 60s through people like <a href="/wiki/D._T._Suzuki" title="D. T. Suzuki">D. T. Suzuki</a> and his influence on figures like <a href="/wiki/Jack_Kerouac" title="Jack Kerouac">Jack Kerouac</a> and <a href="/wiki/Allen_Ginsberg" title="Allen Ginsberg">Allen Ginsberg</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-772"><a href="#cite_note-772">[708]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Relationships_with_other_religious_traditions">Relationships with other religious traditions</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Shamanism">Shamanism</span></h4>
<p><a href="/wiki/Shamanism" title="Shamanism">Shamanism</a> is a widespread practice in Buddhist societies. Buddhist monasteries have long existed alongside local shamanic traditions. Lacking an institutional orthodoxy, Buddhists adapted to the local cultures, blending their own traditions with pre-existing shamanic culture. There was very little conflict between the sects, mostly limited to the shamanic practice of animal sacrifice, which Buddhists see as equivalent to killing one's parents. However, Buddhism requires acceptance of Buddha as the greatest being in the cosmos, and local shamanic traditions were bestowed an inferior status.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shamanism33_773-0"><a href="#cite_note-Shamanism33-773">[709]</a></sup>
</p><p>Research into Himalayan religion has shown that Buddhist and shamanic traditions overlap in many respects: the worship of localized deities, healing rituals and exorcisms. The shamanic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gurung" title="Gurung">Gurung</a> people have adopted some of the Buddhist beliefs such and rebirth but maintain the shamanic rites of "guiding the soul" after death. <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_Samuel" title="Geoffrey Samuel">Geoffrey Samuel</a> describes Shamanic Buddhism: "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vajrayana_Buddhism" title="Vajrayana Buddhism">Vajrayana Buddhism</a> as practiced in <a href="/wiki/Tibet" title="Tibet">Tibet</a> may be described as shamanic, in that it is centered around communication with an alternative mode of reality via the alternative states of consciousness of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tantric_Yoga" title="Tantric Yoga">Tantric Yoga</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shamanism33_773-1"><a href="#cite_note-Shamanism33-773">[709]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_by_country" title="Buddhism by country">Buddhism by country</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Buddhism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Buddhist_data_by_Pew_Research.svg"><img alt="Purple Percentage of Buddhists by country, showing high in Burma to low in United States" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="443" data-file-width="863" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Buddhism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Buddhist_data_by_Pew_Research.svg/330px-Buddhism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Buddhist_data_by_Pew_Research.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Buddhism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Buddhist_data_by_Pew_Research.svg/495px-Buddhism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Buddhist_data_by_Pew_Research.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Buddhism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Buddhist_data_by_Pew_Research.svg/660px-Buddhism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Buddhist_data_by_Pew_Research.svg.png 2x" width="330"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Buddhism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Buddhist_data_by_Pew_Research.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Percentage of Buddhists by country, according to the <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research Center</a>, as of 2010</div></div></div>
<p>Buddhism is practised by an estimated 488 million,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012a_6-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012a-6">[6]</a></sup> 495 million,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJohnsonGrim201334–37_774-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJohnsonGrim201334–37-774">[710]</a></sup> or 535 million<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey20135_775-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey20135-775">[711]</a></sup> people as of the 2010s, representing 7% to 8% of the world's total population.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> is the country with the largest population of Buddhists, approximately 244 million or 18% of its total population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012a_6-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012a-6">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-777"><a href="#cite_note-777">[note 50]</a></sup> They are mostly followers of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Buddhism" title="Chinese Buddhism">Chinese schools</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahayana</a></i>, making this the largest body of Buddhist traditions. Mahayana, also practised in broader <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_East_Asia" title="Buddhism in East Asia">East Asia</a>, is followed by over half of world Buddhists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012a_6-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012a-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to a demographic analysis reported by Peter Harvey:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey20135_775-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey20135-775">[711]</a></sup> <i>Mahayana</i> has 360 million adherents; <i><a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a></i> has 150 million adherents; and <i><a href="/wiki/Vajrayana" title="Vajrayana">Vajrayana</a></i> has 18 million adherents.
</p><p>According to <a href="#CITEREFJohnsonGrim2013">Johnson &amp; Grim (2013)</a>, Buddhism has grown from a total of 138 million adherents in 1910, of which 137 million were in <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>, to 495 million in 2010, of which 487 million are in Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJohnsonGrim201334–37_774-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJohnsonGrim201334–37-774">[710]</a></sup> Over 98% of all Buddhists live in the Asia-Pacific and South Asia region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012_778-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012-778">[713]</a></sup> North America had about 3.9 million Buddhists, Europe 1.3 million, while South America, Africa and the Middle East had an estimated combined total of about 1 million Buddhists in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012_778-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012-778">[713]</a></sup>
</p><p>Buddhism is the dominant religion in <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Bhutan" title="Buddhism in Bhutan">Bhutan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Myanmar" title="Buddhism in Myanmar">Myanmar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Cambodia" title="Buddhism in Cambodia">Cambodia</a>, Hong Kong,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-779"><a href="#cite_note-779">[714]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Japan" title="Buddhism in Japan">Japan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-780"><a href="#cite_note-780">[715]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Tibet" title="Buddhism in Tibet">Tibet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Laos" title="Buddhism in Laos">Laos</a>, Macau,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-781"><a href="#cite_note-781">[716]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Mongolia" title="Buddhism in Mongolia">Mongolia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Singapore" title="Buddhism in Singapore">Singapore</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-782"><a href="#cite_note-782">[717]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Sri_Lanka" title="Buddhism in Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Thailand" title="Buddhism in Thailand">Thailand</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Vietnam" title="Buddhism in Vietnam">Vietnam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-783"><a href="#cite_note-783">[718]</a></sup> Large Buddhist populations live in <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Buddhism" title="Chinese Buddhism">Mainland China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Taiwan" title="Buddhism in Taiwan">Taiwan</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Korea" title="Buddhism in Korea">North Korea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Nepal" title="Buddhism in Nepal">Nepal</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Korea" title="Buddhism in Korea">South Korea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_784-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-784">[719]</a></sup> In Russia, Buddhists form majority in <a href="/wiki/Tuva" title="Tuva">Tuva</a> (52%) and <a href="/wiki/Kalmykia" title="Kalmykia">Kalmykia</a> (53%). <a href="/wiki/Buryatia" title="Buryatia">Buryatia</a> (20%) and <a href="/wiki/Zabaykalsky_Krai" title="Zabaykalsky Krai">Zabaykalsky Krai</a> (15%) also have significant Buddhist populations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-785"><a href="#cite_note-785">[720]</a></sup>
</p><p>Buddhism is also growing by conversion. In New Zealand, about 25–35% of the total Buddhists are converts to Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-786"><a href="#cite_note-786">[721]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-787"><a href="#cite_note-787">[722]</a></sup> Buddhism has also spread to the <a href="/wiki/Nordic_countries" title="Nordic countries">Nordic countries</a>; for example, the Burmese Buddhists founded in the city of <a href="/wiki/Kuopio" title="Kuopio">Kuopio</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_Savonia" title="North Savonia">North Savonia</a> the first Buddhist monastery of <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a>, named the Buddha Dhamma Ramsi monastery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-788"><a href="#cite_note-788">[723]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 12 countries with the largest Buddhist population densities are:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012_778-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012-778">[713]</a></sup>
</p>
