</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Explanatory_notes">Explanatory notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-columns references-column-width reflist-columns-2">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-32"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-32">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Buddhist texts such as the <a href="/wiki/Jataka_tales" title="Jataka tales">Jataka tales</a> of the Theravada Buddhist tradition, and early biographies such as the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhacarita" title="Buddhacarita">Buddhacarita</a></i>, the <a href="/wiki/Lokottarav%C4%81da" title="Lokottaravāda">Lokottaravādin</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81vastu" title="Mahāvastu">Mahāvastu</a></i>, the <a href="/wiki/Sarvastivada" title="Sarvastivada">Sarvāstivādin</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Lalitavistara_S%C5%ABtra" title="Lalitavistara Sūtra">Lalitavistara Sūtra</a></i>, give different accounts about the life of the Buddha; many include stories of his many rebirths, and some add significant embellishments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESwearer2004177_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESwearer2004177-25">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199815–24_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199815–24-26">[26]</a></sup> Keown and Prebish state, "In the past, modern scholars have generally accepted 486 or 483 BCE for this [Buddha's death], but the consensus is now that they rest on evidence which is too flimsy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2010105–106_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2010105–106-27">[27]</a></sup> Scholars are hesitant to make unqualified claims about the historical facts of the Buddha's life. Most accept that he lived, taught and founded a monastic order, but do not consistently accept all of the details contained in his biographies."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004352_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004352-28">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELopez199516_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELopez199516-29">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarrithers198610_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarrithers198610-30">[30]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArmstrong2004xii_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArmstrong2004xii-31">[31]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-33"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-33">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The exact identity of this ancient place is unclear. Please see <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Gautama Buddha</a> article for various sites identified.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-35">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Bihar is derived from <i>Vihara</i>, which means monastery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198849_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198849-34">[32]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-40"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-40">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Other details about Buddha'a background are contested in modern scholarship. For example, Buddhist texts assert that Buddha described himself as a <i>kshatriya</i> (warrior class), but states Gombrich, little is known about his father and there is no proof that his father even knew the term <i>kshatriya</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198850_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198850-38">[35]</a></sup> Mahavira, whose teachings helped establish another major ancient religion <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a>, is also claimed to be <i>ksatriya</i> by his early followers. Further, early texts of both Jainism and Buddhism suggest they emerged in a period of urbanisation in ancient India, one with city nobles and prospering urban centres, states, agricultural surplus, trade and introduction of money.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198850–51_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198850–51-39">[36]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-49"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-49">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The earliest Buddhist biographies of the Buddha mention these Vedic-era teachers. Outside of these early Buddhist texts, these names do not appear, which has led some scholars to raise doubts about the historicity of these claims.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWynne20078–23_45-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWynne20078–23-45">[41]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst201319–32_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst201319–32-47">[43]</a></sup> According to Alexander Wynne, the evidence suggests that Buddha studied under these Vedic-era teachers and they "almost certainly" taught him, but the details of his education are unclear.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWynne20078–23_45-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWynne20078–23-45">[41]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa199322–26_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa199322–26-48">[44]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-63"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-63">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Theravada tradition traces its origins as the oldest tradition holding the Pali Canon as the only authority, Mahayana tradition revers the Canon but also the derivative literature that developed in the 1st millennium CE and its roots are traceable to the 1st century BCE, while Vajrayana tradition is closer to the Mahayana, includes Tantra, is the younger of the three and traceable to the 1st millennium CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin19981–2,_49–58,_253–271_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin19981–2,_49–58,_253–271-61">[56]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams19891–25_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams19891–25-62">[57]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Samsara-72"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Samsara_72-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">On samsara, rebirth and redeath:<br/>* Paul Williams: "All rebirth is due to karma and is impermanent. Short of attaining enlightenment, in each rebirth one is born and dies, to be reborn elsewhere in accordance with the completely impersonal causal nature of one's own karma. The endless cycle of birth, rebirth, and redeath, is samsara."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200274–75_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200274–75-67">[61]</a></sup><br/>* Buswell and Lopez on "rebirth": "An English term that does not have an exact correlate in Buddhist languages, rendered instead by a range of technical terms, such as the Sanskrit <i>Punarjanman</i> (lit. "birth again") and <i>Punabhavan</i> (lit. "re-becoming"), and, less commonly, the related <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Redeath" title="Redeath">PUNARMRTYU</a> (lit. "redeath")."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708-68">[62]</a></sup><br/><br/>See also Perry Schmidt-Leukel (2006) pp. 32–34,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchmidt-Leukel200632–34_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmidt-Leukel200632–34-69">[63]</a></sup> John J. Makransky (1997) p. 27.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMakransky199727_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMakransky199727-70">[64]</a></sup> for the use of the term "redeath." The term <i>Agatigati</i> or <i>Agati gati</i> (plus a few other terms) is generally translated as 'rebirth, redeath'; see any Pali-English dictionary; e.g. pp. 94–95 of Rhys Davids &amp; William Stede, where they list five Sutta examples with rebirth and re-death sense.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[65]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Moksha-88"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Moksha_88-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Graham Harvey: "Siddhartha Gautama found an end to rebirth in this world of suffering. His teachings, known as the dharma in Buddhism, can be summarized in the Four Noble truths."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2016_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2016-74">[67]</a></sup> Geoffrey Samuel (2008): "The Four Noble Truths [...] describe the knowledge needed to set out on the path to liberation from rebirth."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2008136_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2008136-75">[68]</a></sup> See also <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpiro198242_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpiro198242-76">[69]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi,_xxxi–xxxii_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi,_xxxi–xxxii-77">[70]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMakransky199727–28_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMakransky199727–28-78">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200274–75_67-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200274–75-67">[61]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELopez2009147_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELopez2009147-79">[72]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2016_74-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2016-74">[67]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKingsland2016286_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKingsland2016286-80">[73]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB-DL_Four_Truths_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-EB-DL_Four_Truths-81">[web 1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[web 2]</a></sup><br/><br/>The Theravada tradition holds that insight into these four truths is liberating in itself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarter19873179_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarter19873179-83">[74]</a></sup> This is reflected in the Pali canon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnderson2013_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnderson2013-84">[75]</a></sup> According to Donald Lopez, "The Buddha stated in his first sermon that when he gained absolute and intuitive knowledge of the four truths, he achieved complete enlightenment and freedom from future rebirth."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB-DL_Four_Truths_81-1"><a href="#cite_note-EB-DL_Four_Truths-81">[web 1]</a></sup><br/><br/>The <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maha-parinibbana_Sutta" title="Maha-parinibbana Sutta">Maha-parinibbana Sutta</a></i> also refers to this liberation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[web 3]</a></sup> Carol Anderson: "The second passage where the four truths appear in the <i>Vinaya-pitaka</i> is also found in the <i>Mahaparinibbana-sutta</i> (D II 90–91). Here, the Buddha explains that it is by not understanding the four truths that rebirth continues."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnderson2013162_with_note_38,_for_context_see_pp._1–3_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnderson2013162_with_note_38,_for_context_see_pp._1–3-86">[76]</a></sup><br/><br/>On the meaning of moksha as liberation from rebirth, see Patrick Olivelle in the <i>Encyclopædia Britannica</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brittanica_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-Brittanica-87">[web 4]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-91"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-91">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">As opposite to <i>sukha</i>, "pleasure," it is better translated as "pain."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201326–31_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201326–31-90">[77]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-101"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-101">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This explanation is more common in commentaries on the Four Noble Truths within the <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a> tradition: e.g. <a href="#CITEREFAjahn_Sucitto2010">Ajahn Sucitto (2010)</a>; Ajahn Sumedho (ebook);<a href="#CITEREFRahula1974">Rahula (1974)</a>; etc.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Nirodha-106"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Nirodha_106-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Ending rebirth:<br/>* Graham Harvey: "The Third Noble Truth is nirvana. The Buddha tells us that an end to suffering is possible, and it is nirvana. Nirvana is a "blowing out," just as a candle flame is extinguished in the wind, from our lives in samsara. It connotes an end to rebirth"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2016_74-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2016-74">[67]</a></sup><br/>* Spiro: "The Buddhis message then, as I have said, is not simply a psychological message, i.e. that desire is the cause of suffering because unsatisfied desire produces frustration. It does contain such a message to be sure; but more importantly it is an eschatological message. Desire is the cause of suffering because desire is the cause of rebirth; and the extinction of desire leads to deliverance from suffering because it signals release from the Wheel of Rebirth."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpiro198242_76-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpiro198242-76">[69]</a></sup><br/>* John J. Makransky: "The third noble truth, cessation (<i>nirodha</i>) or nirvana, represented the ultimate aim of Buddhist practice in the Abhidharma traditions: the state free from the conditions that created samsara. Nirvana was the ultimate and final state attained when the supramundane yogic path had been completed. It represented salvation from samsara precisely because it was understood to comprise a state of complete freedom from the chain of samsaric causes and conditions, i.e., precisely because it was unconditioned (<i>asamskrta</i>)."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMakransky199727–28_78-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMakransky199727–28-78">[71]</a></sup><br/>* Walpola Rahula: "Let us consider a few definitions and descriptions of Nirvana as found in the original Pali texts [...] 'It is the complete cessation of that very thirst (tanha), giving it up, renouncing it, emancipation from it, detachment from it.' [...] 'The abandoning and destruction of craving for these Five Aggregates of Attachment: that is the cessation of <i>dukkha</i>. [...] 'The Cessation of Continuity and becoming (<i>Bhavanirodha</i>) is Nibbana.'"<sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTERahula2014[[Category:Wikipedia_articles_needing_page_number_citations_from_October_2020]]&lt;sup_class="noprint_Inline-Template_"_style="white-space:nowrap;"&gt;&amp;#91;&lt;i&gt;[[Wikipedia:Citing_sources|&lt;span_title="This_citation_requires_a_reference_to_the_specific_page_or_range_of_pages_in_which_the_material_appears.&amp;#32;(October_2020)"&gt;page&amp;nbsp;needed&lt;/span&gt;]]&lt;/i&gt;&amp;#93;&lt;/sup&gt;_105-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTERahula2014[[Category:Wikipedia_articles_needing_page_number_citations_from_October_2020]]&lt;sup_class="noprint_Inline-Template_"_style="white-space:nowrap;"&gt;&amp;#91;&lt;i&gt;[[Wikipedia:Citing_sources|&lt;span_title="This_citation_requires_a_reference_to_the_specific_page_or_range_of_pages_in_which_the_material_appears.&amp;#32;(October_2020)"&gt;page&amp;nbsp;needed&lt;/span&gt;]]&lt;/i&gt;&amp;#93;&lt;/sup&gt;-105'>[89]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-realms2-119"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-realms2_119-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Earlier Buddhist texts refer to five realms rather than six realms; when described as five realms, the god realm and demi-god realm constitute a single realm.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004711–712_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004711–712-118">[101]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-129"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-129">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This merit gaining may be on the behalf of one's family members.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709_126-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709-126">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Neufeldt1986p123_127-1"><a href="#cite_note-Neufeldt1986p123-127">[109]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SwatosKivisto1998p66_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-SwatosKivisto1998p66-128">[110]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-143"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-143">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The realms in which a being is reborn are:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200460–63_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200460–63-132">[113]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish201336–38_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish201336–38-133">[114]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[subnote 1]</a></sup>
<ol><li><a href="/wiki/Naraka_(Buddhism)" title="Naraka (Buddhism)">Naraka</a>: beings believed in Buddhism to suffer in one of many Narakas (Hells);</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Preta" title="Preta">Preta</a>: sometimes sharing some space with humans, but invisible; an important variety is the <a href="/wiki/Hungry_ghost" title="Hungry ghost">hungry ghost</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey199833_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey199833-136">[115]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Animals_in_Buddhism" title="Animals in Buddhism">Tiryag</a> (animals): existence as an animal along with humans; this realm is traditionally thought in Buddhism to be similar to a hellish realm because animals are believed to be driven by impulse; they prey on each other and suffer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish201336_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish201336-137">[116]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Human_beings_in_Buddhism" title="Human beings in Buddhism">Manusya</a> (human beings): one of the realms of rebirth in which attaining Nirvana is possible; A rebirth in this realm is therefore considered as fortunate and an opportunity to end the endless Samsara and associated Dukkha.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200462_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200462-138">[117]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish201336–37_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish201336–37-139">[118]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Asura_(Buddhism)" title="Asura (Buddhism)">Asuras</a>: variously translated as lowly deities, demi-gods, demons, titans, or anti-gods; recognised in Theravada tradition as part of the heavenly realm;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBareau1955212–223_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBareau1955212–223-140">[119]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Deva_(Buddhism)" title="Deva (Buddhism)">Devas</a> including <a href="/wiki/Brahm%C4%81_(Buddhism)" title="Brahmā (Buddhism)">Brahmās</a>: variously translated as gods, deities, angels, or heavenly beings. The vast majority of Buddhist lay people have historically pursued Buddhist rituals and practices motivated by rebirth into the Deva realm.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200462_138-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200462-138">[117]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGowans2004169_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGowans2004169-141">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Merv_Fowler_1999_65_142-0"><a href="#cite_note-Merv_Fowler_1999_65-142">[121]</a></sup></li></ol>
</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-151"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-151">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Diseases and suffering induced by the disruptive actions of other people are examples of non-karma suffering.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41_150-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41-150">[128]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-156"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-156">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The emphasis on intent in Buddhism marks its difference from the karma theory of Jainism where karma accumulates with or without intent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340-153">[130]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKrishan199747,_55_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKrishan199747,_55-154">[131]</a></sup> The emphasis on intent is also found in Hinduism, and Buddhism may have influenced karma theories of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[132]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-165"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-165">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This Buddhist idea may have roots in the <i>quid-pro-quo</i> exchange beliefs of the Hindu Vedic rituals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Egge2013_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-Egge2013-163">[139]</a></sup> The "karma merit transfer" concept has been controversial, not accepted in later Jainism and Hinduism traditions, unlike Buddhism where it was adopted in ancient times and remains a common practice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-appletonp129_160-1"><a href="#cite_note-appletonp129-160">[136]</a></sup> According to Bruce Reichenbach, the "merit transfer" idea was generally absent in early Buddhism and may have emerged with the rise of Mahayana Buddhism; he adds that while major Hindu schools such as Yoga, Advaita Vedanta and others do not believe in merit transfer, some bhakti Hindu traditions later adopted the idea just like Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[140]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-168"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-168">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Another variant, which may be condensed to the eightfold or tenfold path, starts with a <i>Tathagatha</i> entering this world. A layman hears his teachings, decides to leave the life of a householder, starts living according to the moral precepts, guards his sense-doors, practises mindfulness and the four jhanas, gains the three knowledges, understands the Four Noble Truths and destroys the <a href="/wiki/Asava" title="Asava">taints</a>, and perceives that he is liberated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBucknell1984_109-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBucknell1984-109">[92]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-180"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-180">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The early Mahayana Buddhism texts link their discussion of "emptiness" (<i>shunyata</i>) to <i>Anatta</i> and <i>Nirvana</i>. They do so, states Mun-Keat Choong, in three ways: first, in the common sense of a monk's meditative state of emptiness; second, with the main sense of <i>anatta</i> or 'everything in the world is empty of self'; third, with the ultimate sense of <i>nirvana</i> or realisation of emptiness and thus an end to rebirth cycles of suffering.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Choong1999p85_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-Choong1999p85-179">[153]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-183"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-183">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Some scholars such as Cousins and Sangharakshita translate <i>apranaihita</i> as "aimlessness or directionless-ness".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams2005b56,_note_23_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams2005b56,_note_23-182">[155]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-191"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-191">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">These descriptions of nirvana in Buddhist texts, states Peter Harvey, are contested by scholars because nirvana in Buddhism is ultimately described as a state of "stopped consciousness (blown out), but one that is not non-existent", and "it seems impossible to imagine what awareness devoid of any object would be like".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201375–76_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201375–76-189">[161]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199874–84_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199874–84-190">[162]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-193"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-193">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Scholars note that better rebirth, not nirvana, has been the primary focus of a vast majority of lay Buddhists. This they attempt through merit accumulation and good <i>kamma</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGowans2004169_141-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGowans2004169-141">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Merv_Fowler_1999_65_142-1"><a href="#cite_note-Merv_Fowler_1999_65-142">[121]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-237"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-237">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Wayman and Wayman have disagreed with this view, and they state that the <i>Tathagatagarbha</i> is neither self nor sentient being, nor soul, nor personality.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams2008107_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams2008107-236">[206]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-329"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-329">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The hundreds of rules vary by the <i>sangha</i>; 11th-century Chinese monastic texts include rules such as only reciting the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhavacana" title="Buddhavacana">Buddha's Word</a> alone, not near commonplace people; not eating prohibited foods such as meat, fish, cheese, onions, garlic, animal fat; abstain from anything that can lead to sensual thoughts; etc.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[297]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-349"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-349">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Williams refers to <a href="#CITEREFFrauwallner1973">Frauwallner (1973</a>, p. 155)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-358"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-358">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Many ancient <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Upanishad" title="Upanishad">Upanishads</a> of Hinduism describe <a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">yoga</a> and meditation as a means to liberation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECollins2000199_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollins2000199-355">[322]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[323]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[324]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-375"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-375">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Keren Arbel refers to Majjhima Nikaya 26, <a class="external text" href="http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/mn/mn.026.than.html" rel="nofollow"><i>Ariyapariyesana Sutta, The Noble Search</i></a><br/>See also:<br/>* Majjhima Nikaya 111, <a class="external text" href="http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/mn/mn.111.than.html" rel="nofollow"><i>Anuppada Sutta</i></a><br/>* AN 05.028, <a class="external text" href="http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/an/an05/an05.028.than.html" rel="nofollow"><i>Samadhanga Sutta: The Factors of Concentration</i></a>.<br/>See Johansson (1981), <i>Pali Buddhist texts Explained to Beginners</i> for a word-by-word translation.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-380"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-380">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Arbel explains that "viveka" is usually translated as "detachment," "separation," or "seclusion," but the primary meaning is "discrimination." According to Arbel, the usage of <i>vivicca/vivicceva</i> and <i>viveka</i> in the description of the first <i>dhyana</i> "plays with both meanings of the verb; namely, it's meaning as discernment and the consequent 'seclusion' and letting go," in line with the "discenment of the nature of experience" developed by the four <i>satipatthanas</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArbel201650-51_377-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArbel201650-51-377">[342]</a></sup> Compare Dogen: "Being apart from all disturbances and dwelling alone in a quiet place is called "enjoying serenity and tranquility.""<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMaezumiCook200763_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMaezumiCook200763-378">[343]</a></sup><br/>Arbel further argues that <i>viveka</i> resembles <a href="/wiki/Dhamma_vicaya" title="Dhamma vicaya">dhamma vicaya</a>, which is mentioned in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bojjhanga" title="Bojjhanga">bojjhanga</a>, an alternative description of the <i>dhyanas</i>, but the only <i>bojjhanga</i>-term not mentioned in the stock <i>dhyana</i>-description.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArbel2016106_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArbel2016106-379">[344]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-386"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-386">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFChen2017">Chen 2017</a><span class="error harv-error" style="display: none; font-size:100%"> harvnb error: no target: CITEREFChen2017 (<a href="/wiki/Category:Harv_and_Sfn_template_errors" title="Category:Harv and Sfn template errors">help</a>)</span>: "Samadhi with general examination and specific in-depth investigation means getting rid of the <a href="/wiki/Kleshas_(Buddhism)" title="Kleshas (Buddhism)">not virtuous dharmas</a>, such as greedy desire and hatred, to stay in joy and pleasure caused by nonarising, and to enter the first meditation and fully dwell in it."<br/><a href="#CITEREFArbel2016">Arbel 2016</a>, p. 73<span class="error harv-error" style="display: none; font-size:100%"> harvnb error: no target: CITEREFArbel2016 (<a href="/wiki/Category:Harv_and_Sfn_template_errors" title="Category:Harv and Sfn template errors">help</a>)</span>: "Thus, my suggestion is that we should interpret the existence of <i>vitakka</i> and <i>vicara</i> in the first <i>jhana</i> as wholesome 'residues' of a previous development of wholesome thoughts. They denote the 'echo' of these wholesome thoughts, which reverberates in one who enters the first <i>jhana</i> as wholesome attitudes toward what is experienced."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-395"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-395">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pali_canon" title="Pali canon">Pali canon</a>, <i>Vitakka-vicāra</i> form one expression, which refers to directing one's thought or attention on an object (<i>vitarka</i>) and investigate it (<i>vicāra</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELusthaus200289_383-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELusthaus200289-383">[347]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERhys-DavidsStede1921–25_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERhys-DavidsStede1921–25-387">[350]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGuentherKawamura1975Kindle_Locations_1030-1033_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGuentherKawamura1975Kindle_Locations_1030-1033-388">[351]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKunsang200430_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKunsang200430-389">[352]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBerzin2006_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBerzin2006-390">[353]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Dan_Lusthaus" title="Dan Lusthaus">Dan Lusthaus</a>, <i>vitarka-vicāra</i> is analytic scrutiny, a form of <i><a href="/wiki/Praj%C3%B1%C4%81_(Buddhism)" title="Prajñā (Buddhism)">prajna</a></i>. It "involves focusing on [something] and then breaking it down into its functional components" to understand it, "distinguishing the multitude of conditioning factors implicated in a phenomenal event."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELusthaus2002116_391-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELusthaus2002116-391">[354]</a></sup> The Theravada commentarial tradition, as represented by <a href="/wiki/Buddhaghosa" title="Buddhaghosa">Buddhaghosa</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Visuddhimagga" title="Visuddhimagga">Visuddhimagga</a>, interprets <i>vitarka</i> and <i>vicāra</i> as the initial and sustained application of attention to a meditational object, which culminates in the stilling of the mind when moving on to the second dhyana.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBucknell1993375-376_392-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBucknell1993375-376-392">[355]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStuart-Fox198982_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStuart-Fox198982-393">[356]</a></sup> According to Fox and Bucknell it may also refer to "the normal process of discursive thought," which is quieted through absorption in the second <i>jhāna</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFox198982_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFox198982-394">[357]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBucknell1993375-376_392-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBucknell1993375-376-392">[355]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-399"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-399">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The standard translation for <i>samadhi</i> is "concentration"; yet, this translation/interpretation is based on commentarial interpretations, as explained by a number of contemporary authors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArbel2016_373-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArbel2016-373">[339]</a></sup> Tilmann Vetter notes that <i>samadhi</i> has a broad range of meanings, and "concentration" is just one of them. Vetter argues that the second, third and fourth <i>dhyana</i> are <i>samma-samadhi</i>, "right samadhi," building on a "spontaneous awareness" (sati) and equanimity which is perfected in the fourth <i>dhyana</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988XXVI,_note_9_398-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988XXVI,_note_9-398">[360]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-401"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-401">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The common translation, based on the commentarial interpretation of <i>dhyana</i> as expanding states of absorption, translates <i>sampasadana</i> as "internal assurance." Yet, as Bucknell explains, it also means "tranquilizing," which is more apt in this context.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBucknell1993375-376_392-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBucknell1993375-376-392">[355]</a></sup> See also <i><a href="/wiki/Passaddhi" title="Passaddhi">Passaddhi</a></i>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-402"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-402">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><i>Upekkhā</i> is one of the <a href="/wiki/Brahmavihara" title="Brahmavihara">Brahmaviharas</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-409"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-409">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">With the fourth <i>jhāna</i> comes the attainment of higher knowledge (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abhijna" title="Abhijna">abhijñā</a></i>), that is, the extinction of all mental intoxicants (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%80sava" title="Āsava">āsava</a></i>), but also psychic powers.<sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTESarbacker2021entry:_"abhijñā"_408-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarbacker2021entry:_"abhijñā"-408'>[367]</a></sup> For instance in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anguttara_Nikaya" title="Anguttara Nikaya">AN</a> 5.28, the Buddha states (Thanissaro, 1997.):<br/>"When a monk has developed and pursued the five-factored noble right concentration in this way, then whichever of the six higher knowledges he turns his mind to know and realize, he can witness them for himself whenever there is an opening...."<br/>"If he wants, he wields manifold supranormal powers. Having been one he becomes many; having been many he becomes one. He appears. He vanishes. He goes unimpeded through walls, ramparts, and mountains as if through space. He dives in and out of the earth as if it were water. He walks on water without sinking as if it were dry land. Sitting crosslegged he flies through the air like a winged bird. With his hand he touches and strokes even the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful. He exercises influence with his body even as far as the Brahma worlds. He can witness this for himself whenever there is an opening ..."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-414"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-414">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See, for example, Richard Shankman Richard (2008), <i>"The Experience of Samadhi,"</i> for an overview of the debate ("the Jnana wars") within Theravada Buddhism.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-435"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-435">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Buddha never claimed that the "four immeasurables" were his unique ideas, in a manner similar to "cessation, quieting, nirvana".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAronson198071_434-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAronson198071-434">[391]</a></sup> The Buddhist scripture <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Digha_Nikaya" title="Digha Nikaya">Digha Nikaya</a></i> II.251 asserts the Buddha to be calling the Brahmavihara as "that practice", and he then contrasts it with "my practice".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAronson198071_434-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAronson198071-434">[391]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-468"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-468">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Tillmann Vetter: "Very likely the cause was the growing influence of a non-Buddhist spiritual environment·which claimed that one can be released only by some truth or higher knowledge. In addition the alternative (and perhaps sometimes competing) method of discriminating insight (fully established after the introduction of the four noble truths) seemed to conform so well to this claim."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxxiii_467-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxxiii-467">[423]</a></sup><br/><br/>According to Bronkhorst, this happened under influence of the "mainstream of meditation," that is, Vedic-Brahmanical oriented groups, which believed that the cessation of action could not be liberating, since action can never be fully stopped. Their solution was to postulate a fundamental difference between the inner soul or self and the body. The inner self is unchangeable, and unaffected by actions. By insight into this difference, one was liberated. To equal this emphasis on insight, Buddhists presented insight into their most essential teaching as equally liberating. What exactly was regarded as the central insight "varied along with what was considered most central to the teaching of the Buddha."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199354–55,_96,_99_466-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199354–55,_96,_99-466">[422]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-548"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-548">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">While some interpretations state that Buddhism may have originated as a social reform, other scholars state that it is incorrect and anachronistic to regard the Buddha as a social reformer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QueenKing1996p17_546-0"><a href="#cite_note-QueenKing1996p17-546">[501]</a></sup> Buddha's concern was "to reform individuals, help them to leave society forever, not to reform the world... he never preached against social inequality". <a href="/wiki/Richard_Gombrich" title="Richard Gombrich">Richard Gombrich</a>, quoted by Christopher Queen.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QueenKing1996p17_546-1"><a href="#cite_note-QueenKing1996p17-546">[501]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198830–31_547-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198830–31-547">[502]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-565"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-565">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Digha_Nikaya" title="Digha Nikaya">Digha Nikaya</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Majjhima_Nikaya" title="Majjhima Nikaya">Majjhima Nikaya</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samyutta_Nikaya" title="Samyutta Nikaya">Samyutta Nikaya</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anguttara_Nikaya" title="Anguttara Nikaya">Anguttara Nikaya</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-571"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-571">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The surviving portions of the scriptures of <a href="/wiki/Sarvastivada" title="Sarvastivada">Sarvastivada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mulasarvastivada" title="Mulasarvastivada">Mulasarvastivada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%AB%C5%9B%C4%81saka" title="Mahīśāsaka">Mahīśāsaka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dharmaguptaka" title="Dharmaguptaka">Dharmaguptaka</a> and other schools.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988ix_569-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988ix-569">[522]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarder2000_570-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarder2000-570">[523]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-577"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-577">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Exemplary studies are the study on descriptions of "liberating insight" by Lambert Schmithausen,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchmithausen1981_573-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmithausen1981-573">[525]</a></sup> the overview of early Buddhism by Tilmann Vetter,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988_173-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988-173">[147]</a></sup> the philological work on the four truths by K.R. Norman,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorman1992_574-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorman1992-574">[526]</a></sup> the textual studies by Richard Gombrich,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich1997_575-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich1997-575">[527]</a></sup> and the research on early meditation methods by Johannes Bronkhorst.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1997_576-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1997-576">[528]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-583"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-583">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Well-known proponents of the first position are <a href="/wiki/A._K._Warder" title="A. K. Warder">A. K. Warder</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-580"><a href="#cite_note-580">[subnote 2]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Richard_Gombrich" title="Richard Gombrich">Richard Gombrich</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1997viii_581-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1997viii-581">[531]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-582"><a href="#cite_note-582">[subnote 3]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-586"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-586">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A proponent of the second position is Ronald Davidson.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-585"><a href="#cite_note-585">[subnote 4]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-593"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-593">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Well-known proponents of the third position are J.W. de Jong,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJong199325_587-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJong199325-587">[533]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jong_588-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jong-588">[subnote 5]</a></sup> Johannes Bronkhorst<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-590"><a href="#cite_note-590">[subnote 6]</a></sup> and Donald Lopez.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-592"><a href="#cite_note-592">[subnote 7]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-China_Buswell_2004-630"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-China_Buswell_2004_630-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"The most important evidence – in fact the only evidence – for situating the emergence of the Mahayana around the beginning of the common era was not Indian evidence at all, but came from China. Already by the last quarter of the 2nd century CE, there was a small, seemingly idiosyncratic collection of substantial Mahayana sutras translated into what Erik Zürcher calls 'broken Chinese' by an Indoscythian, whose Indian name has been reconstructed as Lokaksema."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004492_629-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004492-629">[571]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-South-633"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-South_633-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"The south (of India) was then vigorously creative in producing Mahayana Sutras" Warder<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarder2000335_632-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarder2000335-632">[573]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Hill-653"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Hill_653-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See Hill (2009), p. 30, for the Chinese text from the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hou_Hanshu" title="Hou Hanshu">Hou Hanshu</a></i>, and p. 31 for a translation of it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHill200930–31_652-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHill200930–31-652">[592]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-alternative_scheme-676"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-alternative_scheme_676-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHarvey1998">Harvey (1998)</a>, <a href="#CITEREFGombrich1984">Gombrich (1984)</a>, <a href="#CITEREFGethin1998">Gethin (1998</a>, pp. 1–2); identifies "three broad traditions" as: (1) "The Theravāda tradition of Sri Lanka and South-East Asia, also sometimes referred to as 'southern' Buddhism"; (2) "The East Asian tradition of China, Korea, Japan, and Vietnam, also sometimes referred to as 'eastern' Buddhism"; and, (3) "The Tibetan tradition, also sometimes referred to as 'northern' Buddhism.";<br/><a href="#CITEREFRobinsonJohnson1982">Robinson &amp; Johnson (1982)</a> divide their book into two parts: Part One is entitled "The Buddhism of South Asia" (which pertains to Early Buddhism in India); and, Part Two is entitled "The Development of Buddhism Outside of India" with chapters on "The Buddhism of Southeast Asia", "Buddhism in the Tibetan Culture Area", "East Asian Buddhism" and "Buddhism Comes West";<br/><i>Penguin Handbook of Living Religions</i>, 1984, p. 279;<br/>Prebish &amp; Keown, <i>Introducing Buddhism</i>, ebook, Journal of Buddhist Ethics, 2005, printed ed, Harper, 2006.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-other_schemes-677"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-other_schemes_677-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See e.g. the multi-dimensional classification in <a href="#CITEREFEliade_et_al.1987">Eliade et al. (1987)</a>, pp. 440ff <i>Encyclopedia of Religion</i></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-777"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-777">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This is a contested number. Official numbers from the Chinese government are lower, while other surveys are higher. According to Katharina Wenzel-Teuber, in non-government surveys, "49 percent of self-claimed non-believers [in China] held some religious beliefs, such as believing in soul reincarnation, heaven, hell, or supernatural forces. Thus the 'pure atheists' make up only about 15 percent of the sample [surveyed]."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-776"><a href="#cite_note-776">[712]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Subnotes">Subnotes</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1011085734" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="reflist reflist-columns references-column-width reflist-columns-2">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-135"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-135">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The realms of rebirths in Buddhism are further subdivided into 31 planes of existence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[web 7]</a></sup> Rebirths in some of the higher heavens, known as the <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_cosmology#Pure_Abodes" title="Buddhist cosmology">Śuddhāvāsa Worlds</a> or Pure Abodes, can be attained only by skilled Buddhist practitioners known as <a href="/wiki/An%C4%81g%C4%81mi" title="Anāgāmi">anāgāmis</a> (non-returners). Rebirths in the <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_cosmology#Formless_Realm_(Ārūpyadhātu)" title="Buddhist cosmology">Ārūpyadhātu</a> (formless realms) can be attained by only those who can meditate on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ar%C5%ABpajh%C4%81na" title="Arūpajhāna">arūpajhānas</a>, the highest object of meditation.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-580"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-580">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to A.K. Warder, in his 1970 publication "Indian Buddhism", from the oldest extant texts a common kernel can be drawn out.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarder2000_570-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarder2000-570">[523]</a></sup> According to Warder, c.q. his publisher: "This kernel of doctrine is presumably common Buddhism of the period before the great schisms of the fourth and third centuries BC. It may be substantially the Buddhism of the Buddha himself, although this cannot be proved: at any rate it is a Buddhism presupposed by the schools as existing about a hundred years after the parinirvana of the Buddha, and there is no evidence to suggest that it was formulated by anyone else than the Buddha and his immediate followers."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarder2000inside_flap_579-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarder2000inside_flap-579">[530]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-582"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-582">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Richard Gombrich: "I have the greatest difficulty in accepting that the main edifice is not the work of a single genius. By "the main edifice" I mean the collections of the main body of sermons, the four Nikāyas, and of the main body of monastic rules."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich1997_575-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich1997-575">[527]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-585"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-585">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Ronald Davidson: "While most scholars agree that there was a rough body of sacred literature (disputed)(sic) that a relatively early community (disputed)(sic) maintained and transmitted, we have little confidence that much, if any, of surviving Buddhist scripture is actually the word of the historic Buddha."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDavidson2003147_584-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDavidson2003147-584">[532]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Jong-588"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Jong_588-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">J.W. De Jong: "It would be hypocritical to assert that nothing can be said about the doctrine of earliest Buddhism [...] the basic ideas of Buddhism found in the canonical writings could very well have been proclaimed by him [the Buddha], transmitted and developed by his disciples and, finally, codified in fixed formulas."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJong199325_587-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJong199325-587">[533]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-590"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-590">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Bronkhorst: "This position is to be preferred to (ii) for purely methodological reasons: only those who seek nay find, even if no success is guaranteed."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1997vii_589-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1997vii-589">[534]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-592"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-592">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Lopez: "The original teachings of the historical Buddha are extremely difficult, if not impossible, to recover or reconstruct."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELopez19954_591-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELopez19954-591">[535]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div>

<li id="cite_note-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-14">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFAvison2021">Avison, Austin (4 October 2021). <a class="external text" href="https://scholarworks.wmich.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1429&amp;context=hilltopreview" rel="nofollow">"Delusional Mitigation in Religious and Psychological Forms of Self-Cultivation: Buddhist and Clinical Insight on Delusional Symptomatology"</a>. <i><a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=The_Hilltop_Review&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="The Hilltop Review (page does not exist)">The Hilltop Review</a></i>. <b>12</b> (6): 1–29 – via Digital Commons.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Hilltop+Review&amp;rft.atitle=Delusional+Mitigation+in+Religious+and+Psychological+Forms+of+Self-Cultivation%3A+Buddhist+and+Clinical+Insight+on+Delusional+Symptomatology&amp;rft.volume=12&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.pages=1-29&amp;rft.date=2021-10-04&amp;rft.aulast=Avison&amp;rft.aufirst=Austin&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fscholarworks.wmich.edu%2Fcgi%2Fviewcontent.cgi%3Farticle%3D1429%26context%3Dhilltopreview&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-White_2000_21-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-White_2000_21_15-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-White_2000_21_15-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFWhite2000">White, David Gordon, ed. (2000). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=hayV4o50eUEC&amp;pg=PA21" rel="nofollow"><i>Tantra in Practice</i></a>. Princeton University Press. p. 21. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-691-05779-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-691-05779-8"><bdi>978-0-691-05779-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Tantra+in+Practice&amp;rft.pages=21&amp;rft.pub=Princeton+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2000&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-691-05779-8&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DhayV4o50eUEC%26pg%3DPA21&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEPowers200726–27-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPowers200726–27_16-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPowers2007">Powers (2007)</a>, pp. 26–27.</span>

<li id="cite_note-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-17">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Candles in the Dark: A New Spirit for a Plural World" by Barbara Sundberg Baudot, p. 305</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-18">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFClausDiamondMills2020">Claus, Peter; Diamond, Sarah; Mills, Margaret (28 October 2020). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Dg4HEAAAQBAJ&amp;dq=buddhism+indian+subcontinent+2nd+millennium&amp;pg=PA80" rel="nofollow"><i>South Asian Folklore: An Encyclopedia</i></a>. Routledge. p. 80. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-000-10122-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-000-10122-5"><bdi>978-1-000-10122-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=South+Asian+Folklore%3A+An+Encyclopedia&amp;rft.pages=80&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2020-10-28&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-000-10122-5&amp;rft.aulast=Claus&amp;rft.aufirst=Peter&amp;rft.au=Diamond%2C+Sarah&amp;rft.au=Mills%2C+Margaret&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DDg4HEAAAQBAJ%26dq%3Dbuddhism%2Bindian%2Bsubcontinent%2B2nd%2Bmillennium%26pg%3DPA80&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-19">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFAkira_HirakawaPaul_Groner1993">Akira Hirakawa; Paul Groner (1993). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=XjjwjC7rcOYC" rel="nofollow"><i>A History of Indian Buddhism: From Śākyamuni to Early Mahāyāna</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-21"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-21">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFJonathan_H._X._LeeKathleen_M._Nadeau2011">Jonathan H. X. Lee; Kathleen M. Nadeau (2011). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/encyclopediaofas00leej/page/504" rel="nofollow"><i>Encyclopedia of Asian American Folklore and Folklife</i></a>. ABC-CLIO. p. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/encyclopediaofas00leej/page/504" rel="nofollow">504</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-313-35066-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-313-35066-5"><bdi>978-0-313-35066-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+of+Asian+American+Folklore+and+Folklife&amp;rft.pages=504&amp;rft.pub=ABC-CLIO&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-313-35066-5&amp;rft.au=Jonathan+H.+X.+Lee&amp;rft.au=Kathleen+M.+Nadeau&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fencyclopediaofas00leej%2Fpage%2F504&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span>, Quote: "The three other major Indian religions – Buddhism, Jainism and Sikhism – originated in India as an alternative to Brahmanic/Hindu philosophy";<br/><a href="/wiki/Jan_Gonda" title="Jan Gonda">Jan Gonda</a> (1987), <i>Indian Religions: An Overview – Buddhism and Jainism</i>, Encyclopedia of Religion, 2nd Edition, Volume 7, Editor: Lindsay Jones, Macmillan Reference, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-02-865740-3" title="Special:BookSources/0-02-865740-3">0-02-865740-3</a>, p. 4428;<br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFK._T._S._SaraoJefferey_Long2017"><a href="/wiki/K._T._S._Sarao" title="K. T. S. Sarao">K. T. S. Sarao</a>; Jefferey Long (2017). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=m0_njwEACAAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>Encyclopedia of Indian Religions: Buddhism and Jainism</i></a>. Springer Netherlands. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-94-024-0851-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-94-024-0851-5"><bdi>978-94-024-0851-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+of+Indian+Religions%3A+Buddhism+and+Jainism&amp;rft.pub=Springer+Netherlands&amp;rft.date=2017&amp;rft.isbn=978-94-024-0851-5&amp;rft.au=K.+T.+S.+Sarao&amp;rft.au=Jefferey+Long&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dm0_njwEACAAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span>, Quote: "Buddhism and Jainism, two religions which, together with Hinduism, constitute the three pillars of Indic religious tradition in its classical formulation."</span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201326–31-90"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201326–31_90-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFEmmanuel2013">Emmanuel (2013)</a>, pp. 26–31.</span>

<li id='cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich2005a47,_Quote:_"All_phenomenal_existence_[in_Buddhism]_is_said_to_have_three_interlocking_characteristics:_impermanence,_suffering_and_lack_of_soul_or_essence."-92'><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href='#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich2005a47,_Quote:_"All_phenomenal_existence_[in_Buddhism]_is_said_to_have_three_interlocking_characteristics:_impermanence,_suffering_and_lack_of_soul_or_essence."_92-0'>^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFGombrich2005a">Gombrich (2005a)</a>, p. 47, Quote: "All phenomenal existence [in Buddhism] is said to have three interlocking characteristics: impermanence, suffering and lack of soul or essence.".</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-britannicaanatta-93"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-britannicaanatta_93-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/anatta" rel="nofollow">Anatta Buddhism</a>, Encyclopædia Britannica (2013)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-94"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-94">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">[a] <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFChristmas_Humphreys2012">Christmas Humphreys (2012). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=V3rYtmCZEIEC" rel="nofollow"><i>Exploring Buddhism</i></a>. Routledge. pp. 42–43. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-136-22877-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-136-22877-3"><bdi>978-1-136-22877-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Exploring+Buddhism&amp;rft.pages=42-43&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-136-22877-3&amp;rft.au=Christmas+Humphreys&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DV3rYtmCZEIEC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span><br/>[b] <a href="#CITEREFGombrich2005a">Gombrich (2005a</a>, p. 47), Quote: "(...) Buddha's teaching that beings have no soul, no abiding essence. This 'no-soul doctrine' (anatta-vada) he expounded in his second sermon."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-5sourcesanatta-95"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5sourcesanatta_95-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><i>[a]</i> <a class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/anatta" rel="nofollow">Anatta</a>, Encyclopædia Britannica (2013), Quote: "Anatta in Buddhism, the doctrine that there is in humans no permanent, underlying soul. The concept of anatta, or anatman, is a departure from the Hindu belief in atman ("the self").";<br/><i>[b]</i> Steven Collins (1994), Religion and Practical Reason (Editors: Frank Reynolds, David Tracy), State Univ of New York Press, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7914-2217-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7914-2217-5">978-0-7914-2217-5</a>, p. 64; "Central to Buddhist <a href="/wiki/Soteriology" title="Soteriology">soteriology</a> is the doctrine of <a href="/wiki/Anatt%C4%81" title="Anattā">not-self</a> (Pali: anattā, Sanskrit: anātman, the opposed doctrine of ātman is central to Brahmanical thought). Put very briefly, this is the [Buddhist] doctrine that human beings have no soul, no self, no unchanging essence.";<br/><i>[c]</i> John C. Plott et al. (2000), <i>Global History of Philosophy: The Axial Age</i>, Volume 1, Motilal Banarsidass, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-208-0158-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-208-0158-5">978-81-208-0158-5</a>, p. 63, Quote: "The Buddhist schools reject any Ātman concept. As we have already observed, this is the basic and ineradicable distinction between Hinduism and Buddhism";<br/><i>[d]</i> Katie Javanaud (2013), <a class="external text" href="https://philosophynow.org/issues/97/Is_The_Buddhist_No-Self_Doctrine_Compatible_With_Pursuing_Nirvana" rel="nofollow">Is The Buddhist 'No-Self' Doctrine Compatible With Pursuing Nirvana?</a>, Philosophy Now;<br/><i>[e]</i> David Loy (1982), "Enlightenment in Buddhism and Advaita Vedanta: Are Nirvana and Moksha the Same?", <i>International Philosophical Quarterly</i>, Volume 23, Issue 1, pp. 65–74</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-96"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-96">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBrian_Morris2006">Brian Morris (2006). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=PguGB_uEQh4C&amp;pg=PA51" rel="nofollow"><i>Religion and Anthropology: A Critical Introduction</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p. 51. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-85241-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-85241-8"><bdi>978-0-521-85241-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Religion+and+Anthropology%3A+A+Critical+Introduction&amp;rft.pages=51&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-85241-8&amp;rft.au=Brian+Morris&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DPguGB_uEQh4C%26pg%3DPA51&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span>, Quote: "(...) anatta is the doctrine of non-self, and is an extreme empiricist doctrine that holds that the notion of an unchanging permanent self is a fiction and has no reality. According to Buddhist doctrine, the individual person consists of five skandhas or heaps – the body, feelings, perceptions, impulses and consciousness. The belief in a self or soul, over these five skandhas, is illusory and the cause of suffering."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-GombrichScherrer2008p209-97"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-GombrichScherrer2008p209_97-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFRichard_Francis_GombrichCristina_Anna_Scherrer-Schaub2008">Richard Francis Gombrich; Cristina Anna Scherrer-Schaub (2008). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=U7_Rea05eAMC" rel="nofollow"><i>Buddhist Studies</i></a>. Motilal Banarsidass. pp. 209–210. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-208-3248-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-208-3248-0"><bdi>978-81-208-3248-0</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Buddhist+Studies&amp;rft.pages=209-210&amp;rft.pub=Motilal+Banarsidass&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-208-3248-0&amp;rft.au=Richard+Francis+Gombrich&amp;rft.au=Cristina+Anna+Scherrer-Schaub&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DU7_Rea05eAMC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span></span>

<li id='cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200458,_Quote:_"Buddhism_shares_with_Hinduism_the_doctrine_of_Samsara,_whereby_all_beings_pass_through_an_unceasing_cycle_of_birth,_death_and_rebirth_until_they_find_a_means_of_liberation_from_the_cycle._However,_Buddhism_differs_from_Hinduism_in_rejecting_the_assertion_that_every_human_being_possesses_a_changeless_soul_which_constitutes_his_or_her_ultimate_identity,_and_which_transmigrates_from_one_incarnation_to_the_next.-112'><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href='#cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200458,_Quote:_"Buddhism_shares_with_Hinduism_the_doctrine_of_Samsara,_whereby_all_beings_pass_through_an_unceasing_cycle_of_birth,_death_and_rebirth_until_they_find_a_means_of_liberation_from_the_cycle._However,_Buddhism_differs_from_Hinduism_in_rejecting_the_assertion_that_every_human_being_possesses_a_changeless_soul_which_constitutes_his_or_her_ultimate_identity,_and_which_transmigrates_from_one_incarnation_to_the_next._112-0'>^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFTrainor2004">Trainor (2004)</a>, p. 58, Quote: "Buddhism shares with Hinduism the doctrine of Samsara, whereby all beings pass through an unceasing cycle of birth, death and rebirth until they find a means of liberation from the cycle. However, Buddhism differs from Hinduism in rejecting the assertion that every human being possesses a changeless soul which constitutes his or her ultimate identity, and which transmigrates from one incarnation to the next..</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilson2010-113"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilson2010_113-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilson2010_113-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFWilson2010">Wilson (2010)</a>.</span>

</li>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEConze201371,_Quote:_&quot;Nirvana_is_the_''raison_d'être''_of_Buddhism,_and_its_ultimate_justification.&quot;-116"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConze201371,_Quote:_&quot;Nirvana_is_the_''raison_d'être''_of_Buddhism,_and_its_ultimate_justification.&quot;_116-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFConze2013">Conze (2013)</a>, p. 71, Quote: "Nirvana is the <i>raison d'être</i> of Buddhism, and its ultimate justification.".</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEChoong199928–29,_Quote:_&quot;Seeing_(''passati'')_the_nature_of_things_as_impermanent_leads_to_the_removal_of_the_view_of_self,_and_so_to_the_realisation_of_nirvana.&quot;-121"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChoong199928–29,_Quote:_&quot;Seeing_(''passati'')_the_nature_of_things_as_impermanent_leads_to_the_removal_of_the_view_of_self,_and_so_to_the_realisation_of_nirvana.&quot;_121-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFChoong1999">Choong (1999)</a>, pp. 28–29, Quote: "Seeing (<i>passati</i>) the nature of things as impermanent leads to the removal of the view of self, and so to the realisation of nirvana.".</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-Leaman2002p23-124"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Leaman2002p23_124-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFOliver_Leaman2002">Oliver Leaman (2002). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=vK-GAgAAQBAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>Eastern Philosophy: Key Readings</i></a>. Routledge. pp. 23–27. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-134-68919-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-134-68919-4"><bdi>978-1-134-68919-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Eastern+Philosophy%3A+Key+Readings&amp;rft.pages=23-27&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-134-68919-4&amp;rft.au=Oliver+Leaman&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DvK-GAgAAQBAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-125"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-125">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">[a] <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFChristmas_Humphreys2012">Christmas Humphreys (2012). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=V3rYtmCZEIEC" rel="nofollow"><i>Exploring Buddhism</i></a>. Routledge. pp. 42–43. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-136-22877-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-136-22877-3"><bdi>978-1-136-22877-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Exploring+Buddhism&amp;rft.pages=42-43&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-136-22877-3&amp;rft.au=Christmas+Humphreys&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DV3rYtmCZEIEC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span><br/>[b] <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBrian_Morris2006">Brian Morris (2006). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=PguGB_uEQh4C&amp;pg=PA51" rel="nofollow"><i>Religion and Anthropology: A Critical Introduction</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p. 51. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-85241-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-85241-8"><bdi>978-0-521-85241-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Religion+and+Anthropology%3A+A+Critical+Introduction&amp;rft.pages=51&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-85241-8&amp;rft.au=Brian+Morris&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DPguGB_uEQh4C%26pg%3DPA51&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span>, Quote: "(...) anatta is the doctrine of non-self, and is an extreme empiricist doctrine that holds that the notion of an unchanging permanent self is a fiction and has no reality. According to Buddhist doctrine, the individual person consists of five skandhas or heaps – the body, feelings, perceptions, impulses and consciousness. The belief in a self or soul, over these five skandhas, is illusory and the cause of suffering."<br/>[c] <a href="#CITEREFGombrich2005a">Gombrich (2005a</a>, p. 47), Quote: "(...) Buddha's teaching that beings have no soul, no abiding essence. This 'no-soul doctrine' (anatta-vada) he expounded in his second sermon."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709-126"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709_126-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709_126-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709_126-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709_126-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBuswellLopez2003">Buswell &amp; Lopez (2003)</a>, pp. 708–709.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Neufeldt1986p123-127"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Neufeldt1986p123_127-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Neufeldt1986p123_127-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFRonald_Wesley_Neufeldt1986">Ronald Wesley Neufeldt (1986). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=iaRWtgXjplQC" rel="nofollow"><i>Karma and Rebirth: Post Classical Developments</i></a>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-SwatosKivisto1998p66-128"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-SwatosKivisto1998p66_128-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFWilliam_H._SwatosPeter_Kivisto1998">William H. Swatos; Peter Kivisto (1998). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=6TMFoMFe-D8C" rel="nofollow"><i>Encyclopedia of Religion and Society</i></a>. Rowman Altamira. p. 66. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7619-8956-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7619-8956-1"><bdi>978-0-7619-8956-1</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+of+Religion+and+Society&amp;rft.pages=66&amp;rft.pub=Rowman+Altamira&amp;rft.date=1998&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7619-8956-1&amp;rft.au=William+H.+Swatos&amp;rft.au=Peter+Kivisto&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D6TMFoMFe-D8C&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey199834-130"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey199834_130-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHarvey1998">Harvey (1998)</a>, p. 34.</span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200460–63-132"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200460–63_132-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFTrainor2004">Trainor (2004)</a>, pp. 60–63.</span>
