<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish201336–38-133"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish201336–38_133-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFKeownPrebish2013">Keown &amp; Prebish (2013)</a>, pp. 36–38.</span>

<li id="cite_note-Merv_Fowler_1999_65-142"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Merv_Fowler_1999_65_142-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Merv_Fowler_1999_65_142-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFFowler1999">Fowler (1999)</a>, p. 65 Quote: "For a vast majority of Buddhists in Theravadin countries, however, the order of monks is seen by lay Buddhists as a means of gaining the most merit in the hope of accumulating good karma for a better rebirth."</span>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-175"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-175">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFSteven_Collins2010">Steven Collins (2010). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=d5pshUYiUVwC" rel="nofollow"><i>Nirvana: Concept, Imagery, Narrative</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p. 31. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-88198-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-88198-2"><bdi>978-0-521-88198-2</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Nirvana%3A+Concept%2C+Imagery%2C+Narrative&amp;rft.pages=31&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-88198-2&amp;rft.au=Steven+Collins&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dd5pshUYiUVwC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span>, Quote: "This general scheme remained basic to later Hinduism, to Jainism, and to Buddhism. Eternal salvation, to use the Christian term, is not conceived of as world without end; we have already got that, called samsara, the world of rebirth and redeath: that is the problem, not the solution. The ultimate aim is the timeless state of moksha, or as the Buddhists seem to have been the first to call it, nirvana."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-176"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-176">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFSteven_Collins1990">Steven Collins (1990). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=8sLMkNn26-gC&amp;pg=PA5" rel="nofollow"><i>Selfless Persons: Imagery and Thought in Theravada Buddhism</i></a>. </li>

<li id="cite_note-195"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-195">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/John_Bowker_(theologian)" title="John Bowker (theologian)">John Bowker</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Oxford_Dictionary_of_World_Religions" title="Oxford Dictionary of World Religions">The Oxford Dictionary of World Religions</a></i> (1997), Oxford University Press, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-19-213965-7" title="Special:BookSources/0-19-213965-7">0-19-213965-7</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200264,_Quote:_In_the_''Mahatanhasankhaya_Sutta''_the_Buddha_[stresses]_that_things_originate_in_dependence_upon_causal_conditioning,_and_this_emphasis_on_causality_describes_the_central_feature_of_Buddhist_ontology._All_elements_of_samsara_exist_in_some_sense_or_another_relative_to_their_causes_and_conditions.-196"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200264,_Quote:_In_the_''Mahatanhasankhaya_Sutta''_the_Buddha_[stresses]_that_things_originate_in_dependence_upon_causal_conditioning,_and_this_emphasis_on_causality_describes_the_central_feature_of_Buddhist_ontology._All_elements_of_samsara_exist_in_some_sense_or_another_relative_to_their_causes_and_conditions._196-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFWilliams2002">Williams (2002)</a>, p. 64, Quote: In the <i>Mahatanhasankhaya Sutta</i> the Buddha [stresses] that things originate in dependence upon causal conditioning, and this emphasis on causality describes the central feature of Buddhist ontology. All elements of samsara exist in some sense or another relative to their causes and conditions..</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-197"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-197">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFRobert_Neville2004">Robert Neville (2004).  Jeremiah Hackett (ed.). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=kEER8fGxCfMC" rel="nofollow"><i>Philosophy of Religion for a New Century: Essays in Honor of Eugene Thomas Long</i></a>. Jerald Wallulis. Springer. p. 257. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4020-2073-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4020-2073-5"><bdi>978-1-4020-2073-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Philosophy+of+Religion+for+a+New+Century%3A+Essays+in+Honor+of+Eugene+Thomas+Long&amp;rft.pages=257&amp;rft.pub=Springer&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4020-2073-5&amp;rft.au=Robert+Neville&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DkEER8fGxCfMC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span>, Quote: "[Buddhism's ontological hypotheses] that nothing in reality has its own-being and that all phenomena reduce to the relativities of pratitya samutpada. The Buddhist ontological hypothesese deny that there is any ontologically ultimate object such a God, Brahman, the Dao, or any transcendent creative source or principle."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin1998153–155-198"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin1998153–155_198-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFGethin1998">Gethin (1998)</a>, pp. 153–155.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-199"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-199">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGuy_Debrock2012">Guy Debrock (2012).  Paul B. Scheurer (ed.). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Y18yBwAAQBAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>Newton's Scientific and Philosophical Legacy</i></a>. G. Debrock. Springer. p. 376, note 12. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-94-009-2809-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-94-009-2809-1"><bdi>978-94-009-2809-1</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Newton%27s+Scientific+and+Philosophical+Legacy&amp;rft.pages=376%2C+note+12&amp;rft.pub=Springer&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.isbn=978-94-009-2809-1&amp;rft.au=Guy+Debrock&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DY18yBwAAQBAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Kalupahana1975p54-200"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Kalupahana1975p54_200-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFDavid_J._Kalupahana1975">David J. Kalupahana (1975). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=GOYGAAAAYAAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>Causality: The Central Philosophy of Buddhism</i></a>. University of Hawaii Press. pp. 54–60. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8248-0298-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8248-0298-1"><bdi>978-0-8248-0298-1</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Causality%3A+The+Central+Philosophy+of+Buddhism&amp;rft.pages=54-60&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Hawaii+Press&amp;rft.date=1975&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8248-0298-1&amp;rft.au=David+J.+Kalupahana&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DGOYGAAAAYAAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-201"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-201">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGenjun_Sasaki1986">Genjun Sasaki (1986). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=vUBPAzlxJPUC" rel="nofollow"><i>Linguistic Approach to Buddhist Thought</i></a>. Motilal Banarsidass. pp. 67–69. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-208-0038-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-208-0038-0"><bdi>978-81-208-0038-0</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Linguistic+Approach+to+Buddhist+Thought&amp;rft.pages=67-69&amp;rft.pub=Motilal+Banarsidass&amp;rft.date=1986&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-208-0038-0&amp;rft.au=Genjun+Sasaki&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DvUBPAzlxJPUC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin1998151–152-202"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin1998151–152_202-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFGethin1998">Gethin (1998)</a>, pp. 151–152.</span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201365–72-203"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201365–72_203-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHarvey2013">Harvey (2013)</a>, pp. 65–72.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201351–66-204"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201351–66_204-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFEmmanuel2013">Emmanuel (2013)</a>, pp. 51–66.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey199854,_Quote:_&quot;The_main_concrete_application_of_the_abstract_principle_is_in_the_form_of_a_series_of_conditioned_links_(''nidanas''),_culminating_in_the_arising_of_dukkha.&quot;_(...)_&quot;This_[doctrine]_states_the_principle_of_conditionality,_that_all_things,_mental_and_physical,_arise_and_exist_due_to_the_presence_of_certain_conditions,_and_cease_once_their_conditions_are_removed:_nothing_(except_''Nibbana'')_is_independent._The_doctrine_thus_complements_the_teaching_that_no_permanent,_independent_self_can_be_found.&quot;-205"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey199854,_Quote:_&quot;The_main_concrete_application_of_the_abstract_principle_is_in_the_form_of_a_series_of_conditioned_links_(''nidanas''),_culminating_in_the_arising_of_dukkha.&quot;_(...)_&quot;This_[doctrine]_states_the_principle_of_conditionality,_that_all_things,_mental_and_physical,_arise_and_exist_due_to_the_presence_of_certain_conditions,_and_cease_once_their_conditions_are_removed:_nothing_(except_''Nibbana'')_is_independent._The_doctrine_thus_complements_the_teaching_that_no_permanent,_independent_self_can_be_found.&quot;_205-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHarvey1998">Harvey (1998)</a>, p. 54, Quote: "The main concrete application of the abstract principle is in the form of a series of conditioned links (<i>nidanas</i>), culminating in the arising of dukkha." (...) "This [doctrine] states the principle of conditionality, that all things, mental and physical, arise and exist due to the presence of certain conditions, and cease once their conditions are removed: nothing (except <i>Nibbana</i>) is independent. The doctrine thus complements the teaching that no permanent, independent self can be found.".</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-238"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-238">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Brunnholzl, Karl, When the Clouds Part, The <i>Uttaratantra</i> and Its Meditative Tradition as a Bridge between Sutra and Tantra, Snow Lion, Boston &amp; London, 2014, page 3.</span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams2008104–105,_108–109,_Quote:_&quot;..._[The_''Mahaparinirvana_Sutra'']_refers_to_the_Buddha_using_the_term_&quot;Self&quot;_in_order_to_win_over_non-Buddhist_ascetics.&quot;-239"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams2008104–105,_108–109,_Quote:_&quot;..._[The_''Mahaparinirvana_Sutra'']_refers_to_the_Buddha_using_the_term_&quot;Self&quot;_in_order_to_win_over_non-Buddhist_ascetics.&quot;_239-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFWilliams2008">Williams (2008)</a>, pp. 104–105, 108–109, Quote: "... [The <i>Mahaparinirvana Sutra</i>] refers to the Buddha using the term "Self" in order to win over non-Buddhist ascetics.".</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-240"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-240">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFFowler1999">Fowler (1999)</a>, pp. 101–102 Quote: "Some texts of the <i>tathagatagarbha</i> literature, such as the <i>Mahaparinirvana Sutra</i> actually refer to an <i>atman</i>, though other texts are careful to avoid the term. This would be in direct opposition to the general teachings of Buddhism on <i>anatta</i>. Indeed, the distinctions between the general Indian concept of <i>atman</i> and the popular Buddhist concept of Buddha-nature are often blurred to the point that writers consider them to be synonymous."</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-291"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-291">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFShōhei_Ichimura2001">Shōhei Ichimura (2001). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=xTW6XNxOxbkC" rel="nofollow"><i>Buddhist Critical Spirituality: Prajñā and Śūnyatā</i></a>. Motilal Banarsidass. p. 114. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-208-1798-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-208-1798-2"><bdi>978-81-208-1798-2</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Buddhist+Critical+Spirituality%3A+Praj%C3%B1%C4%81+and+%C5%9A%C5%ABnyat%C4%81&amp;rft.pages=114&amp;rft.pub=Motilal+Banarsidass&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-208-1798-2&amp;rft.au=Sh%C5%8Dhei+Ichimura&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DxTW6XNxOxbkC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-292"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-292">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFCarl_Olson2005">Carl Olson (2005). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/differentpathsof0000olso" rel="nofollow"><i>The Different Paths of Buddhism: A Narrative-Historical Introduction</i></a></span>. </li>

<li id="cite_note-436"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-436">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMartin_G._Wiltshire1990">Martin G. <li id="cite_note-461"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-461">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFJoseph_Mitsuo_KitagawaFrank_E._ReynoldsTheodore_M._Ludwig1980">Joseph Mitsuo Kitagawa; Frank E. Reynolds; Theodore M. Ludwig (1980). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=p4UeAAAAIAAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>Transitions and Transformations in the History of Religions: Essays in Honor of Joseph M. Kitagawa</i></a>. Brill Academic. pp. 56–58. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-90-04-06112-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-90-04-06112-5"><bdi>978-90-04-06112-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Transitions+and+Transformations+in+the+History+of+Religions%3A+Essays+in+Honor+of+Joseph+M.+Kitagawa&amp;rft.pages=56-58&amp;rft.pub=Brill+Academic&amp;rft.date=1980&amp;rft.isbn=978-90-04-06112-5&amp;rft.au=Joseph+Mitsuo+Kitagawa&amp;rft.au=Frank+E.+Reynolds&amp;rft.au=Theodore+M.+Ludwig&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dp4UeAAAAIAAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span>, Quote: "Suffering describes the condition of samsaric (this worldly) existence that arises from actions generated by <i>ignorance</i> of anatta and anicca. The doctrines of no-self and impermanence are thus the keystones of <i>dhammic</i> order."</span>

<li id='cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor2004108–109,_Quote:_"(...)_both_textual_and_archaeological_evidence_shows_that_devotion_has_long_been_a_part_of_Buddhism._The_practice_of_venerating_relics_and_images_has_long_played_a_central_role_even_in_Buddhist_traditions_that_strongly_emphasize_that_Gautama_Buddha_was_a_human_being_(...)".-485'><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href='#cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor2004108–109,_Quote:_"(...)_both_textual_and_archaeological_evidence_shows_that_devotion_has_long_been_a_part_of_Buddhism._The_practice_of_venerating_relics_and_images_has_long_played_a_central_role_even_in_Buddhist_traditions_that_strongly_emphasize_that_Gautama_Buddha_was_a_human_being_(...)"._485-0'>^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFTrainor2004">Trainor (2004)</a>, pp. 108–109, Quote: "(...) both textual and archaeological evidence shows that devotion has long been a part of Buddhism. The practice of venerating relics and images has long played a central role even in Buddhist traditions that strongly emphasize that Gautama Buddha was a human being (...)"..</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-Phelps,_Norm_2004_p._76-493"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Phelps,_Norm_2004_p._76_493-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Phelps,_Norm_2004_p._76_493-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Phelps, Norm (2004). <i>The Great Compassion: Buddhism &amp; Animal Rights.</i> New York: Lantern Books. p. 76. <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-59056-069-8" title="Special:BookSources/1-59056-069-8">1-59056-069-8</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-494"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-494">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://www.accesstoinsight.org/canon/sutta/anguttara/an05-177.html" rel="nofollow">Vanijja Sutta: Business (Wrong Livelihood)</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20051119074312/http://www.accesstoinsight.org/canon/sutta/anguttara/an05-177.html" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 19 November 2005 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-495"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-495">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://www.buddhanet.net/budsas/ebud/ebdha069.htm#note4" rel="nofollow">"Buddhism and Vegetarianism, The Rationale for the Buddha's Views on the Consumption of Meat"</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20131007043230/http://www.buddhanet.net/budsas/ebud/ebdha069.htm" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 2013-10-07 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a> by Dr V. A. Gunasekara" 'The rule of vegetarianism was the fifth of a list of rules which Devadatta had proposed to the Buddha. Devadatta was the founder of the tapasa movement in Buddhism and his special rules involved ascetic and austere practices (forest-dwelling, wearing only rags, etc). The Buddha rejected all the proposed revisions of Devadatta, and it was in this context that he reiterated the tikoiparisuddha rule. (On this see the author's Western Buddhism and a Theravada heterodoxy, BSQ Tracts on Buddhism'</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-496"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-496">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Phelps, Norm (2004). <i>The Great Compassion: Buddhism &amp; Animal Rights.</i> New York: Lantern Books. pp. 64-65. <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-59056-069-8" title="Special:BookSources/1-59056-069-8">1-59056-069-8</a>.</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-549"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-549">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHajime_Nakamura1983">Hajime Nakamura (1983). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=asNLliQHDNQC" rel="nofollow"><i>A History of Early Vedānta Philosophy</i></a>. Motilal Banarsidass. pp. 102–104, 264–269, 294–295. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-208-0651-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-208-0651-1"><bdi>978-81-208-0651-1</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+Early+Ved%C4%81nta+Philosophy&amp;rft.pages=102-104%2C+264-269%2C+294-295&amp;rft.pub=Motilal+Banarsidass&amp;rft.date=1983&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-208-0651-1&amp;rft.au=Hajime+Nakamura&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DasNLliQHDNQC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span>; Quote: "But the Upanishadic ultimate meaning of the Vedas, was, from the viewpoint of the Vedic canon in general, clearly a new idea.."; p. 95:  The [oldest] Upanishads in particular were part of the Vedic corpus (...) When these various new ideas were brought together and edited, they were added on to the already existing Vedic..."; p. 294: "When early Jainism came into existence, various ideas mentioned in the extant older Upanishads were current,....".</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-550"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-550">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKlaus_G._Witz1998">Klaus G. Witz (1998). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=2jnPlEqwe_UC" rel="nofollow"><i>The Supreme Wisdom of the Upaniṣads: An Introduction</i></a>. Motilal Banarsidass. pp. 1–2, 23. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-208-1573-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-208-1573-5"><bdi>978-81-208-1573-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Supreme+Wisdom+of+the+Upani%E1%B9%A3ads%3A+An+Introduction&amp;rft.pages=1-2%2C+23&amp;rft.pub=Motilal+Banarsidass&amp;rft.date=1998&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-208-1573-5&amp;rft.au=Klaus+G.+Witz&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D2jnPlEqwe_UC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span>; Quote: "In the <a href="/wiki/Aranyaka" title="Aranyaka">Aranyakas</a> therefore, thought and inner spiritual awareness started to separate subtler, deeper aspects from the context of ritual performance and myth with which they had been united up to then. This process was then carried further and brought to completion in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Upanishad" title="Upanishad">Upanishads</a>. (...) The knowledge and attainment of the Highest Goal had been there from the Vedic times. But in the Upanishads inner awareness, aided by major intellectual breakthroughs, arrived at a language in which Highest Goal could be dealt with directly, independent of ritual and sacred lore".<br/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFEdward_Fitzpatrick_Crangle1994">Edward Fitzpatrick Crangle (1994). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=HOzdcIxJy2sC" rel="nofollow"><i>The Origin and Development of Early Indian Contemplative Practices</i></a>. Otto Harrassowitz Verlag. pp. 58 with footnote 148, 22–29, 87–103, for Upanishads–Buddhist Sutta discussion see 65–72. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-3-447-03479-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-3-447-03479-1"><bdi>978-3-447-03479-1</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Origin+and+Development+of+Early+Indian+Contemplative+Practices&amp;rft.pages=58+with+footnote+148%2C+22-29%2C+87-103%2C+for+Upanishads-Buddhist+Sutta+discussion+see+65-72&amp;rft.pub=Otto+Harrassowitz+Verlag&amp;rft.date=1994&amp;rft.isbn=978-3-447-03479-1&amp;rft.au=Edward+Fitzpatrick+Crangle&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DHOzdcIxJy2sC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Olivelle1992-551"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Olivelle1992_551-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFPatrick_Olivelle1992">Patrick Olivelle (1992). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=fB8uneM7q1cC" rel="nofollow"><i>The Samnyasa Upanisads: Hindu Scriptures on Asceticism and Renunciation</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-597"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-597">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFSalomon2020">Salomon, Richard (20 January 2020). <a class="external text" href="https://www.lionsroar.com/how-the-gandharan-manuscripts-change-buddhist-history/" rel="nofollow">"How the Gandharan Manuscripts Change Buddhist History"</a>. <i>Lion's Roar</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-686"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-686">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFAnn_R._KinneyMarijke_J._KlokkeLydia_Kieven2003">Ann R. Kinney; Marijke J. Klokke; Lydia Kieven (2003). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=sfa2FiIERLYC" rel="nofollow"><i>Worshiping Siva and Buddha</i></a>. University of Hawaii Press. p. 20. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8248-2779-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8248-2779-3"><bdi>978-0-8248-2779-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Worshiping+Siva+and+Buddha&amp;rft.pages=20&amp;rft.pub=University+of+Hawaii+Press&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8248-2779-3&amp;rft.au=Ann+R.+Kinney&amp;rft.au=Marijke+J.+Klokke&amp;rft.au=Lydia+Kieven&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dsfa2FiIERLYC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span>; Quote: "Orthodox forms of Buddhism are collectively called Hinayana (...). <li id="cite_note-748"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-748">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMartin_MartyR_Scott_Appleby1994">Martin Marty; R Scott Appleby (1994). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=qd5yzP5hdiEC" rel="nofollow"><i>Fundamentalisms Observed</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-749"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-749">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFOppenheimer2014">Oppenheimer, Mark (18 December 2014). <a class="external text" href="https://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2014/12/the-zen-predator-of-the-upper-east-side/383831/" rel="nofollow">"The Zen Predator of the Upper East Side"</a>. <i>The Atlantic</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-750"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-750">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFCorder2018">Corder, Mike (14 September 2018). <a class="external text" href="https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2018-09-14/dalai-lama-meets-alleged-victims-of-abuse-by-buddhist-gurus" rel="nofollow">"Dalai Lama Meets Alleged Victims of Abuse by Buddhist Gurus"</a>. <i>US News</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-751"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-751">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFMarsh2018">Marsh, Sarah (5 March 2018). <a class="external text" href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/mar/05/buddhist-group-admits-sexual-abuse-by-teachers" rel="nofollow">"Buddhist group admits sexual abuse by teachers"</a>. <i>The Guardian</i>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Guardian&amp;rft.atitle=Buddhist+group+admits+sexual+abuse+by+teachers&amp;rft.date=2018-03-05&amp;rft.aulast=Marsh&amp;rft.aufirst=Sarah&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fworld%2F2018%2Fmar%2F05%2Fbuddhist-group-admits-sexual-abuse-by-teachers&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-752"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-752">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFSperryAtwood2018">Sperry, Rod Meade; Atwood, Haleigh (30 March 2018). <a class="external text" href="https://www.lionsroar.com/against-the-stream-to-investigate-allegations-of-sexual-misconduct-by-founding-teacher-noah-levine/" rel="nofollow">"Against the Stream to investigate allegations of sexual misconduct by Noah Levine; results expected within a month"</a>. <i>Lion's Roar</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-100"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-100">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFBhikkhu_Bodhi">Bhikkhu Bodhi. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180826212523/http://www.beyondthenet.net/dhamma/fourNoble.htm" rel="nofollow">"The Four Noble Truths"</a>. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.beyondthenet.net/dhamma/fourNoble.htm" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 26 August 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">28 May</span> 2016</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=The+Four+Noble+Truths&amp;rft.au=Bhikkhu+Bodhi&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.beyondthenet.net%2Fdhamma%2FfourNoble.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-134"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-134">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFMahathera">Mahathera, Ven. Suvanno. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130807234453/http://www.buddhanet.net/pdf_file/allexistence.pdf" rel="nofollow">"The 31 Planes of Existence"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. www.buddhanet.net. </li>
<li id="cite_note-675"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-675">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation encyclopaedia cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080609051748/http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/tibetan%20buddhism" rel="nofollow">"Tibetan Buddhism"</a>. <i>American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language</i>. Houghton Mifflin Company. 2004. </li>
</ol></div></div>

<li><a href="/wiki/Buddhism_and_Western_philosophy" title="Buddhism and Western philosophy">Western philosophy</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="background: #FFD068;;width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Category:Buddhism-related_lists" title="Category:Buddhism-related lists">Lists</a></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
